issueDTO.title: Add comprehensive test protection to our CI/CD
issueDTO.description:
Let???s define a comprehensive test standard in our wallet app monorepo to protect our code, at the same time, use reasonable way to reduce the execution of test on demand.

Standard:
* Trigger on demand: like the way shown in this PR: https://github.com/Greenstand/treetracker-wallet-app/pull/596/files Use different GitHub action to trigger test on demand, that is to say, just trigger some of the test when the file that are relevant to that kind of test changed.
* Naming: 
  * file: ci-cd-pr-[domain].yaml for example: ci-cd-pr-package-wallet.yaml
  * name: PR CI/CD for [domain] 
* Type of tests
  * E2E test, which means it request really API and really communicate with outside service and database, for example, the e2e test in packages/wallet, it really request the wallet api.
  * Integration test, which means it mocked some outside service, for example, the int test in apps/web, written by cypress, it mock the request to wallet api and return mock fake object, NOTE, sometimes the name of cypress test is e2e, but we basically use it as a interaction test, the name e2e is from the naming trandition of cypress community, so this is a little bit confusing, please note.
  * Unit test, just test a single function, single component e.g.

- [x] PR CI/CD for all
- [ ] #579 
- [ ] https://github.com/Greenstand/treetracker-wallet-app/issues/510
- [ ] #607
- [ ] #606

issueDTO.title: Replace deprecated package `coffee-script`
issueDTO.description:
**Describe the bug**

1. This package has been deprecated
2. This is not suitable for sustainable code

**To Reproduce**

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

1. Run the command `npm install`
2. Error occurs

**Expected behavior**


1. Run the command `npm install`
2. The error does not occur because the package has been suitably upgraded according to the recommendations of the organization that manages the package.
3. The application must continue to run
4. Feature functionality must be maintained

- Error message on installation

```
npm warn deprecated coffee-script@1.12.7: CoffeeScript on NPM has moved to "coffeescript" (no hyphen)

```

issueDTO.title: [Artifacts] Podman artifacts should support emitting events
issueDTO.description:
### Feature request description

Currently unlike other resources, Podman Artifacts doesn't emit any events when pulling, adding or removing etc. 

### Suggest potential solution

Add support to Podman to emit aforementioned events.

### Have you considered any alternatives?

N/A

### Additional context

N/A
comments: /assign

Too many commits 😅 
@ninja-quokka, @mheon Hope you're having a good day. I'd appreciate your advice on an issue I'm facing regarding the placement of artifact event logic.

I'm confused about where it should go and am debating two options:

- (1) `pkg/domain/infra/abi/artifact.go`
  - Pro: This mirrors the [network event implementation](https://github.com/containers/podman/blob/87b16eb6c997d824c3148911fef84cd8eabda72f/pkg/domain/infra/abi/network.go#L174-L176) and feels natural as logic related to the podman binary.

- (2) `container-libs/common/pkg/libartifact`
  - Pro: pkg/domain/infra/abi should just be a thin wrapper for libpod, so detailed implementation should go to libartifact with the other core artifact logic.
  - My Confusion: The event logic feels too Podman-specific to belong in container-libs.


Which location do you think is more appropriate?
Thanks!

> Too many commits 😅 
> @ninja-quokka, @mheon Hope you're having a good day. I'd appreciate your advice on an issue I'm facing regarding the placement of artifact event logic.
> 
> I'm confused about where it should go and am debating two options:
> 
> - (1) `pkg/domain/infra/abi/artifact.go`
>   - Pro: This mirrors the [network event implementation](https://github.com/containers/podman/blob/87b16eb6c997d824c3148911fef84cd8eabda72f/pkg/domain/infra/abi/network.go#L174-L176) and feels natural as logic related to the podman binary.
> 
> - (2) `container-libs/common/pkg/libartifact`
>   - Pro: pkg/domain/infra/abi should just be a thin wrapper for libpod, so detailed implementation should go to libartifact with the other core artifact logic.
>   - My Confusion: The event logic feels too Podman-specific to belong in container-libs.
> 
> 
> Which location do you think is more appropriate?
> Thanks!
> 
> 
> 

Hi mate!

My suggestion would be 1, because events are Podman specific. If you imagine a 3rd party project wanting to utilise libartifact wouldn't have use for the event logic.

I lean towards option 2, using a similar mechanism to what we use for libimage - https://github.com/containers/container-libs/blob/main/common/libimage/runtime.go#L70

We have a channel to send events. That channel can be set up when you initialize the library, but it doesn't need to be. Podman will pass a channel, other users will not.

This is the best way as the `pkg/domain/infra/abi` endpoints do not guarantee that events are always emitted. If I have a codepath in, say, `play kube` that calls directly into libartifact, there would be no event - despite an artifact being created.

> I lean towards option 2, using a similar mechanism to what we use for libimage - https://github.com/containers/container-libs/blob/main/common/libimage/runtime.go#L70
> 
> We have a channel to send events. That channel can be set up when you initialize the library, but it doesn't need to be. Podman will pass a channel, other users will not.
> 
> This is the best way as the `pkg/domain/infra/abi` endpoints do not guarantee that events are always emitted. If I have a codepath in, say, `play kube` that calls directly into libartifact, there would be no event - despite an artifact being created.

Ohh that's a great point about the channel being optional @mheon , I forgot about that!

I was missing the complete picture of the event processing architecture for each component. Thanks! 🙇 This approach looks better, as it guarantees that other code paths using `container-libs/common/pkg/libartifact` can receive events through the channel, if one is provided.

@mheon Would it be okay if I ask a couple of questions to check if we are on the same page?

(1) To use a similar mechanism, we would need to have a goroutine for receiving artifact events, right? https://github.com/containers/podman/blob/905721cae54adb755605a545fb2c6a5dd6404b1a/libpod/runtime.go#L687

(2) For the same reasons, it seems the `Network` event handling would potentially benefit from a similar refactoring in the future, given that it also depends on https://github.com/containers/container-libs/blob/97d630e8ce5b090c45c646f8669866b8958722c3/common/libnetwork/netavark/network.go#L24

Point 1 is accurate; the channel needs something reading it. Shouldn't be a big deal resource-wise as the channel will just block until events happen and won't be scheduled otherwise.

For point 2, I would generally agree. I believe @ashley-cui is working on a refactor of some of that code now that could include this?

Thanks! Got it. I want to work on this issue, through below the process. If there are something different with your thought, please tell me. This is the biggest task I've ever worked on in `Podman` so I want to get a confirmation from you. ???I'd appreciate your guidance when you have a moment. 🙇 

**1. container-libs**
  - Making a issue for this
  - common/pkg/libartifact/events.go
    - Adding required event type, struct, function
    - E.g. https://github.com/containers/container-libs/blob/main/common/libimage/events.go
  - common/pkg/libartifact/store/store.go
    - Adding eventChannel as a member variable
    - Adding event sending logics at each method such as Add
    - E.g. https://github.com/containers/container-libs/blob/36964d15757a4c8abea44e5fdac0cb31d98f3684/common/libimage/push.go#L106

**2. podman**
- docs/source/markdown/podman-events.1.md
  - documentation
- libpod/runtime.go
  - Adding `Runtime` method, which make a goroutine for getting artifact events through the channel. 
  - This method is called when initializing runtime.ArtifactStore
- libpod/events.go, libpod/events/config.go, libpod/events/events.go, libpod/events/journal_linux.go, libpod/events/logfile.go
  - Adding codes for handling artifact events in podman
- test/e2e/events_test.go
  - Adding e2e test for checking artifact events working properly.

issueDTO.title: Failure to index extremely distant dates
issueDTO.description:
### What happens?

We fail to convert very distant dates to Tantivy date values

### To Reproduce

```sql
create table extreme_dates (id serial primary key, dates date);
insert into extreme_dates (dates) values ('57439-03-01');
create index on extreme_dates using bm25 (id, dates) with (key_field = 'id');

macOS

Yes

issueDTO.title: MudDateRangePicker - proper values seen as invalid when Editable=True
issueDTO.description:
### Before reporting

- [x] I searched existing issues
- [x] I tried in private/incognito browser

### What went wrong?

When you have the `Editable` attribute on `MudDateRangePicker` set to `true` internal validation fails on valid date ranges. This only occurs when you open the picker and do not change the value. I'm guessing there are some internal text fields when `Editable` is `true` and validation is failing on those for whatever reason.

### Reproduction link

https://try.mudblazor.com/snippet/ckGfEiPHqXExJHsx

### Reproduction steps

The following steps assume you've navigated to the try.mudblazor.com link posted in this issue.
1. Click calendar picker adornment.
2. Click outside of calendar picker without selecting a new date range to close it
3. Click validate button
4. See validation error

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d2476973-e686-42d7-a9c6-f0cfd48c0d04

8.7.0

### Version (working)

Chrome

Server

issueDTO.title: Add custom input generator for `array_sum`
issueDTO.description:
### Description

The following `integer overflow` was seen in `array_sum` function with expression fuzzer. 
An `InputGenerator` for `array_sum` say `ArraySumInputGenerator`, should be added that is similar to `MapUnionSumInputGenerator`, in order to ensure the values in the integer array [do not overflow](https://github.com/facebookincubator/velox/blob/2b51a3cdd081ff6b9a729a86996edc664d7b2c40/velox/functions/prestosql/fuzzer/MapUnionSumInputGenerator.h#L32) when added. 
The custom input generators for functions should also be wired into the expression fuzzer.

Alternatively, `array_sum` can be added to the list of skip functions in [`ExpressionFuzzerTest.cpp`](https://github.com/facebookincubator/velox/blob/2b51a3cdd081ff6b9a729a86996edc664d7b2c40/velox/expression/fuzzer/ExpressionFuzzerTest.cpp#L127). 

See https://github.com/facebookincubator/velox/pull/15399/#issuecomment-3523935299 for fuzzer repro path  to reproduce the error locally.

cc: @peterenescu @mbasmanova @aditi-pandit @czentgr 

### Error Reproduction

velox_expression_runner_test  --fuzzer_repro_path="/Users/pramod/Downloads/tmp/coalesce_repro/velox_expressionVerifier_5gRpp9" --sql_path="/Users/pramod/Downloads/tmp/coalesce_repro/velox_expressionVerifier_5gRpp9/sql" --mode=verify

### Relevant logs

```bash
Executing expression 0 : switch(map_key_exists(null,ceiling(coalesce(0.4492889642715454,0.05161726474761963))),transform_values(if("c0",{[382->530] [530->295] 644797815 => {[382->458] [458->383] [383->108] 0.05657687829807401, null, false, -805899563}}),lambda ROW<__a0:INTEGER,__a1:ROW<f0:DOUBLE,f1:INTERVAL DAY TO SECOND,f2:BOOLEAN,f3:INTERVAL DAY TO SECOND>> -> 2011-04-17),array_has_duplicates($internal$canonicalize(array_intersect(find_first({[47->37] {null}},array_sum({[400->715] [715->234] [234->565] 6976801220365335985, [401->317] [317->100] [100->151] 5371919366574234310, [402->701] [701->397] [397->300] 780637959026489352, [403->688] [688->606] [606->257] 6855833019528270910, null, ...3 more}),lambda ROW<__a0:ARRAY<ARRAY<VARCHAR>>> -> is_null("__a0"))))),"c1")
Common eval succeeded.
Only simplified path threw exception:
...
Error Code: ARITHMETIC_ERROR
Reason: integer overflow: 6976801220365335985 + 5371919366574234310
Retriable: False
Context: array_sum({[400->715] [715->234] [234->565] 6976801220365335985, [401->317] [317->100] [100->151] 5371919366574234310, [402->701] [701->397] [397->300] 780637959026489352, [403->688] [688->606] [606->257] 6855833019528270910, null, ...3 more}:ARRAY<BIGINT>)
Function: checkedPlus
```

repository.name: velox

summary.attemptedFixes: add custom input generator for array_sum, wire custom input generators for functions into the expression fuzzer, add array_sum to the list of skip functions in ExpressionFuzzerTest.cpp
summary.otherNotes: integer overflow was seen in array_sum function with expression fuzzer, custom input generators for functions should be wired into the expression fuzzer, alternatively array_sum can be added to the list of skip functions in ExpressionFuzzerTest.cpp

issueDTO.title: InkDrinker_1: Camera bounds show areas outside the scene when using aspect ratios other than 16:9
issueDTO.description:
### Problem Description
When playing the **InkDrinker 1** level (*scene: `ink_combat_round_1`*) with an aspect ratio different from **16:9** (for example, *21:9* or *4:3*), the camera bounds allow parts of the scene to be visible that were not meant to be seen.  
This happens when the game window expands horizontally or vertically, exposing areas outside the region "dressed" by the level designer.


### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open the project in the **Godot** editor.  
2. In **Project Settings**, enable **Debug Aspect Ratio**.  
3. Start the level **InkDrinker 1** (*scene: `ink_combat_round_1`*).  
4. Resize the window (for example, make it wider or taller).  
5. Observe that the camera shows undesigned or empty areas outside the intended playable region.


### Expected Result
The camera should remain within the designed playable area and not display regions outside the intended environment.

---

### Suggested Fix
This issue could be resolved by **adding more decoration (e.g., water)** around the edges of the scene and **adjusting the camera limits** so that the view stays centered on the action.  

>[!NOTE]
>- Found while testing the main issue #1083 .
>- Scene path: `res://scenes/quests/lore_quests/quest_001/2_ink_combat/ink_combat_round_1.tscn`
comments: Adjust the camera limits so that the view remains centered. Currently, the visible tiles are **19 horizontally** and **11 vertically**, so the approximate bounds should be: - Right limit: `15 * 64` - Bottom limit: `8.5 * 64`

issueDTO.title: `rows_hide()` function to compliment `cols_hide()`
issueDTO.description:
## Proposal for `rows_hide()` function

After the gt object has been created and formatted, it is possible to hide particular columns. There are cases were hiding rows would also be useful. 

This is especially important for groups of data scientists where `gt` is the basis of table formatting. For example, complex report tables with titles, footnotes, and other styling choices might get made by some centralized process, but then individuals might want to grab the stylized table, select just certain rows and columns, and then update the title but *not* have to worry about copying over the footnotes or other formatting details.

    # Some function has produced a table
    my_table <- iris |>
      group_by(Species) |>
      summarize(across(where(is.numeric), mean)) |>
      gt(rowname_col = 'Species') |>
      # Now have a bunch of formating
      gt::tab_header('Some Title')
    
    # And now I need to take extract just a subset of the rows/colums
    # for a report, but we shouldn't copy/paste all of the formatting
    # code
    
    my_table |>
      cols_hide(contains('Sepal')) # this works to hide extraneous columns...
    
    # But why isn't there a rows_hide() equivalent? What if I need to 
    # hide the setosa row?
    my_table |>
      cols_hide(contains('Sepal')) |>
      rows_hide(Species == 'setosa')   # This function doesn't exist.

I would expect that `rows_hide()` would be able to specify a body row in all the usual ways that `cells_body(rows=)` can select rows.

Looking into the code for `cols_hide()`, it appears that there is a flag being set that marks if the column is to be displayed. Is it reasonable to create a corresponding rows flag that will control if a particular row is displayed?

A design question is "What to do if there are summary rows?" Because we are *hiding* (and not removing), I think that the summary rows shouldn't be changed. However, there should be a way to also hide the `summary_row()` output.
comments: This makes a lot of sense and I think it would be a great feature! Agree that summaries shouldn???t be affected but there should be some facility for hiding those rows as well.

My endorsements to the proposal.

Dear @dereksonderegger, may I ask if you found a workaround?

I know I can do the following (following your example):

`
my_table |>
  as.data.frame() |>
  filter(Species != 'setosa')
`

But that leaves us with a data frame, which I don't know how to plug into the well-formatted table... =(

repository.description: Easily generate information-rich, publication-quality tables from R
repository.name: gt

summary.main: The main goal of this issue is to create a `rows_hide()` function that allows users to hide specific rows in a table, similar to how `cols_hide()` allows users to hide specific columns.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The issue does not specify any specific requirements or validations, but it does mention that the `summary_row()` output should not be affected by the `rows_hide()` function and that there should be a way to hide summary rows as well.
summary.attemptedFixes: The author suggests creating a corresponding flag for rows that marks if a particular row is to be displayed, similar to how `cols_hide()` sets a flag for columns. Additionally, the issue mentions that a workaround is to convert the gt object to a data frame and then filter the rows, but this method does not preserve the table formatting.
summary.otherNotes: This issue proposes the creation of a `rows_hide()` function to complement the existing `cols_hide()` function in the gt package. The function would allow users to hide specific rows in a table, which is useful for data scientists who need to extract and update specific parts of a report without having to copy and paste formatting code.

issueDTO.title: cols_align_decimal() fails with accounting = TRUE when summary rows are added.
issueDTO.description:
Since you seem to have `summary_rows` on the mind right now . . . `cols_align_decimal()` fails for accounting formatting on the summary rows when `summary_rows` are included. Grouping *without* adding summary rows works as intended.

## Reproducible example
Reprexes include `gtsave()` to get the correct representation, since the normal reprex output is not indicative.

**1. Grouped without summary rows (working correctly):**
``` r
# Grouped, no summaries
library(gt)
dplyr::tibble(
  char = LETTERS[1:8],
  num = c(1.2, -33.52, 9023.2, -283.527, 0.401, -123.1, NA, 41),
  group = c(rep("Group 1", 4), rep("Group 2", 4))) |> 
  dplyr::group_by(group) |> 
  gt() |> 
  fmt_currency(num, 
               accounting = TRUE, 
               decimals = 2) |> 
  cols_align_decimal() |> 
  gtsave("out.png")
```

<sup>Created on 2022-12-09 with [reprex v2.0.2](https://reprex.tidyverse.org)</sup>
![out](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4965916/206765264-f0ccc4af-5725-4581-80e8-7432a3e57014.png)


**2. Grouped with summary rows, 2 decimals (bug)**
``` r
# Grouped, no summaries, decimals = 2
library(gt)
dplyr::tibble(
  char = LETTERS[1:8],
  num = c(1.2, -33.52, 9023.2, -283.527, 0.401, -123.1, NA, 41),
  group = c(rep("Group 1", 4), rep("Group 2", 4))) |> 
  dplyr::group_by(group) |> 
  gt() |> 
  fmt_currency(num, 
               accounting = TRUE, 
               decimals = 2) |> 
  summary_rows(groups = TRUE,
               columns = c("num"),
               fns = list(`Group Diff` = ~ sum(., na.rm = TRUE)),
               formatter = fmt_currency,
               decimals = 2,
               accounting = TRUE) |>
  cols_align_decimal() |> 
  gtsave("out2.png")
```

<sup>Created on 2022-12-09 with [reprex v2.0.2](https://reprex.tidyverse.org)</sup>

![out2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4965916/206765488-78e633bb-d57a-4b28-9b70-8f632cb152af.png)

Same outcome when `decimals = 0`, which as you know is my pet use case, and `grand_summary_rows()` seems to present the same issue.

comments:
I just worked on making `summary_rows()` better in https://github.com/rstudio/gt/pull/1159 so this is a good follow up to that work. I'm thinking that `cols_align_decimal()` has to become lazy (do the alignment work after all the parts are in place), and have an option to include summary cells (with the default being `TRUE`).

Thanks for reporting this! It was easy to miss but having consistent formatting across parts is very important indeed.

repository.description: Easily generate information-rich, publication-quality tables from R
repository.name: gt

summary.main: The main goal of the issue is to fix the failure of `cols_align_decimal()` when `summary_rows` are added, specifically when `accounting = TRUE` and `decimals = 2`.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The issue requires consistent formatting across parts, specifically when `accounting = TRUE` and `decimals = 2`.
summary.attemptedFixes: The issue is already reported and discussed in the comments, with a suggestion to make `cols_align_decimal()` lazy and have an option to include summary cells.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is about the failure of `cols_align_decimal()` when `summary_rows` are added, specifically when `accounting = TRUE` and `decimals = 2`. It's related to the previous work on `summary_rows()` and requires making `cols_align_decimal()` lazy and having an option to include summary cells.

issueDTO.title: Using `tab_style` to bold the highest value between two columns in a single row
issueDTO.description:
Hello,

I am trying to compare two columns and bold the highest value in the first row. The last section of my code is my attempt, however, it bolds both values.  How can I fix this?

My other question is about repeating that code 50+ times as I add more rows and columns. What's the best way to loop the `tab_style` code? Thank you very much for your help!

```
percentage <- tibble(
  Model = "10-item (Equal, Unordered)",
  N = "1000",
  Class_3_BestAIC = 0,
Class_4_BestAIC = 100,
Class_3_BestCAIC = 0,
Class_4_BestCAIC = 100,
Class_3_BestBIC = 0,
Class_4_BestBIC = 100,
Class_3_BestaBIC = 0,
Class_4_BestaBIC = 100
)

percentage %>%
  gt(rowname_col = "Model") %>%
  tab_header(
    md(
      "*Percentage of Times the Lowest Value Occurred in Each Class Model
for the AIC, CAIC, BIC, and Adjusted BIC*"
    )
  ) %>%
  cols_label(
    N = md("*N*"),
    Class_3_BestAIC = md("*3*"),
    Class_4_BestAIC = md("*4*"),
    Class_3_BestCAIC = md("*3*"),
    Class_4_BestCAIC = md("*4*"),
    Class_3_BestBIC = md("*3*"),
    Class_4_BestBIC = md("*4*"),
    Class_3_BestaBIC = md("*3*"),
    Class_4_BestaBIC = md("*4*")
  ) %>%
  tab_spanner(
    id = "AIC",
    label = md("*Classes*"),
    columns = c(Class_3_BestAIC, Class_4_BestAIC)
  ) %>%
  tab_spanner(
    id = "CAIC",
    label = md("*Classes*"),
    columns = c(Class_3_BestCAIC, Class_4_BestCAIC)
  ) %>%
  tab_spanner(
    id = "BIC",
    label = md("*Classes*"),
    columns = c(Class_3_BestBIC, Class_4_BestBIC)
  ) %>%
  tab_spanner(
    id = "aBIC",
    label = md("*Classes*"),
    columns = c(Class_3_BestaBIC, Class_4_BestaBIC)
  ) %>%
  tab_spanner(
    id = "AIC_Value",
    label = md("*AIC*"),
    spanners = "AIC",
    columns = c(Class_3_BestAIC, Class_4_BestAIC)
  ) %>%
  tab_spanner(
    id = "CAIC_Value",
    label = md("*CAIC*"),
    spanners = "CAIC",
    columns = c(Class_3_BestCAIC, Class_4_BestCAIC)
  ) %>%
  tab_spanner(
    id = "BIC_Value",
    label = md("*BIC*"),
    spanners = "BIC",
    columns = c(Class_3_BestBIC, Class_4_BestBIC)
  ) %>%
  tab_spanner(
    id = "aBIC_Value",
    label = md("*aBIC*"),
    spanners = "aBIC",
    columns = c(Class_3_BestaBIC, Class_4_BestaBIC)
  ) %>%
  tab_spanner(
    label = md("*Latent Class Analysis with Categorical Outcomes*"),
    spanners = c("AIC", "CAIC", "BIC", "aBIC")
  ) %>%
  tab_stubhead(label = md("*Model*")) %>%
  cols_width(1 ~ px(100),
             everything() ~ px(40)) %>%
  cols_align(align = "center") %>%
  cols_align(align = "left",
             columns = 1) %>%
  opt_table_font(font = "Times New Roman") %>%
  opt_align_table_header(align = "left") %>%
  tab_options(
    heading.title.font.size = px(16),
    row_group.as_column = TRUE,
    stub.border.width = 0,
    heading.border.bottom.color = "black",
    column_labels.border.top.color = "black",
    column_labels.border.bottom.color = "black",
    table_body.border.bottom.color = "black",
    table.border.bottom.color = "black",
    table.border.top.color = "black",
    table.background.color = "white"
  ) %>%
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_borders(
        sides = c("top", "bottom"),
        color = "white",
        weight = px(1)
      ),
      cell_text(align = "center"),
      cell_fill(color = "white", alpha = NULL)
    ),
    locations = cells_body(columns = everything(),
                           rows = everything())
  ) %>%
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_text(weight = "bold")
            ),
    locations = list(
    cells_body(
     columns = c(Class_3_BestAIC,Class_4_BestAIC),
     row = 1)
  )
) 
```

issueDTO.title: `cols_align_decimal()` does not work for scientific numbers
issueDTO.description:
When I apply `cols_align_decimal()` to a column that was formated using `fmt_scientific()`, the decimal point is not aligned (for rows where the power of 10 part is missing).

Reprex:

```
library(gt)
exibble["num"] |>
  gt() |>
  fmt_scientific() |>
  cols_align_decimal()
```

![image](https://github.com/rstudio/gt/assets/36004669/04c09f03-ed7c-4f49-a1aa-02bf28519643)

issueDTO.title: `fmt_currency` silently fails on `bit64::integer64` values
issueDTO.description:
## Prework

* [x] Read and agree to the [code of conduct](https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html) and [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/rstudio/gt/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md).
* [x] If there is [already a relevant issue](https://github.com/rstudio/gt/issues), whether open or closed, comment on the existing thread instead of posting a new issue.

## Description

When a `bit64::integer64` column is provided to `fmt_currency()`, no formatting occurs, and no warnings are displayed. This is relevant as queries to many databases via the `odbc` package return `integer64` columns when a database column type calls for a large integer (ie Databricks' `bigint` type).

## Reproducible example

```r
df <- tibble::tibble(
  name = c("foo", "bar"),
  money = bit64::as.integer64(c(1000, 2000))
)

# fails
df |>
  gt::gt() |>
  gt::fmt_currency(columns = money, currency = "USD")

# works
df$money <- as.numeric(df$money)
df |>
  gt::gt() |>
  gt::fmt_currency(columns = money, currency = "USD")
```

## Expected result

Either formatting to work successfully, or a warning displayed that the indicated column cannot be formatted due to a type mismatch.

## Session info

```
comments:
Hi! Thanks for the report. The reason is that `fmt_currency()` (and most other `fmt_*()` functions only work with numeric or integer types. From [`fmt_currency()` docs](https://gt.rstudio.com/reference/fmt_currency.html#compatibility-of-formatting-function-with-data-values)

> fmt_currency() is compatible with body cells that are of the "numeric" or "integer" types. Any other types of body cells are ignored during formatting. This is to say that cells of incompatible data types may be targeted, but there will be no attempt to format them.

You'd likely need to use `fmt()` to format these.

You can set an [option](https://gt.rstudio.com/reference/gt-options.html?q=options#null) to be on the safe side, but that means you will have to manually specify `columns` in all your `fmt_*()` calls.

```r
options(gt.strict_column_fmt = TRUE)
```


```r
df <- tibble::tibble(
    name = c("foo", "bar"),
    money = bit64::as.integer64(c(1000, 2000))
)

df |>
    gt::gt() |>
    gt::fmt(columns = money, compat = "integer64", fns =   function(x) paste0("$", x, "USD"))
```

repository.description: Easily generate information-rich, publication-quality tables from R
repository.name: gt

summary.main: The main goal of the issue is to make `fmt_currency` work with `bit64::integer64` values, and provide a solution to format these values successfully.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The issue requires a fix that makes `fmt_currency` work with `bit64::integer64` values.
summary.attemptedFixes: The solution is to use `fmt` to format these values, and set an option to be on the safe side.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is about `fmt_currency` silently failing on `bit64::integer64` values. The reason is that `fmt_currency` only works with numeric or integer types. The solution is to use `fmt` to format these values. An option can be set to be on the safe side, but it means manually specifying `columns` in all `fmt_*()` calls.

issueDTO.title: `AbsolutePath.Exists` should return `true` if the entity is a directory
issueDTO.description:
I've had this simple program:
```fsharp
open TruePath
open TruePath.SystemIo

let repoRoot = AbsolutePath __SOURCE_DIRECTORY__ / ".."

let folders = [|
        repoRoot / "TdLib.Api" / "Objects"
        repoRoot / "TdLib.Api" / "Functions"
    |]
    for folder in folders do
        if folder.Exists() then
            printfn $"Removing folder \"{folder.Value}\"???"
            folder.DeleteDirectoryRecursively()
        else printfn $"Nothing to clean in \"{folder.Value}\": folder doesn't exist."
```

And it broke because `folder.Exists()` doesn't check for directory existence, but only for files.

Let's have separate explicit methods `ExistsFile()` and `ExistsDirectory()` (in fact we already have the latter), and make `Exists()` to check the entity for existence without checking for its exact kind.
comments: I'm working on this.

I think it's already handled by #172.

(Sorry I am a bit overwhelmed by work at the moment, so didn't review that yet, but I will soon!)
@ForNeVeR Ah, I didn't see your comment in time..I opened the PR already. Sorry about that.

repository.name: TruePath

summary.main: The main goal is to make the `AbsolutePath.Exists` method return `true` if the entity is a directory, and fix the issue with the program breaking due to incorrect method usage.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The issue requires explicit methods for file and directory existence, and the `Exists()` method should check for existence without checking for exact kind.
summary.attemptedFixes: The author is already working on this issue, and a PR has been opened.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is related to #172, and the author is overwhelmed with work, so the review is pending.

issueDTO.title: go-git (go-git-fixtures) increasing significantly module cache size
issueDTO.description:
Adding `github.com/go-git/go-git/v5` to a project and running `go mod tidy` causes a significant increase in module cache size.

The culprit seems to be `github.com/go-git/go-git-fixtures`:

```
# du -d1 -h $(go env GOMODCACHE)/cache/download/github.com/go-git | sort -h
64K	/go/pkg/mod/cache/download/github.com/go-git/gcfg
92K	/go/pkg/mod/cache/download/github.com/go-git/go-billy
768K	/go/pkg/mod/cache/download/github.com/go-git/go-git
94M	/go/pkg/mod/cache/download/github.com/go-git/go-git-fixtures
95M	/go/pkg/mod/cache/download/github.com/go-git
```

example with a project using `nfpm` as a tool dependency:

```$ go mod why -m github.com/go-git/go-git-fixtures/v4
# github.com/go-git/go-git-fixtures/v4
github.com/goreleaser/nfpm/v2/cmd/nfpm
github.com/goreleaser/nfpm/v2/internal/cmd
github.com/goreleaser/nfpm/v2
github.com/goreleaser/chglog
github.com/go-git/go-git/v5
github.com/go-git/go-git/v5.test
github.com/go-git/go-git-fixtures/v4
```

Adding ~95MB for a ~800K dependency (~94M overhead) sounds concerning
comments: @kruskall thanks for opening this issue. `go-git-fixtures` contains important fixtures that are used during `go-git` tests, those are mostly `git` repositories, dotfiles or worktrees, which can be quite big when compared to just code. I haven't look into ways of optimizing this yet, but I'm assuming that restructuring some of the tests should suffice.

go-git currently depends on 2 version of go-git-fixtures:
	github.com/go-git/go-git-fixtures/v4 v4.3.2-0.20231010084843-55a94097c399
	github.com/go-git/go-git-fixtures/v5 v5.0.0-20241203230421-0753e18f8f03
The v4 listed above contains a 62MB file (data.go) which has since been removed. So if we remove (or at least update to latest) v4, it will significantly reduce the size.
@AriehSchneier the idea is to deprecate `v4` on `v6-transport`, we just need to be aware of the inflight PRs which are touching tests, so that we avoid conflicts or duplication of effort.

After the merge of #1569, only the v5 is being downloaded:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/516b100c-d101-49d9-9485-b7e7add79484)

I'm under the impression that we should be able to remove that altogether by ensuring that all references to `go-git-fixtures` are within `_test.go` files. The two offenders I know off are:

- https://github.com/go-git/go-git/blob/0ba20950388d620d0c5de4d5e09e590c4e4f7099/internal/transport/test/receive_pack.go#L23
- https://github.com/go-git/go-git/blob/0ba20950388d620d0c5de4d5e09e590c4e4f7099/internal/transport/test/common.go#L9

However, there may be more.

repository.description: A highly extensible Git implementation in pure Go.
repository.name: go-git

summary.main: The main goal of the issue is to investigate and resolve the significant increase in module cache size caused by `github.com/go-git/go-git-fixtures` when adding `github.com/go-git/go-git/v5` to a project and running `go mod tidy`.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The issue is about the significant increase in module cache size, which is a concern.
summary.attemptedFixes: Some possible solutions mentioned include restructuring some of the tests, removing or updating `v4` of `go-git-fixtures`, and ensuring that all references to `go-git-fixtures` are within `_test.go` files.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is about the significant increase in module cache size when adding `github.com/go-git/go-git/v5` to a project and running `go mod tidy`. The culprit seems to be `github.com/go-git/go-git-fixtures`. The issue is related to the tests in `go-git` and the large size of the fixtures.

comments:
# :wave: Important: PLEASE READ :wave:

This issue has been labeled as a **good first issue** and is available for anyone to work on.

If this is your first time contributing to an open source project, some aspects of the development process may seem unusual, arcane, or some combination of both.

1.  **You cannot "claim" issues.** People new to open source often want to "claim" or be assigned an issue before beginning work. The typical rationale is that people want to avoid wasted work in the event that someone else ends up working the issue. However, this practice is not effective in open source, as it often leads to "issue squatting", in which an individual asks to be assigned, is granted their request, and then never ends up working on the issue. Accordingly, you are encouraged to communicate your intent to address this issue, ideally by providing a rough outline as to how you plan to address the issue or asking clarifying questions, but, at the end of the day, we will take running code and rough consensus in order to move forward quickly.
2.  **We have a very high bar for contributions.** We have very high standards for contributions and expect all contributions???whether new features, tests, or documentation???to be rigorous, thorough, and complete. Once a pull request is merged into stdlib, that contribution immediately becomes the collective responsibility of all maintainers of stdlib. When we merge code into stdlib, we are saying that we, the maintainers, commit to reviewing subsequent changes and making bugfixes to the code. Hence, in order to ensure future maintainability, this naturally leads to a higher standard of contribution.

Before working on this issue and opening a pull request, please read the project's [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/stdlib-js/stdlib/blob/develop/CONTRIBUTING.md). These guidelines and the associated [development guide](https://github.com/stdlib-js/stdlib/blob/develop/docs/contributing/development.md) provide important information, including links to stdlib's [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/stdlib-js/stdlib/blob/develop/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md), license policy, and steps for setting up your local development environment.

To reiterate, we **strongly** encourage you to refer to our contributing guides **before** beginning work on this issue. Failure to follow our guidelines significantly decreases the likelihood that you'll successfully contribute to stdlib and may result in automatic closure of a pull request without review.

Setting up your local development environment is a critical first step, as doing so ensures that automated development processes for linting, license verification, and unit testing can run prior to authoring commits and pushing changes. If you would prefer to avoid manual setup, we provide pre-configured [development containers](https://github.com/stdlib-js/stdlib/tree/develop/.devcontainer) for use locally or in GitHub Codespaces.

We place a high value on consistency throughout the stdlib codebase. We encourage you to closely examine other packages in stdlib and attempt to emulate the practices and conventions found therein.

-   If you are attempting to contribute a new package, sometimes the best approach is to simply copy the contents of an existing package and then modify the minimum amount necessary to implement the feature (e.g., changing descriptions, parameter names, and implementation).
-   If you are contributing tests, find a package implementing a similar feature and emulate the tests of that package.
-   If you are updating documentation, examine several similar packages and emulate the content, style, and prose of those packages.

In short, the more effort you put in to ensure that your contribution looks and feels like stdlib???including variables names, bracket spacing, line breaks, etc???the more likely that your contribution will be reviewed and ultimately accepted. We encourage you to closely study the codebase **before** beginning work on this issue.

:sparkles: Thank you again for your interest in stdlib, and we look forward to reviewing your future contributions. :sparkles:

issueDTO.title: ESP32 completely hangs if a WebSocket Server shutdown while a NF based WebSocket client was attached
comments:
after digging deeper it looks like this function never excepts or returns if the server is gone:
```
        [MethodImpl(MethodImplOptions.InternalCall)]
        public static extern int send(object socket, byte[] buf, int offset, int count, int flags, int timeout_ms);
```
in
```
    internal class NativeSocket
```

repository.description: :house: The landing page for .NET nanoFramework repositories.
repository.name: Home

summary.main: When a NF WebSocket Client is connected to a WebSocket Server and the server is restarted, stopped or otherwise no longer available, the NF based ESP chip completely halts. This is a catastrophic bug for any production deployment.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The issue is specific to ESP32 with firmware version 1.14.x and requires the presence of a WebSocket client and server. The client should be able to connect to the server and send data every 1-3 seconds. The server should be stopped or restarted to reproduce the issue.
summary.attemptedFixes: The author tried to handle exceptions in the WebSocket client but it never gets called in firmware 1.14.x. The function 'send' in 'NativeSocket' class is not throwing exceptions or returning if the server is gone.
summary.otherNotes: This issue is about ESP32 completely hanging if a WebSocket Server shutdown while a NF based WebSocket client was attached. It was observed in firmware version 1.14.x and worked fine in 1.12.x. The main goal is to have an exception thrown if the server cannot be reached anymore.

issueDTO.title: [docs] address missing topics in docs
issueDTO.description:
Reviewing analytics from the search feature, about 7% of all searches queries have no match to the docs content. This data is based off the latest Helm 2 docs.

Filing this issue as a reference - as we work on documentation tidy-ups it would be great to include info on any of these topics to guide users who have these kinds of queries.

---

Data of top 10 'no result' queries:

```
1. volume               82 searches
2. b4enc                40 
3. atomic               27
4. imagePullSecrets     24
5. toJson               23
6. cronJob              22
7. concat               21
8. nameOverride         21
9. volumeMounts         19
10. tojson              16
``` 

A full .csv of the top 'no result' results can [be seen here](https://github.com/helm/helm-www/files/3535805/BH4D9OD16A_helm_20190525_to_20190821_no_result_searches.pdf). It is based off search queries over the last 90 days.
comments: @flynnduism it would be really interesting to see an update of this data, if you can provide it. Thanks!

Here's a [CSV](https://dl3.pushbulletusercontent.com/oGX3L5XEwEy41Wyw5gECN4pfeEKM3hyo/BH4D9OD16A_helm_20200508-20200708_popular_searches.csv) of search data from the last 90 days. --- Top 25 searches at a glance:

Adding to this, here is recent (3 month) user search data which returned **no results** on the site. ([full CSV](https://dl3.pushbulletusercontent.com/0OnOl6HuZctL6VddoEmQqfSJxBH2Cdef/BH4D9OD16A_helm_20200514-20200714_no_result_searches.csv)). I'm tagging this as a `good first issue`, it would be great if any contributors could add context around these subjects. Adding notes, redirects or background for things that don't exist would help bring clarity. See #726 for an example of this.

Thanks for the reporting here, @flynnduism.

I checked a few of the search topics in here. A couple of these search topics all relate to function calls available in Helm's template calls. tojson, b64enc, concat, haskey, trimsuffix and randalphanum all resolve to their function definitions, so that knocks a few off the list.

if you search for "image pull secrets" instead of "imagepullsecrets", https://helm.sh/docs/howto/charts_tips_and_tricks/#creating-image-pull-secrets comes up. Is there a way to create aliases for search terms with algolia?

For "atomic", they're probably looking for documentation on the `--atomic` flag. A code search query on github only shows this as documentation for `helm help`. This looks like a good area to document: https://github.com/helm/helm-www/search?q=--atomic&unscoped_q=--atomic

For "proxy", I'm assuming they're referring to HTTP_PROXY or other related proxy setup environment variables, which may also be useful to document.

Not sure what we can do about "nameoverride".

As for the other search terms, it looks like users are trying to look for information on specific charts. They should probably be using [CNCF Artifact Hub](https://artifacthub.io/) instead.
This issue has been marked as stale because it has been open for 90 days with no activity. This thread will be automatically closed in 30 days if no further activity occurs.

summary.attemptedFixes: A few search topics were checked and resolved, including function calls and image pull secrets. It was suggested to create aliases for search terms with Algolia.
summary.otherNotes: Data of top 10 'no result' queries are provided in a .csv file. The issue is tagged as a 'good first issue' and contributors are encouraged to add context around the missing topics. Some search topics are already resolved, such as function calls and image pull secrets. The issue is marked as stale and will be automatically closed in 30 days if no further activity occurs.

issueDTO.title: [Feature] Expose login/registration error messages to the end user
issueDTO.description:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.

When creating an account, any errors are not exposed to the end user. Only "Unknown error" is seen, which isn't helpful. An error message is exposed in the browser console, however this isn't accessible when trying to play on a mobile browser. 

### Describe the Feature

Request is to

1. For standard/"expected" error messages, handle them with a user-friendly string
2. For unexpected error messages, display unknown error with an "advanced" button showing the error message so people can Google/report it here 

### Additional context

Relevant code looks to be https://github.com/pagefaultgames/pokerogue/blob/beta/src%2Fplugins%2Fapi%2Fpokerogue-account-api.ts#L55

I have no familiarity with this project (just hit this error 10 minutes ago when trying to play for the first time) but I'm happy to have a crack at implementing this.
comments:
A few ideas:
- Ideally we would have a known list of "common error messages" that [Rogueserver](https://github.com/pagefaultgames/rogueserver) is known to dole out with more personalized/human-friendly error messages
  - Fallback could be a generic "Unknown error occurred".
- We might have to truncate it and/or cut newlines depending on how it interacts with the UI system

issueDTO.title: Convert `ResourceSize` type alias into newtype
issueDTO.description:
Newtypes allow to constrain what operations make sense on a value in order to prevent mistakes.

Please consider whether providing a newtype for the `ResourceSize` type alias would make sense and what operations could be provided for it -- please see https://github.com/Rust-for-Linux/linux/issues/1198 for a similar thread about `Offset`.

At the time of writing, the patches would need to be based on top of that patch series.

Please take the chance as well to write a couple examples/tests for the newtype.

Related: https://github.com/Rust-for-Linux/linux/issues/1204.
Lore: https://lore.kernel.org/rust-for-linux/CANiq72maV_j1uV=2nPGbTgRabnk8cpc7TNN_FQ+ou52OpZ=k6Q@mail.gmail.com/.

---

This requires submitting a proper patch to the LKML and the Rust for Linux mailing list. Please recall to test your changes (including generating the documentation if changed, running the Rust doctests if changed, etc.), to use a proper title for the commit, to sign your commit under the Developer's Certificate of Origin and to add a `Suggested-by:` tag, and a `Link:` tag to this issue. Please see https://docs.kernel.org/process/submitting-patches.html and https://rust-for-linux.com/contributing for details.

issueDTO.title: Enabling "Randomize port on launch" may impact download speeds in certain cases
issueDTO.description:
### What is the issue?

Whilst it sounds attractive from an anti-tracking aspect to randomize the port you use on each launch; this could lead to slower download speeds.

This being due to DHT, peers, and trackers keeping your old port in their lists. They will continue trying to send data to your old port until that peer has announced to the tracker to get your new IP:Port. This could be 30 minutes or longer. Whilst it wouldn't be a big issue with a large swarm, it would impact torrents with a smaller swarm, and might have users complaining about slow speeds.

I think this caveat should be stated in the docs, but the average user doesn't read docs, (All those guilty, say I 😉) and may enable it regardless. My suggestion is to have a small note in the same style as the "Automatically map port" setting, pointing out that caveat below the option in the Network GUI.

"May impact download speeds in certain cases"

### Which application of Transmission?

macOS app

### Which version of Transmission?

4.0.0-dev (671f835228)
comments:
If anyone wants to work on this --

* I'd take a docs/ PR for this for 4.0.x

* I'd take a one-liner in prefs/settings for 4.1.x (semver minor and would need to go to translators)
Let's go for the settings note: I wasn't aware of that fact, so it should have direct visibility.
@Coeur 4.1.0 freeze is coming soon, looks like you milestoned this for that release. Do you have bandwidth to make a PR?
No, I'm still minimising my participation until that code_style.sh is addressed one way or another (like #7573).

summary.validationOrRequirement: The note should be in the same style as the 'Automatically map port' setting and should be below the option in the Network GUI.
summary.attemptedFixes: The suggestion is to have a small note in the Network GUI pointing out the caveat below the option 'Randomize port on launch'.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is related to the Transmission macOS app version 4.0.0-dev and may impact download speeds in certain cases.

issueDTO.title: Improve test coverage for src/plugin/routes/PluginRoutes.tsx
issueDTO.description:
# Goal  
The goal of this issue is to improve the code coverage for this file

# Tasks  
1. Review the file to identify sections of code that are being ignored by Codecov or are not covered by tests.  
2. Create or update test cases to ensure 100% coverage for the file.  
3. Remove any `/* istanbul ignore */` or equivalent statements that bypass code coverage reporting, unless absolutely necessary.  

# Resources  
1. Refer to the foundational documentation on writing test cases in the repository.  
1. Check the [Codecov report](https://app.codecov.io/gh/PalisadoesFoundation/talawa-admin/tree/develop?displayType=list) for details on the uncovered lines.  

# Acceptance Criteria  
1. All sections of the file are covered by tests.  
1. Code coverage for the file reaches 100%.  
1. PR created with necessary updates, passing all checks and reviews.
1. All tests must be valid

# If the file is not used in the code base:

1. Remove the file and its test cases
1. Submit a PR with the removed file(s) as the PR for this issue

# Other
If you are new to testing, refer to [past test code coverage improvement PRs](https://github.com/PalisadoesFoundation/talawa-admin/issues?q=is%3Aissue%20state%3Amerged%20in%3Atitle%20test%20)

>     1. Analysis Phase
>        
>        * Review the current test file and identify gaps in coverage using Codecov report
>        * Analyze AddPeopleToTag.tsx to understand all code paths, edge cases, and conditional logic
>        * Check for any /* istanbul ignore */ statements and evaluate if they can be removed
> 
>     2. Test Coverage Strategy
>        
>        * Component rendering tests (default state, with props, different user roles)
>        * User interaction tests (button clicks, form submissions, modal interactions)
>        * State management tests (loading states, error states, success states)
>        * API call mocking and response handling (success/failure scenarios)
>        * Edge cases (empty data, network errors, permission checks)
>        * Accessibility and error boundary tests if applicable
> 
>     3. Implementation
>        
>        * Use React Testing Library best practices (@testing-library/react)
>        * Mock GraphQL queries/mutations with proper Apollo Client mocking
>        * Test user interactions with fireEvent/userEvent
>        * Ensure all conditional branches and error handlers are covered
>        * Remove unnecessary istanbul ignore statements after achieving coverage
>

>        
>        * Run tests locally and verify 100% coverage for the file

>        * Check that new tests follow repository testing conventions

issueDTO.title: Replace deprecated package `inflight`
issueDTO.description:
**Describe the bug**

1. This package has been deprecated
2. This is not suitable for sustainable code

**To Reproduce**

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

1. Run the command `npm install`
2. Error occurs

**Expected behavior**

1. Run the command `npm install`
2. The error does not occur because the package has been suitably upgraded according to the recommendations of the organization that manages the package.
3. The application must continue to run
4. Feature functionality must be maintained


**Additional details**

- Error message on installation

```
npm warn deprecated inflight@1.0.6: This module is not supported, and leaks memory. Do not use it. Check out lru-cache if you want a good and tested way to coalesce async requests by a key value, which is much more comprehensive and powerful.

```

**Potential internship candidates**

Please read this if you are planning to apply for a Palisadoes Foundation internship 
- https://github.com/PalisadoesFoundation/talawa/issues/359

issueDTO.title: Support new issue types
issueDTO.description:
Github introduced new enhancements to issues: issue types, sub-issues, and other minor issues. It seems like they're forcing these issue types by default now, the field is visible even if you don't want to use it, my guess is it will be a default soon.
So it makes sense to implement this kind of API.

https://github.blog/changelog/2025-01-13-evolving-github-issues-public-preview/
While it's stated that it's in "preview", they've already started rolling it out actively without opting in.
comments:
https://github.blog/changelog/2025-03-18-github-issues-projects-rest-api-support-for-issue-types/
APIs should be available

Hi! If no one is working on this, may I take it and open a PR?
Proposed approach: add issueType support in the model, map the REST fields, add tests, and update docs.
Please let me know if you have any preferences before I start.
PR welcome.

issueDTO.title: Enterprise installations not recognized (throws an Exception)
issueDTO.description:
**Description of the bug**
When listing installations for a given App ID, the deserialization of the JSON response fails with the exception:
```
hudson.remoting.ProxyException: com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.exc.InvalidFormatException: Cannot deserialize value of type `org.kohsuke.github.GHTargetType` from String "Enterprise": not one of the values accepted for Enum class: [ORGANIZATION, USER]
 at [Source: REDACTED (`StreamReadFeature.INCLUDE_SOURCE_IN_LOCATION` disabled); line: 1, column: 756] (through reference chain: java.lang.Object[][0]->org.kohsuke.github.GHAppInstallation["target_type"])
	at PluginClassLoader for jackson2-api//com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.exc.InvalidFormatException.from(InvalidFormatException.java:67)
	at PluginClassLoader for jackson2-api//com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.DeserializationContext.weirdStringException(DeserializationContext.java:1959)
	at PluginClassLoader for jackson2-api//com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.DeserializationContext.handleWeirdStringValue(DeserializationContext.java:1245)
	at PluginClassLoader for jackson2-api//com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.deser.std.EnumDeserializer._deserializeAltString(EnumDeserializer.java:447)
	at PluginClassLoader for jackson2-api//com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.deser.std.EnumDeserializer._fromString(EnumDeserializer.java:304)
	at PluginClassLoader for jackson2-api//com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.deser.std.EnumDeserializer.deserialize(EnumDeserializer.java:273)
	at PluginClassLoader for jackson2-api//com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.deser.impl.FieldProperty.deserializeAndSet(FieldProperty.java:138)
	at PluginClassLoader for jackson2-api//com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.deser.BeanDeserializer.deserializeFromObject(BeanDeserializer.java:399)
	at PluginClassLoader for jackson2-api//com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.deser.BeanDeserializer.deserialize(BeanDeserializer.java:185)
	at PluginClassLoader for jackson2-api//com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.deser.std.ObjectArrayDeserializer.deserialize(ObjectArrayDeserializer.java:218)
	at PluginClassLoader for jackson2-api//com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.deser.DefaultDeserializationContext.readRootValue(DefaultDeserializationContext.java:342)
	at PluginClassLoader for jackson2-api//com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.ObjectReader._bindAndClose(ObjectReader.java:2131)
	at PluginClassLoader for jackson2-api//com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.ObjectReader.readValue(ObjectReader.java:1566)
	at PluginClassLoader for github-api//org.kohsuke.github.GitHubResponse.parseBody(GitHubResponse.java:104)
	at PluginClassLoader for github-api//org.kohsuke.github.GitHubPageIterator.lambda$fetch$0(GitHubPageIterator.java:147)
	at PluginClassLoader for github-api//org.kohsuke.github.GitHubClient.createResponse(GitHubClient.java:679)
	at PluginClassLoader for github-api//org.kohsuke.github.GitHubClient.sendRequest(GitHubClient.java:466)
Caused: hudson.remoting.ProxyException: org.kohsuke.github.HttpException: Server returned HTTP response code: 200, message: 'null' for URL: [https://api.github.com/app/installati](https://api.github.com/app/installations)
   ...
```

**To Reproduce**
To reproduce:

 1. Install a GitHub App at the enterprise level (this is a rather new feature)
 1. do an api call to
[https://api.github.com/app/installations](https://docs.github.com/en/rest/apps/apps?apiVersion=2022-11-28#list-installations-for-the-authenticated-app)
   
The `target_type` field will be `"Enterprise"` in one of the installations returned, and the deserialization will fail.

**Expected behavior**
A clear and concise description of what you expected to happen.
Just return the deserialized content with this new `target_type`

**Desktop (please complete the following information):**
 Does not apply

**Additional context**
Fixing this will require adding the `ENTERPRISE` type to the `GHTargetType` Enum here:
https://github.com/hub4j/github-api/blob/main/src/main/java/org/kohsuke/github/GHTargetType.java#L17
comments: Please submit PR.

issueDTO.title: [Feature request] Support matching-refs API
issueDTO.description:
See https://docs.github.com/en/rest/git/refs?apiVersion=2022-11-28#list-matching-references. The endpoint is `/repos/{owner}/{repo}/git/matching-refs/{ref}`.

The goal of this endpoint is to list refs that match the given prefix. It's useful to avoid fetching all available refs.

issueDTO.title: [CIR] Implement missing X86 builtins
issueDTO.description:
### Overview
Implement CIR handling for X86-specific builtin functions that are not yet handled in the incubator. For these builtins, the initial implementation should be done in the upstream LLVM repository and then back-ported to the incubator. The implementation should be based on the handling of the same builtins in `clang\CodeGen\TargetBuiltins\X86.c`.

Many people can work on this in parallel, if we can successfully coordinate the work to avoid overlap as much as possible. To that end, I am adding a partial list here of the builtins that need to be implemented. If you would like to contribute to this task, please comment saying which builtin(s) you are working on.

I will remove builtins from this list as they are upstreamed.

Please check the table below before beginning work to make sure no one else is working on the builtins you are targeting. If you have any questions, please comment here tagging @andykaylor.

### Needed builtins

| Builtin group | Assignee |
| --- | --- |
| masked rounding | |
| vfmadd, vfmaddsub | |
| masked expand | |
| masked compress | |
| extractf128 | |
| pmovqd512_mask | |
| permdi | |
| alignd | |
| shuff32x4, shufi32x4 | |
| kshiftl, kshiftr | |
| rotate | |
| prord | |
| select, selectsh | |
| cmpb, ucmpb | |
| vpcomb, vpcomub | |
| ktest, kortest | |
| kadd, kor, kand, kxnor, knot, kmov | |
| kunpck | |
| sqrtps | |
| pmul, pmulu | |
| pternlog | |
| vpshl, vpshr, shiftleft, shiftright | |
| reduce fmul, fadd, fmax, fmin | |
| rdrand_step | |
| fpclass | |
| intersect | |
| multishift | |
| convert half | |
| cpuid | |
| emul, mulh | |
| readwritebarrier | |
| address of return address | |
| stosb | |
| t2rpntlvw | |
| ud2, int2c | |
| readfs, readgs | |
| encodekey | |
| aesenc, aesencwide | |

### Existing incubator tests
clang/test/CIR/CodeGen/X86/*
comments:
Hi!

This issue may be a good introductory issue for people new to working on LLVM. If you would like to work on this issue, your first steps are:

1. Check that no other contributor is working on this issue. If someone is assigned to the issue or claimed to be working on it, ping the person. After one week without a response, the assignee may be changed.
1. Leave a comment indicating that you are working on the issue, or just create a [pull request](https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/pulls) after following the steps below. [Mention](https://docs.github.com/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issues/linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue) this issue in the description of the pull request.
1. Fix the issue locally.
1. [Run the test suite](https://llvm.org/docs/TestingGuide.html#unit-and-regression-tests) locally. Remember that the subdirectories under `test/` create fine-grained testing targets, so you can e.g. use `make check-clang-ast` to only run Clang's AST tests.
1. Create a Git commit.
1. Run [`git clang-format HEAD~1`](https://clang.llvm.org/docs/ClangFormat.html#git-integration) to format your changes.
1. Open a [pull request](https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/pulls) to the [upstream repository](https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project) on GitHub. Detailed instructions can be found [in GitHub's documentation](https://docs.github.com/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pull-requests/proposing-changes-to-your-work-with-pull-requests/creating-a-pull-request). [Mention](https://docs.github.com/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issues/linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue) this issue in the description of the pull request.

If you have any further questions about this issue, don't hesitate to ask via a comment in the thread below.


@llvm/issue-subscribers-good-first-issue

Author: Andy Kaylor (andykaylor)

<details>
### Overview
Implement CIR handling for X86-specific builtin functions that are not yet handled in the incubator. For these builtins, the initial implementation should be done in the upstream LLVM repository and then back-ported to the incubator. The implementation should be based on the handling of the same builtins in `clang\CodeGen\TargetBuiltins\X86.c`.

Many people can work on this in parallel, if we can successfully coordinate the work to avoid overlap as much as possible. To that end, I am adding a partial list here of the builtins that need to be implemented. If you would like to contribute to this task, please comment saying which builtin(s) you are working on.

I will remove builtins from this list as they are upstreamed.

Please check the table below before beginning work to make sure no one else is working on the builtins you are targeting. If you have any questions, please comment here tagging @<!-- -->andykaylor.

### Needed builtins

| Builtin group | Assignee |
| --- | --- |
| masked rounding | |

| masked compress | |

| pternlog | |

### Existing incubator tests
clang/test/CIR/CodeGen/X86/*
</details>
I have marked this as a "good first issue" but interested contributors should be aware of some special handling needed for working on ClangIR issues.

First, in order to even reproduce the problem you will need to build clang with ClangIR enabled. By default, clang does not build ClangIR support. You can find instructions for building with ClangIR enabled [here](https://llvm.github.io/clangir/GettingStarted/build-install.html).

Second, after building but before starting any other work, you should verify that you see an error when compiling the suggested minimal test case with ClangIR enabled. You should see an error (in this case, ``) when you compile the test case using the following options: `-fclangir -emit-cir`. The error may be followed by other errors or a stack dump. If you do not see an error, either someone else has already implemented this feature, or you are using the wrong repository (perhaps you built the ClangIR incubator repository?).

Third, the code to implement this feature should be based on the classic codegen handling of the builtins. The task here is to find the correct code, copy it to the CIR/CodeGen/CIRGenBuiltinX86.cpp file, and update it to generate CIR instread of LLVM IR. As part of the migration process, you may need to update the code to conform to the coding standards used in CIR, which are slightly different from the usual clang standards (mostly, variable identifiers start with lowercase in CIR code). You will also need to create or migrate a LIT test that exercises the new code.

Don't hesitate to ask for help if you need it. The entire point of "good first issue" is to help new people get involved with our project.
@Thibault-Monnier @woruyu @HendrikHuebner @siddu0660 FYI
@Priyanshu3820 It looks like @Thibault-Monnier has covered most of the builtins for https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/issues/167752, but there is more work to be done here.

If we end up burning through all of these quickly, there are still many builtins to be handled for other targets.

issueDTO.title: [CIR] Upstream handling of X86 builtins
issueDTO.description:
### Overview
This is an umbrella task for all X86 builtin upstreaming. There are enough X86-specific builtins that creating separate issues for each logical group is not practical. Many people can work on this in parallel, if we can successfully coordinate the work to avoid overlap as much as possible. To that end, I am adding a partial list here of the builtins that need to be upstreamed. If you would like to contribute to this task, please comment saying which builtin(s) you are working on.

I will remove builtins from this list as they are upstreamed.

Please check the table below before beginning work to make sure no one else is working on the builtins you are targeting. If you have any questions, please comment here tagging @andykaylor.

### Needed builtins

| Builtin group | Assignee |
| --- | --- |
| rdtsc, rdtscp |  |
| lzcnt, tzcnt |  |
| undef |  |
| vec_ext |  |
| vec_set |  |
| xsave, xrstor |  |
| masked store | |
| masked load | |
| convert to mask | |
| compress store | |
| gather | |
| scatter | |
| vinsert, shuffle, blend , perm | |

Many more builtins are needed but not yet implemented in the incubator. I will create a separate issue for that. work.

### Existing incubator tests
clang/test/CIR/CodeGen/X86/*

issueDTO.title: Make onboarding and auth quicker
issueDTO.description:
### Priority

Medium (nice to have)

### Feature Description

### Problems
- Getting through the onboarding quickly isn't possible, due to the levels of built-in friction
- Re-authenticating is confusing and frustrating
  - When an existing user is forced to reauthenticate with google due to their google session being expired, they have to click through all the initial onboarding screens. Then if they use Brave or a similar browser that prompts them to allow legacy oauth, the page will refresh and they'll have to do that click through process again. This is a very frustration workflow for someone who just wants to see their calendar, and will result in drop-offs from existing users. 

### Solutions
- [ ] Allow user to click through the initial onboarding screen (instead of having to wait until the screen text finishes rendering)
- [ ] Add a Skip Intro button to the onboarding flow starting on the first page
- [x] If a user already signed up, redirect them to the oauth page immediately (rather than loading the welcome screen)
- [ ] Add a message telling users that they need to reauthenticate with google (in order to keep their account safe)
- [x] Fix onboarding test `act` warnings

Improve styes
- [x] Next buttons

### Use Case

This'll make it easier for newcomers to get started, and for existing users to keep using the app.

Making these steps cumbersome is leading to drop-offs in adoption

### Additional Context

### Implementation Guidance

**Add flag to the API response**
- Differentiate between a user not being able to authenticate because
  - They've never signed up
  - They signed up, but their google access token is expired
- Consider returning a 200-level response instead of a 401 depending on the above case

issueDTO.title: Deprecate `verbose_individual_losses` in trainer
issueDTO.description:
In `deepinv.training.Trainer`, if `verbose_individual_losses=False` but `train=False` (i.e. being used in tester mode) and `compute_eval_losses=False` (as usual), then trainer will fail as the progress bar will try to print the total loss but this hasn't been calculated.

https://github.com/deepinv/deepinv/blob/2bc07427272ac56d20f501bb8e266e0d3aeff9b2/deepinv/training/trainer.py#L1026

I would suggest to deprecate the option completely, the argument doesn't add much, we could just always print the total loss to the end of the progress bar either way, if the user doesn't want it they can ignore it. We should conditionally add it if and only if it exists.

Furthermore, there's no point conditioning this below, adding a value to the logs is no overhead anyway.

https://github.com/deepinv/deepinv/blob/2bc07427272ac56d20f501bb8e266e0d3aeff9b2/deepinv/training/trainer.py#L827

repository.description: DeepInverse: a PyTorch library for solving imaging inverse problems using deep learning
repository.name: deepinv

summary.main: Deprecate the `verbose_individual_losses` option in the `trainer` module to fix an issue that causes the trainer to fail when used in tester mode.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The requirement is to deprecate the option and add the total loss to the end of the progress bar, if the user doesn't want it, they can ignore it.
summary.attemptedFixes: Deprecate the `verbose_individual_losses` option completely, and conditionally add it to the progress bar if and only if it exists.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is related to the `trainer` module in the `deepinv` repository, specifically in the `trainer.py` file.

comments: /assign

Thank you! I???ll look into it and do my best to fix the issue properly.

I???d like to test the UI locally without actually calling the Gemini API, just to quickly check how the command text is displayed after `npm start`. However, it always triggers a real API call, and when tokens run out, it slows down the process a lot. 2. I tried using React DevTools to trace which files correspond to each UI component, but it throws an error when launched (I???ve attached a screenshot). 3. Currently, `Ctrl + D` already works as an exit command. Should I make it so that pressing `Ctrl + D` *once* during command execution shows the full command, or should I assign a different key? 4. Should the key event be handled globally (like the existing `Ctrl + D` exit behavior) or locally inside `/packages/cli/src/ui/components/messages/ToolConfirmationMessage.tsx` ??? similar to how `'d'` is handled? 1. /auth gemini disable will prevent it from calling gemini. It shouldn't call gemini wtihout a prompt
2. this is more sophisticated than my process. Haven't really used React DevTools
3. CTRL-D was a suggestion - assign whatever you think a good key would be. maybe see what other tools might use and people might be familiar with
4. That is a really interesting question. Which makes it most useful to you? However the point is for NON-confirmed tools. So if you're in yolo mode and its doing shell commands it truncates them with ... at the end. for Tool confirmation it expands it when you hit d. So maybe it will just turn off truncation and do expansion for all? Or maybe it will just be the tool that is currently running? I think doing it for all would be simpler --but you might need to limit to what is being displayed if you do (in case it tries to do EVERY tool ever in that session)

issueDTO.title: Update histograms based on include/exclude null section/withdrawn filters
issueDTO.description: **Describe the bug** From the TA grading page, clicking on "statistics & charts" we can view an overall histogram of the student grades for that gradeable. We can use edit filters to include/exclude students who are in the NULL section (dropped the course) and similarly students who are withdrawn. While toggling include for these options changes the number of students & the average & other stats on the grade details page, it does not remove these students from the histogram. The histogram is identical before & after even though there are multiple students who submitted the assignment & were graded who are in NULL section and or withdrawn. **Expected behavior** These filters are new, so I guess the code that does the plots needs to be updated to pay attention to the filters.

- [ ] Style guide compliance
  - [ ] Use sentence case subheadings. Only proper nouns should be capitalized after the first word of the heading.
  - [ ] Capitalize OpenTelemetry proper nouns and de-capitalize general nouns (for example, Collector is capitalized when referring to the OTel Collector, but signal names such as span or trace are not capitalized.

- [ ] Grammar
  - [ ] Unnecessary passive voice
  - [ ] Unnecessary adverbs and general wordiness
  - [ ] Future tense - should almost always be present tense
- [ ] Tone/voice continuity - look for any obvious shifts in tone or voice and correct them
- [ ] Request a review for accuracy from the Collector SIG.

issueDTO.title: Integer/pixel size for `gap` parameter in `st.container` and `st.columns`
issueDTO.description:
### Checklist

- [x] I have searched the [existing issues](https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/issues) for similar feature requests.
- [x] I added a descriptive title and summary to this issue.

### Summary

`st.container` and `st.columns` both have a `gap` parameter but it's only possible to specify small/medium/large/None. We should additionally allow setting a pixel value. 

### Why?

I had a few situations where I wanted a tiny gap of only a few pixels. `None` felt to small and `"small"` felt too big. 

### How?

Just accept an integer in addition to the existing values, similar to `width` or `height` parameters we have elsewhere. 

### Additional Context

_No response_

issueDTO.title: [DOCS]: Bring back benchmarking guide
issueDTO.description:
### Feature request

The benchmarking guide with details about `dynamo/benchmarks/llm` scripts was lost when deleting `examples/llm` directory here: https://github.com/ai-dynamo/dynamo/pull/1899

The old guide contents are here for reference: https://github.com/ai-dynamo/dynamo/blob/35c56065bb490e12bba84a6abf8107dc1f2c7529/examples/llm/benchmarks/README.md

These help explain how to use the benchmarking scripts here: https://github.com/ai-dynamo/dynamo/tree/main/benchmarks/llm

It has some outdated concepts like steps for using `dynamo serve` that should be updated for new deployment steps instead. CC @alec-flowers 

### Describe the problem you're encountering

No documentation on perf.sh and plot_pareto.py scripts


### Describe alternatives you've tried

_No response_
comments: CC @ziqifan617 @kthui @tanmayv25

Thanks for opening this issue ??? I???d be happy to help recreate the benchmarking guide.

My plan is to rebuild the documentation by referencing the old `examples/llm/benchmarks/README.md` as a baseline and aligning it with the current `benchmarks/llm` structure (including updated scripts like `perf.sh`, `plot_pareto.py`, and related examples). The goal is to make the new guide easier to follow for both local and multi-node benchmarking setups and to focus on the scripts currently located at `benchmarks/llm`.

Since I don???t have access to multi-GPU or cluster hardware, I???ll be testing portions of the workflow locally on an Apple M1 Pro system. The initial draft will concentrate on verifying documentation accuracy, updating deprecated references (like old `dynamo serve` usage), and adding clear notes about hardware prerequisites, data paths, and script functionality (e.g., `perf.sh` options and expected outputs).

After the first pass, I???ll request review specifically from maintainers familiar with the benchmarking workflow to confirm integration across supported backends (vLLM, TensorRT-LLM, etc.) and add notes for high-performance environments.

Does this plan sound aligned with what you???re expecting for this doc restoration?

@rmccorm4 @hhzhang16

@AsadShahid04 this makes sense to me, would love to review! you can also use smth like brev.nvidia.com to test if it makes sense

cc: @BenHamm @hhzhang16 who can also review with me
Yup, sounds good to me too! Please tag me in any MRs, happy to review. Thanks for working on this!

## Testing Update & Issue Found

I've successfully restored the benchmarking guide and tested it on brev.dev. The documentation is working well, but I discovered an issue with the `perf.sh` script that affects the `plot_pareto.py` workflow.

### Issue: Directory Structure Mismatch

**Problem:** The `plot_pareto.py` script expects benchmark results to be organized in subdirectories like:
`artifacts_0/`
`-concurrency1/`
`profile_export_aiperf.json`
`-concurrency2/`
`profile_export_aiperf.json`
`...`


However, when running `perf.sh` with multiple concurrency levels (e.g., `--concurrency 1,2,4,8`), AIPerf appears to be creating a single `profile_export_aiperf.json` file in the artifacts directory, overwriting previous results instead of creating separate subdirectories for each concurrency level.

**What I observed:**
- Running `bash benchmarks/llm/perf.sh --concurrency 1,2,4,8 ...` creates `artifacts_0/` with a single `profile_export_aiperf.json` file
- The `plot_pareto.py` script fails with: `Exception: non-unique matches: []` because it can't find the expected `-concurrency<N>/` subdirectories


**Possible causes:**
1. AIPerf's output format may have changed and no longer creates subdirectories automatically
2. The `perf.sh` script may need to be updated to manually create subdirectories for each concurrency level before calling AIPerf
3. AIPerf may need a different flag or configuration to create per-concurrency subdirectories

**Testing environment:**
- Tested on brev.dev with Dynamo 0.7.0 (built from source)
- AIPerf version: (`0.2.0`)
- Model tested: Qwen/Qwen3-0.6B

Should I:
1. Investigate further and propose a fix to `perf.sh` to create the expected directory structure?
2. Update the documentation to note this limitation?
3. Both?

@hhzhang16 @athreesh

Opened a bug for directory structure mismatch:
https://github.com/ai-dynamo/dynamo/issues/4233

Opened a PR for review...but cannot test pareto graph until bug fix. WIll try opening a PR for pareto fix soon after confirmation!

https://github.com/ai-dynamo/dynamo/pull/4234

> Investigate further and propose a fix to perf.sh to create the expected directory structure?

I think this option would be best! There's a chance that things have changed following the switch to AIPerf that require changes in our scripts
