issueDTO.title: perf: move to parking_lot avoid poisoned locks
issueDTO.description:
If we ever want to get rid of these panics for poisoned locks, we can switch to [parking_lot](https://docs.rs/parking_lot) which doesn't do poisoning. Poisoning only happens when a thread panics while a lock is acquired. If we are strict about not panicking, then we don't need the poisoning feature and its extra overhead.

_Originally posted by @demosdemon in https://github.com/ava-labs/firewood/pull/1027#discussion_r2183245436_
comments: Interesting side effect of using parking lot and the changes @AminR443 is making with #1447 is that it opens up access to something like [`ArcMutexGuard`](https://docs.rs/parking_lot/latest/parking_lot/struct.ArcMutexGuard.html) which has some niche and valuable use cases but must be used sparingly to prevent holding onto the lock longer than necessary.

repository.description: Compaction-Less Database Optimized for Efficiently Storing Recent Merkleized Blockchain State
repository.name: firewood

summary.main: move to parking_lot to avoid poisoned locks and potentially remove panics for poisoned locks
summary.validationOrRequirement: strict about not panicking, then we don't need the poisoning feature and its extra overhead
summary.otherNotes: Interesting side effect of using parking lot and the changes @AminR443 is making with #1447 is that it opens up access to something like [ArcMutexGuard](https://docs.rs/parking_lot/latest/parking_lot/struct.ArcMutexGuard.html) which has some niche and valuable use cases but must be used sparingly to prevent holding onto the lock longer than necessary.

issueDTO.title: [All SDKs] OAuth token endpoint should be configurable
issueDTO.description:
## Description

For clients using OAuth2 credentials, the token endpoint is currently hardcoded in all SDKs (with `/oauth/token` value).
Could it be possible to make it configurable? Or even better support oidc discovery?

I'm willing to contribute if that's something you would be interested in :)

## Steps to take
Change the `apiTokenIssuer` field in the configuration to accept a full URL.
So:
| `ApiTokenIssuer` | Endpoint SDK will hit |
| --- | --- |
| `issuer.fga.example` |  `https://issuer.fga.example/oauth/token` |
| `https://issuer.fga.example` |  `https://issuer.fga.example/oauth/token` |
| `https://issuer.fga.example:8080` |  `https://issuer.fga.example:8080/oauth/token` |
| `issuer.fga.example/some_endpoint` |  `https://issuer.fga.example/some_endpoint` |
| `https://issuer.fga.example/some_endpoint` |  `https://issuer.fga.example/some_endpoint` |
| `https://issuer.fga.example:8080/some_endpoint` |  `https://issuer.fga.example:8080/some_endpoint` |

Of course, we'll need to do some of the validations to ensure e.g. users are passing fields with `https` or `http` (and not e.g. ftp) and that the full url is valid

## Related Issues
- .NET SDK issue: https://github.com/openfga/dotnet-sdk/issues/30
- (duplicate) https://github.com/openfga/sdk-generator/issues/197

## SDKs to be updated
- [ ] JS SDK (https://github.com/openfga/js-sdk/pull/139) by @marcoquotech
- [x] Go SDK (https://github.com/openfga/sdk-generator/pull/275)
- [x] .NET SDK (https://github.com/openfga/dotnet-sdk/pull/151) by @OsmanMElsayed 
- [x] Python SDK https://github.com/openfga/python-sdk/issues/136
- [x] Java SDK (https://github.com/openfga/sdk-generator/pull/240)
comments: I opened the PR #240 for the Java SDK. I have prepared all other SDKs (go, js, dotnet and python) but I'll wait your review on this one before submitting them 😃.
@le-yams do you still have the other sdk examples around? I know it's been a while!
Hi I've opened the PR #421 for the Python SDK. Looking forward to a review

The only way this can be properly solved is to use the well known endpoint of the IDP in question, to correctly discover endpoints for the `issuer` and `token_endpoint`, etc. The current implementation doesn't work for Microsoft Entra ID, nor Amazon Cognito for example, for different reasons.

Additionally, the reliance on audience for OIDC client credentials auth doesn't work for Amazon Cognito (as far as I can tell) as it doesn't appear to support audience and there is no `aud` claim for it in an access token.

Unfortunately, also the Python SDK still seems to experience this issue, as the suffix is hardcoded in the [OAuth client's `_obtain_token` function](https://github.com/openfga/sdk-generator/blob/e25309ce8a543418bd9ea346a039ac9f4d16476c/config/clients/python/template/src/oauth2.py.mustache#L63).

Edit: Should be fixed now.

Hi @dyeam0,

I implemented the fix for this in the dotnet SDK following the same pattern in the go, java & python SDKs. It would be great to get someone's 👀 on the PR: https://github.com/openfga/dotnet-sdk/pull/151
@OsmanMElsayed Thanks for the PR! We will get someone lined up to review it for you.

issueDTO.title: Support serializing with custom cost model
issueDTO.description:
Currently the extract in Rust can be passed a custom cost model to use for extration. 

The serialization also could be passed the same type of cost model to facilitate serializing using the same cost model that would be used for extraction.
comments: I???d like to try this???could you provide some hints in code?

Sure! The extraction logic takes in a cost model:

https://github.com/egraphs-good/egglog/blob/529f428d2443f126cd23d1012d7dba980baeed33/src/extract.rs#L143-L146

The serialization does not:

https://github.com/egraphs-good/egglog/blob/529f428d2443f126cd23d1012d7dba980baeed33/src/serialize.rs#L125C37-L125C52

To serialize a cost, each node's cost must be emitted separately and not include the costs of the children.

So you wouldn't want to use the [`fold` method of the CostModel](https://github.com/egraphs-good/egglog/blob/529f428d2443f126cd23d1012d7dba980baeed33/src/extract.rs#L17). You would want to use the `enode_cost` and `base_value_cost`. To use the `container_cost`, we could pass the the identity cost for all children instead of using their real values. It would be better to maybe provide in the children costs and then subtract them off the result, or change the interface to allow creating a container cost without it's children, but both of those changes would require changes to the `CostModel` trait, which might be better to avoid to start.

repository.description: egraphs + datalog!
repository.name: egglog

summary.main: Implement support for serializing with a custom cost model, allowing the serialization to use the same cost model that would be used for extraction.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The serialization should be able to pass the same type of cost model that would be used for extraction, and each node's cost must be emitted separately and not include the costs of the children.
summary.attemptedFixes: The comments suggest that the fix involves using `enode_cost` and `base_value_cost` instead of `fold` method of the CostModel, and possibly using the `container_cost` with the identity cost for all children.
summary.otherNotes: The extraction logic takes in a cost model, while the serialization does not. To serialize a cost, each node's cost must be emitted separately and not include the costs of the children. The `enode_cost` and `base_value_cost` should be used instead of the `fold` method of the CostModel. The `container_cost` could be used with the identity cost for all children instead of their real values.

issueDTO.title: [InstCombine] Missed optimization: fail to fold `(A >> C1) Pred C2` if `shr` is used multiple times
issueDTO.description:
Alive2 proof: https://alive2.llvm.org/ce/z/4JKW9d

### Motivating example 

```llvm
define i1 @src(i32 %a){
entry:
  %div = ashr exact i32 %a, 3
  call void @use(i32 %div)
  %cmp = icmp slt i32 %div, 15
  ret i1 %cmp
}
```
can be folded to:
```llvm
define i1 @tgt(i32 %a) {
  %div = ashr exact i32 %a, 3
  call void @use(i32 %div)
  %cmp = icmp slt i32 %a, 120
  ret i1 %cmp
}
```
This enables more optimizations for the other user of `shr` as I observe in benchmark.
Unsigned case is in alive2 proof.

### Real-world motivation
Signed case is derived from [z3/src/sat/smt/pb_solver.cpp](https://github.com/Z3Prover/z3/blob/master/src/sat/smt/pb_solver.cpp) (after O3 pipeline).
Unsigned case is derived from [z3/src/tactic/core/collect_occs.cpp](https://github.com/Z3Prover/z3/blob/master/src/tactic/core/collect_occs.cpp) (after O3 pipeline).
The example above is a reduced version. If you're interested in the original suboptimal IR and optimal IR, email me please.

**Let me know if you can confirm that it's an optimization opportunity, thanks.**

summary.main: The main goal of the issue is to enable more optimizations for the other user of `shr` by fixing the missed optimization in LLVM's InstCombine pass.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The issue requires confirmation that it's an optimization opportunity. The author is open to suggestions and wants to see performance data from pre-commit CI. The issue is also labeled as a good first issue, making it suitable for new contributors.
summary.attemptedFixes: The issue has been reviewed, and the line `if (IsAShr && Shr->hasOneUse())` in the function `foldICmpShrConstant` has been identified as the potential cause. The suggestion is to remove this condition and see how it breaks other patterns in CI.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is about missed optimization in LLVM's InstCombine pass, specifically failing to fold `(A >> C1) Pred C2` when `shr` is used multiple times. The motivating example is provided, and the real-world motivation is derived from Z3's code. The issue is labeled as a good first issue.

issueDTO.title: [Bug]: Mac OS VFS: Exclamation mark on sync status but no easy way to tell what's wrong
issueDTO.description:
### ?????? Before submitting, please verify the following: ??????

- [X] This is a **bug**, not a question or a configuration issue.
- [X] This issue is **not** already reported on Github (I've searched it).
- [X] Nextcloud Server and Desktop Client are **up to date**. See [Server Maintenance and Release Schedule](https://github.com/nextcloud/server/wiki/Maintenance-and-Release-Schedule) and [Desktop Releases](https://nextcloud.com/install/#install-clients) for supported versions.
- [X] I agree to follow Nextcloud's [Code of Conduct](https://nextcloud.com/contribute/code-of-conduct/)

### Bug description

On the 3.14-macOS-vfs clients that we are using, we often see the exclamation mark icon on the status bar. Hovering on it, it says the vfs sync had an issue.
However, opening the settings panel and clicking on "Create debug archive" freezes the UI and the Nextcloud process becomes unresponsive. This seems to be related (kind of a side effect) to the sync issue itself, because when the sync status is OK, it's possible to generate the debug archive without freezes.

The problem is, I have no clue on what the problem is and therefore haven't found a way to prevent/work around it.
...


### Steps to reproduce

1. Have the client running for at least some hours.
2. The client shows an exclamation mark on the status bar, complaining the last sync had an issue.
3. Open the settings panel and click on "Create debug archive"
...


### Expected behavior

The debug archive should be created.
Observed behaviour: the panel hangs and the process becomes unresponsive, I have to kill it.
Seems similar to what happened a few versions back, on opening the settings panel, where the process froze and needed to be killed. 
...


### Which files are affected by this bug

-

### Operating system

macOS

### Which version of the operating system you are running.

Sonoma 14.6.1

### Package

Official macOS 12+ universal pkg

### Nextcloud Server version

29.0.6

### Nextcloud Desktop Client version

3.14.0-vfs

### Is this bug present after an update or on a fresh install?

Updated from a minor version (ex. 3.4.2 to 3.4.4)

### Are you using the Nextcloud Server Encryption module?

Encryption is Disabled

### Are you using an external user-backend?

- [ ] Default internal user-backend
- [ ] LDAP/ Active Directory
- [ ] SSO - SAML
- [ ] Other

### Nextcloud Server logs

_No response_

### Additional info

_No response_
comments:
By reopening the client (i.e. quitting and relaunching the app) brings back the sync status to OK. 
The debug archive contains some errors, in the current case: 

Very frequently:
`Nil deleted metadatas received in change read at https://.../remote.php/dav/files/user for user: user https://...`

Much less frequently:
`err: Error while sending authentication request to nextcloud: Error while connecting to nextcloud: error sending request for url (https://.../index.php/apps/notify_push/uid`

and also:
`1 depth read of url https://.../remote.php/dav/files/user did not complete successfully, error: Impossibile trovare un server con il nome host specificato.` (this looks like a DNS lookup failure)
Last but not least: if possible, it would be great to add timestamps at the beginning of each line in the debug log file.
This issue might be related to #7240 and hopefully closed by it as well.

@claucambra I need to add more info to this issue about the client behaviour.
The 3.14.0 and 3.14.1 versions (mac OS vfs) seem to bring back a performance issue that makes the client almost unusable, at least on our shares, which are fairly large.
The FileProviderExt process is often consuming 100% of one core. I don't know if this is a known issue.
I had to revert to 3.13.4 which doesn't seem suffer from this problem (it does suffer from other issues however, which are solved by 3.14.0).

The console log shows some error lines and among those, I saw some "watchdog" like messages about high CPU consumption by the FileProviderExt process.
So I wonder wether the exclamation mark can arise because of a timeout in sync time or a stop because of too high CPU consumption? 

The end result is that FInder is often (not always) very slow in opening folders that were not previously opened, and also in opening files, I guess this happens simply because the FIleProviderExt process is busy.

Let me know if you need console logs, I'll attach them.
Thanks and regards,

issueDTO.title: feat: build tags for all the providers to disable them on demand
issueDTO.description:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

The idea is that all the providers get their own build tags. Say `go:aws` `go:gcp` `go:vault` etc.

In the register file in which we include all of them, we can also add their build tags.

This adds the ability that people who are very security focus can actually disable ALL the source code for a provider they don't want to use and actually only include the provider they DO want to use.

So a build could be created in which only the code is included that lets you deal with AWS provider. This further strengthens the security posture of ESO because other providers couldn't bleed into the only providers being used by the user.

**Note**: ESO would ALWAYS build ALL of the providers. This is strictly a user operated feature. If users would like to opt-out from providers they need to build their own ESO with the right build flags.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
A clear and concise description of what you want to happen.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
A clear and concise description of any alternative solutions or features you've considered.

**Additional context**
Add any other context or screenshots about the feature request here.
comments: This could be a good first issue for newcomers 😄 - it's really some file additions and a Makefile change.
Calling dibs on this one, happy to work on it :)
got here too late :P

Hey all, my apologies about the delay, I haven't found time to work on this story.
I've started in this fork if it's of any help to other contributors [link](https://github.com/external-secrets/external-secrets/compare/main...pomyslowynick:external-secrets:main)
I don't want to block others from contributing if they've time to dedicate to this story.
If nobody wants to pick it up I'll work on it whenever I find the time.

I???d be happy to take this on if no one else is currently working on it.
I???ve already started a fork with some initial work here: [link](https://github.com/ShimonDarshan/external-secrets/tree/feat/add-option-to-build-only-specific-providers).
Please go ahead @ShimonDarshan  👍

Update:
I???ve implemented support for building ESO with provider-specific build tags using Go???s native build tag mechanism.

You can build the controller to include only the providers you need by running:
`make build PROVIDER=aws`
Or, to build the controller with multiple providers:
`make build PROVIDER="vault,aws"`

By default, PROVIDER is set to all_providers (which includes all providers available in ESO).
If you want to build all providers, you don???t need to set anything, you can just run the build command:
`make build`

I tested this by building the controller with only the AWS provider and confirmed that deploying the HashiCorp Vault provider failed as expected.
You can see my changes [here](https://github.com/ShimonDarshan/external-secrets/tree/feat/add-option-to-build-only-specific-providers-v2)
@ShimonDarshan can you open a PR for it? looks promising!

issueDTO.title: Refactor to avoid nested ternary operators
issueDTO.description:
###  Avoid nested ternary operators

It would be great if we cold avoid using Nested Ternary Operators in this repo. It seems the pattern has been used in different places which may motivate developers to use it again. 

# Reason

Nested ternary operators are generally considered a suboptimal coding practice because they significantly reduce code readability and maintainability. While the ternary operator is designed as a concise substitute for simple if-else statements, nesting them multiple times (e.g., a ? b : c ? d : e) quickly creates a complex and confusing structure that is difficult for developers to parse visually and logically. This ambiguity can lead to errors, as the operator precedence might not be immediately clear to someone other than the original author. For this reason, using clear, multi-line if-else if-else statements or a switch statement is strongly recommended when dealing with multiple conditions, prioritizing clarity over brevity to ensure the code remains understandable and easier to debug.


# Solution

- Add the proper ESLINT config. After this the ESLINT validation would fail, so you could spot the defected blocks. 
- Simply fix them all

issueDTO.title: Feature: unused imports lint/fixer
issueDTO.description:
I am getting a warning from protoc but not from the linter (using the vscode extension).

For example:

`warning: Import google/protobuf/wrappers.proto but not used.`
comments:
@tzachshabtay Thank you for your suggestion.
It sounds useful. I attached the label to this issue for starters.
Agree with @tzachshabtay.  It would also be useful to identify unused `imports` (or unused `messages` in the case where all `.proto` files across the org are available in a central repo).

I don't think it is possible for this lint rule to be reliably implemented in protolint?

Detection of unused imports requires the package name associated with the import to be known.
This requires reading the contents of the imported file to locate the package name definition (it can't be inferred from the import statement alone.)

As far as I can tell protolint only looks at a single proto file in isolation (as opposed to protoc which has the context of all of the files).

Please do correct me if I'm mistaken here!

You???re right. Besides, this rule needs the `proto_path` to find imports.
If users set it in the config, then imports can be checked properly.

With some additional logic to process all imports, the rule could be implemented.

issueDTO.title: Improve readability of workflows
issueDTO.description:
GitHub Actions have been pinned, but without inline comments showing the release version.

It would improve readability to use a standard tool like
https://www.npmjs.com/package/actions-up
to add comments to all pinned actions so maintainers can spot more easily when Dependabot updates haven't been merged yet.

Now:
```yaml
uses: actions/checkout@08c6903cd8c0fde910a37f88322edcfb5dd907a8
```

After:
```yaml
uses: actions/checkout@08c6903cd8c0fde910a37f88322edcfb5dd907a8 # v5.0.0
```

Where has the update process been defined?
Workflows contain old dependencies like bindgen-cli 0.70.1, tools should be updated too.

issueDTO.title: El Juguete Perdido ??? Sequence Puzzle: Visual issues when using aspect ratios other than 16:9
issueDTO.description:
In the scene `3_sequence_puzzle/sequence_puzzle.tscn`, some backgrounds or decorative elements appear outside the visible playable area when using aspect ratios other than 16:9.  
Additionally, the **Camera2D node** needs adjustment, as its current bounds prevent the player from progressing past a certain point in the level.

### Quick Steps
1. Open the scene in **Godot**.  
2. Enable **Debug Aspect Ratio**.  
3. Change the window aspect ratio (e.g., 21:9 or 4:3) and check for elements out of place.

issueDTO.title: Make dependabot auto-add `preview-benchmark-results` label
issueDTO.description:
To save a few minutes each time we update dependencies, it would be nice if we didn't have to manually trigger the benchmarking workflow by adding the `preview-benchmark-results` label to check on the performance impact of the dependency bump. 

Not sure if there may be a permissions issue for who can add the label -- I believe external users cannot add it, but perhaps there's a way to do so with GH secrets?
comments:
LLM suggests something along these lines:
```yml
name: Manage Dependabot Issues

on:
  pull_request:
    types: [opened, labeled]
    branches:
      - main # Or your target branch

jobs:
  label_issue_from_dependabot_pr:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    if: contains(github.event.pull_request.labels.*.name, 'dependencies') # Check for Dependabot's default label
    steps:
      - name: Add a label to a related issue
        uses: peter-evans/create-or-update-comment@v2 # Or a similar action that can interact with issues
        with:
          issue-number: ${{ github.event.pull_request.body | extract_issue_number }} # Assuming issue number is in PR body
          body: |
            Dependabot PR opened: ${{ github.event.pull_request.html_url }}
          labels: 'dependabot-update, needs-review' # Add your desired labels to the issue
          token: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
```

You can actually specify labels to add to the PR in the dependabot config. 


https://github.com/unitaryfoundation/ucc-bench/blob/16f631000961ac1d28f7584c541bc9c88b685493/.github/dependabot.yml#L22 is where we do so in ucc-bench. Not sure why we didn't do it here;probably just forgot.

issueDTO.title: Create `core_eia191__monthly_gas_storage`
issueDTO.description:
### Overview

What is the problem we're solving? For very simple items, this can be encapsulated in the success criteria.

EIA form 191 contains valuable information about working and base gas in reservoirs, injections, withdrawals, and location of reservoirs reported by operators of all underground natural gas storage fields on a monthly basis. Let's bring this data into PUDL!

### Precursors
What do we need to do before we can start work on this issue?

- [ ] #4755 

### Success Criteria

There is no one size fits all in table transforms, though we document our approach to cleaning data [here](https://catalystcoop-pudl.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dev/data_guidelines.html#examples-of-acceptable-changes).

The new table should meet the following criteria:
* a well defined and unique primary key: one or more columns that naturally explain what a row in the table corresponds to. For this table, this _should_ be one row per year and ID. You'll need to check that the combination of these fields is unique, and in the case of duplications, propose a strategy for creating a unique primary key.
* all categorical columns should be constrained (e.g., the state column shouldn't contain "New York City" in it).
* nulls should be standardized
* units should be standardized
* data types should be defined and enforced
* metadata should be added to the database schema for each new field and for the table itself
* data should be validated in DBT

### Transform the data
- [ ] Make a copy of `devtools/inspect-assets.ipynb`. Use the notebook to load the `raw_eia191__data` asset and inspect it. This asset contains all years of the table extracted and concatenated together.
- [ ] In the notebook, explore the table and transform it. Here are some docs re [standard pudl transforms](https://catalystcoop-pudl.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dev/data_guidelines.html#examples-of-acceptable-changes).
    - [ ] Make sure there are no non-standard nulls (e.g., "-"). If there are, replace them with `pd.NA`.
    - [ ] Check for primary keys of the table and drop if there are **clear** errors (ex: duplicates on expected PKs but with clear bad records aka one decent looking record and one with mostly nulls).
    - [ ] Handle unexpected dtypes: e.g., no numbers in the state column
    - [ ] Convert the `operating_state` column to well-behaved state subdivision codes (e.g., Alaska to AK). Do this by mapping the existing state names against `core_pudl__codes_subdivisions`, cleaning up strings as is needed. We'll need to decide how to handle the non-state values (e.g., Mexico, other) reported for correction records.
    - [ ] Clean up column names as needed to create succinct but informative variable names.
    - [ ] Convert the month and the date columns to one combined `report_date` column using `pudl.helpers.convert_to_date()`

#### Bring the tables into PUDL's ETL
- [ ] Once you're satisfied with the table, it's time to bring it into dagster.
   - [ ] In `pudl/src/pudl/transform/eia191.py` add a new `core` asset function based on [asset naming conventions](https://catalystcoop-pudl.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dev/naming_conventions.html#asset-naming-conventions). In this case: `core_eia191__monthly_gas_storage`
   - [ ] add the `@asset()` decorator to this function.
   - [ ] Migrate your transforms for the notebook into this function.
   - [ ] [Reload the code location in dagster](https://catalystcoop-pudl.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dev/dev_dagster.html#reloading-code-locations), search for your new table in the "Asset" tab and materialize it. See [our docs on Dagster](https://catalystcoop-pudl.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dev/dev_dagster.html) for support.
- [ ] **Checkpoint:** Before you press on to the next set of tasks, get a review from a Catalyst developer.
- [ ] Add metadata for this table to add this table to the database schema
   - [ ] define the table  in `pudl/src/metadata/resources/eia191.py`
       - [ ] define the fields (aka column names)
       - [ ] add primary keys if possible
       - [ ] add `"field_namespace": "eia",`
       - [ ] add `"sources": ["eia191"],`
       - [ ] add `"etl_group": "eia191",`
       - [ ] consult with a Catalyst developer about how to update table documentation
    - [ ] Go add any new fields into `pudl/src/pudl/metadata/fields.py`
       - [ ] check that each field doesn't already exist.
       - [ ] add a description for each field.
       - [ ] add the data type
       - [ ] add constraints (enums/categories or patterns) if relevant.
       - [ ] add units
- [ ] **Checkpoint:** Before you press on to the next set of tasks, get a review from a Catalyst developer.
- [ ] Write the table to the PUDL database
   - [ ] Add the io manager to the asset() decorator: `@asset(io_manager_key="pudl_io_manager")`
   - [ ] [update alembic schema](https://catalystcoop-pudl.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dev/run_the_etl.html#database-schema-migration)
- [ ] Materialize your table via the [dagster ui](https://catalystcoop-pudl.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dev/run_the_etl.html#running-the-etl-via-the-dagster-ui)
- [ ] Add a table schema in [dbt](https://catalystcoop-pudl.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dev/data_validation_reference.html#adding-new-tables) and add [expected row counts](https://catalystcoop-pudl.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dev/data_validation_quickstart.html#row-counts)
- [ ] Add any other DBT tests that seem sensible (e.g., volume can't be negative).

summary.otherNotes: This issue aims to bring EIA form 191 data into PUDL. The data includes information about working and base gas in reservoirs, injections, withdrawals, and location of reservoirs reported by operators of all underground natural gas storage fields on a monthly basis.

issueDTO.title: Feature: Behavior Tree Integration via MCP (built on existing ROS Action support)
issueDTO.description:
### Discussed in https://github.com/robotmcp/ros-mcp-server/discussions/64
Originally posted by **mokcontoro** September 10, 2025
### Summary Now that ROS 2 Actions are implemented in the MCP interface, the next milestone is to leverage these capabilities for behavior tree generation and execution. This would enable LLMs or external planners to dynamically compose and orchestrate robot behaviors from existing action primitives. ### Motivation Behavior trees (BTs) provide a robust and modular structure for sequencing and prioritizing robot tasks. With ROS Actions already accessible through MCP, we can use BTs as the planning and execution layer that composes these atomic skills into complex, explainable behaviors. This approach aligns well with ongoing research in skills composition and would make the MCP???ROS bridge far more expressive and reusable across tasks and platforms. ### Proposed Tasks #### Define MCP Tool Schema for BT creation and execution, e.g.: ``` { "name": "execute_behavior_tree", "parameters": { "tree_definition": "string (XML or JSON)", "context": "object (optional task/environment data)" } } ``` #### Add a Behavior Tree Manager in ros_mcp_server that: - Parses and executes BT definitions using py_trees or BehaviorTree.CPP. - Connects leaf nodes to existing ROS Actions or Services. - Streams BT status updates back to MCP. ### Demo: #### Example: Pick-and-place pipeline composed of: - NavigateToPose - PickObject - PlaceObject #### LLM generates or modifies BT structure based on high-level commands. #### (Optional) Explore integration with Claude Skills as a conceptual reference for structured, declarative skill graphs.
comments:
Hey @stex2005, I noticed this issue is assigned but hasn???t had much recent activity, hence I've started to understand more about behaviour trees and work on this issue.

I???ve already built a lightweight PyTree manager for parsing and executing JSON-based behaviour trees. I can also share the proposed functions for both the manager and the server here before opening a PR. 

Would it make sense to create an experimental `behaviour_tree` branch for the same? 

Thanks,
Bharat

@itsbharatj thanks for your message!

Quick question, does your approach use ROS-related BT libraries/packages, or is it implemented as a standalone?

My reasoning is:

- If it???s meant to interface with Behavior Trees running within ROS (e.g., using a ROS BT package), it might make sense to integrate the functionality within the `ros-mcp-server`.

- If it???s meant to be independent (e.g., using PyTrees or another generic BT library that can connect to ROS or other consumers), then a separate `bt-mcp-server` would be the cleaner approach.

I???m currently debating whether we should integrate the BT features directly into the ros-mcp-server or develop a separate bt-mcp-server. Personally, I???m leaning toward a separate MCP server for Behavior Trees, where the LLM acts as the glue agent, coordinating between ROS and BT. The BT server would expose tools like list_trees, load_tree, start/stop/tick, status/inspect, and set_blackboard/get_blackboard. The ROS and BT servers could interoperate through the LLM client (using respective tool namespaces) or via a thin coordinator layer if needed (possibly through Claude Skills). 

However, this decision is open for discussion and suggestions. Depending on the approach we decide to use, I???ll either create a feature branch on `ros-mcp-server` (if tied to ROS BT packages) or scaffold a new `bt-mcp-server` repository (if independent).

Found a few options out there, to not reinvent the wheel!

https://github.com/qcr/ros_trees/tree/ros2

https://github.com/splintered-reality/py_trees_ros

Hey @stex2005, thanks for your elaborate comment and reasoning. 

> does your approach use ROS-related BT libraries/packages, or is it implemented as a standalone?

Based on my understanding if we are incorporating ROS actions we would require ROS dependencies. However, the `BT_Manager` would be standalone as an template to read the `JSON` and `XML` generated by the LLM based on the requirement of the task (and the available ROS actions) and tool to verify and debug for any inconsistencies in the files. 

One of the things I noticed based on my initially testing was that given a specific goal for example `Move a turtle in a circle` the LLM did not utilise the BT planning tool until stated very explicitly. I'm not sure if you would have faced something similar while building multiple tools into the functions. 

I think you're right on creating a different server in the beginning to test `behaviour_trees` along with integrating some essential tools from `server.py`. If it works well, we can try integrating it together and testing it.

> Found a few options out there, to not reinvent the wheel!

Thanks for sharing these links, I think if they work well it can help abstract a lot of things.

> Based on my understanding if we are incorporating ROS actions we would require ROS dependencies. However, the `BT_Manager` would be standalone as an template to read the `JSON` and `XML` generated by the LLM based on the requirement of the task (and the available ROS actions) and tool to verify and debug for any inconsistencies in the files. 

You can use ROS actions to consume the BT, but I think that the generation of the BT itself could be independent. For instance, the LLM could decide whether to use actions/topics/services or any other available tools.

> One of the things I noticed based on my initially testing was that given a specific goal for example `Move a turtle in a circle` the LLM did not utilise the BT planning tool until stated very explicitly. I'm not sure if you would have faced something similar while building multiple tools into the functions. 

I think that we can provide some additional CTX, but I am expecting BT to be more useful when you have more complicated tasks and/or when you explicitly ask the LLM to plan a complex task. For instance, ask drawing a letter with the turtle sim and the LLM will fail. 

> I think you're right on creating a different server in the beginning to test `behaviour_trees` along with integrating some essential tools from `server.py`. If it works well, we can try integrating it together and testing it.

Honestly, both options can work in the beginning, but later we should discuss how to integrate it within the robotmcp mission.

issueDTO.title: Check SLRU hit ratio
issueDTO.description:
From https://www.postgresql.eu/events/pgconfde2025/sessions/session/6457/slides/664/pgconfde25-herrera-slru.pdf

Suggested query (from the slides above).

```
SELECT name, blks_zeroed, blks_read,
blks_hit+blks_read AS blks_accessed,
CASE WHEN blks_hit+blks_read = 0 THEN 'NaN'
ELSE (blks_hit::numeric / (blks_hit+blks_read))
::numeric(4,2) END AS hit_ratio
FROM pg_stat_slru;
```
comments: I've been working on this. Can you check the slru_hit_ratio service on the branch issue381? Thanks.

issueDTO.title: Investigate monthly vs annual EIA 191 data availability
issueDTO.description:
### Overview

What is the problem we're solving? For very simple items, this can be encapsulated in the success criteria.

Right now, we're only archiving the monthly data form from EIA 191. We should confirm that the data available from the annual report does not include respondents not available through the monthly data, so that we're not accidentally missing data points.

We know that EIA 191 annual data goes back to 2005 and monthly data only goes back to 2014, so if we want older years of data we'll inevitably need both. However, we need to know whether these datasets are expected to overlap or not to understand how to process both datasets.

### Success Criteria

How will we know that we're done?

* [ ] Decide whether and how to integrate the annual EIA 191 data into PUDL

### Next steps
* [ ] Download annual EIA 191 data for all years available: https://www.eia.gov/naturalgas/ngqs/#?report=RP7&year1=2014&year2=2023&company=Name
* [ ] Download monthly EIA 191 data for the same time period: https://www.eia.gov/naturalgas/ngqs/#?report=RP8&year1=2014&year2=2023&company=Name
* [ ] Compare: any respondents missing in one dataset and not the other?
* [ ] Compare: do the monthly records sum to the annual values for respondents appearing in both datasets?

issueDTO.title: Integrate EIA Form 191 Monthly Underground Natural Gas Storage Report
issueDTO.description:
### Overview

What is the problem we're solving? For very simple items, this can be encapsulated in the success criteria.

[EIA-191: Monthly Underground Natural Gas Storage Report](https://www.eia.gov/survey/#eia-191) data includes working and base gas in reservoirs, injections, withdrawals, and location of reservoirs reported by operators of all underground natural gas storage fields on a monthly basis.

So far, we've archived and extracted this data (see #2603, #3402).

To fully integrate this data into the PUDL database, we still need to clean this data, validate it, add it to the database, define its metadata, and write up some source documentation.

### Resources for integration

- The [survey form](https://www.eia.gov/survey/form/eia_191/form.pdf) and [spreadsheet](https://www.eia.gov/survey/form/eia_191/form.xlsx) are what respondents see.
- The [instructions PDF](https://www.eia.gov/survey/form/eia_191/form.xlsx) provided by EIA
- The [NGQS](https://www.eia.gov/naturalgas/ngqs/) and user guide, which is where we sourced the original data from.

### Success Criteria

How will we know that we're done?

* [ ] The data is extracted into a well-normalized and cleaned table with well-defined metadata
* [ ] Every table is validated by a standard series of DBT tests
* [ ] The EIA 191 data source is well documented

### Out of scope

- Explore integration of this dataset with related entity IDs from other natural gas datasets
- Harvest data into normalized entities

### Next steps

**PUDL Development Setup**

Before starting on any of these sub-issues, you'll want to set up your development environment.

- [ ] Fork the PUDL repository and follow the steps to set up the [PUDL development environment](https://catalystcoop-pudl.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dev/dev_setup.html)
- [ ] Activate the pudl-dev environment: mamba activate pudl-dev
- [ ] Grab the latest raw data for any relevant tables - in this case, EIA 191. To do so, run pudl_datastore --dataset eia191
- [ ] Generate the existing EIA 191 assets: follow the instructions to [open Dagster](https://catalystcoop-pudl.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dev/run_the_etl.html#running-the-etl-via-the-dagster-ui), and in the left-hand menu find the "raw_eia191" asset group. Click "Materialize all".

At the end of these steps, you should have successfully materialized all existing `eia191` assets in PUDL.

**Resources**
- Got stuck, have a question or need help? Push your progress to a draft PR so we can see what you're working on, and leave a comment in this issue tagging @catalyst-cooperative/com-dev. In general, the earlier you open a draft PR the sooner we can provide support and give feedback! Even if you only make it partway through the issue, someone else will also be able to pick up on your progress.

issueDTO.title: some TTLs not updating automatically (I guess)
issueDTO.description:
I'm designing a true dual-read register file with a write port and I'm making heavy use of 74245s in my design and It just doesn't work sometimes until some kind of a event happens (e.g. clicking on the border of DIP switches or connecting constants instead of input pins on the same circuit) I made a simpler one before and it worked but I tried to redesign it and I'm not sure if this version even works correctly or not but I wasn't able to resolve the issue. I added some other features to this design which just made debugging more complicated; I'm not even sure if the inputs on the *W*rite bus work correctly or if I have set the directions correctly but unfortunately I don't have the previous version so I'll be uploading this one.

I'm using the package `logisim-evolution-bin 4.0.0-1` from the AUR.

Thanks in advanced!
comments:
the 74245 IC seems to work fine in smaller scale testing (using constants as input and wires as outputs)

also I forgot to upload the circuit so here it is:

[circ.tar.gz](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/23439044/circ.tar.gz)

I can replicate this, on a fresh build from main, and in a more minimal environment (plus a knockoff TTL74245 in case anyone needs one):

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/7c8b4e96-f080-47dd-82e7-7757557a96da

[issue_2388.tar.gz](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/23456302/issue_2388.tar.gz)

Notice that the upper wires update only when the `DIR` pin is toggled or when the circuit is modified (ex a wire is modified).

I *suspect* this may be related to [pins 2???9 and 11???18 being labeled as output pins](https://github.com/logisim-evolution/logisim-evolution/blob/55da393bb5b5ac2c4c56809dc589bde7256403c9/src/main/java/com/cburch/logisim/std/ttl/Ttl74245.java#L35), removing pins from that array does appear to cause behavior I infer is correct:

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/0b3051e4-828b-4bd6-a704-fd2c900b5984

However that makes the pins be marked as input pins (rather than inoutput pins) which may cause further issues? I don't know.

If you select one of the 74245 components and set its "Show the internal structure" attribute to "Yes", you will see that this [bidirectional bus transceiver](https://www.alldatasheet.com/datasheet-pdf/view/51058/FAIRCHILD/74245.html) has tristate buffers, which are controlled by the DIR and ENABLE inputs. The observed behaviour is aligned to the data sheet and shown internal structure. I am therefore closing this issue as invalid.

I think there might be a misunderstanding, the problem isn't with the logic but rather that the chip doesn't update when using DIP switches, I might have implemented it wrong but the point with uploading the circuit was to show how I'm wiring the DIP switches to the TTLs, also @MinekPo1 seems to be able to replicate the issue

OK, I can now reproduce the non-propagation. I somehow managed to overlook it in my initial test with the `issue_2388.circ` provided by @MinekPo1. Still, I cannot find an obvious cause for that issue in `src/main/java/com/cburch/logisim/std/ttl/Ttl74245.java`. @davidhutchens or @BFH-ktt1, could you maybe have a look what is going on?

I have given this a brief look using a debugger. It seems that the simulator upgrade has optimized CircuitState so that when a value is changed on a port, it only marks the component dirty if the port is an input port. Thus the component's propagate() method is never called when it is an output port.

Making the change suggested by @MinekPo1 causes the simulator to mark the component dirty when the value changes on the port so it works as expected.

I note that the component seems to read or write to any port regardless of its input/output status!

I want to think about this and test some more before trying to fix it.
I suspect those ports should actually be declared INOUT, but AbstractTtlGate does not provide that option. The proper fix may be to add that capability there.
I have a working solution adding INOUT to AbstractTtlGate and using it in TTL74245. It still needs clean up and testing.

Thanks @davidhutchens for looking at this issue so quickly and finding a fix! I hope that change all pins to INOUT has no unwanted side effects with the other TTL gates, e.g., regarding the displayed tooltips when hovering over the pins. I am looking forward to your PR!

I'm always surprised how popular the TTL components still are among our users. @MinekPo1 and @Mani4D46: It would be great if you could test @davidhutchens fix with your TTL design once it becomes available.

@maehne: I am not changing all OUTPUT ports to INOUT. I am adding a constructor parameter to pass INOUT ports as well as the other kinds. So it should not change the behavior of any other TTL implementations. I will add a ToolTip string for the INOUT ports.

However, there may be (likely are?) other TTLs that should have some of their ports changed from OUTPUT to INOUT. I'm not sure how to look for those. Would @Mani4D46 or @MinekPo1 have any suggestions about where or how to look?

I'm surprised at how fast you guys resolved this issue, I took a look at all supported TTLs but wasn't able to find any other ones with bidirectional in/outs. the fact that TI blocks my IP address because of my location doesn't make this process any easier.

Thank you @Mani4D46 and @MinekPo1 for having a look. Thank you for the script, @MinekPo1.

The script does point out several files that have the same expression for the port number in getPort and setPort, but they are not actually the same port.

Ttl74164 does read from an OUTPUT port, but it expects to get back what it wrote, although it might just get U on a reset. For this work, I'll ignore it since its behavior has not changed. `data.pullDown` is not relevant to this issue. This is a shift register and that method does the shift on the data.

So at this time, we have just one file that should be using INOUT. I'll proceed with the clean up and testing. A PR will follow.

The observed behavior is aligned to the data sheet and shown internal structure. issueDTO.title: [Store] Allow VectorDocument ID to be a string
issueDTO.description:
Hello, I've been migrating a homegrown AI integration onto Symfony AI. I love the initiative and how it simplifies things. However, I hit a wall when migrating my custom Pinecone integration with Symfony Store. 
The problem is that it expects the vector document ID (coming from Pinecone) to be in `UUID` format, in my case, it is not. All the information is already stored in Pinecone with a different ID format, so I can't use it to query my database (I get an `InvalidArgumentException`). 
It would be great to add a way to overcome this. Perhaps the `VectorDocument` id could support `strings`, or is there a reason it must be a `UUID`?

This is the chunk of code I'm referring to: https://github.com/symfony/ai/blob/main/src/store/src/Bridge/Pinecone/Store.php#L71-L78

Thanks in advance!
comments: No, that's a valid change request i guess - PR welcome :)

Perfect, I can help with that. But first, I'd like to know what solution you'd prefer. In my humble opinion, the `VectorDocumet` id type should be `string`, so it doesn't impose anything on the client, but let me know your thoughts

I recall we had some kind of discussion somewhere about it already and thought about going with `int|string|Uuid` but it could also be just `int|string` i guess

cc @paulinevos @VincentLanglet @OskarStark do you recall?

`int|string|Uuid` would be my favorite, so when reading from the store and it is a string, we should try to populate a `Uuid` class and catch if this is not a valid one, one this case we can set it as string.

> `int|string|Uuid` would be my favorite, so when reading from the store and it is a string, we should try to populate a `Uuid` class and catch if this is not a valid one, one this case we can set it as string.

The only downside I can think of is if I send a string (in UUID format), when I read from the object, I'll get a `UUID` 
In other words, the input is a `string` and the output would be a `UUID`, perhaps that inconsistency may cause trouble to some apps
Indeed 🤔
what about supporting `UUID`, but without automatically casting strings?

repository.description: Symfony AI is a set of components that integrate AI capabilities into PHP applications
repository.name: ai

summary.main: Allow VectorDocument ID to be a string, and to support UUID but without automatically casting strings, to overcome the issue of the ID being expected to be in UUID format but is currently a string.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The requirement is to allow the VectorDocument ID to be a string, and to support UUID but without automatically casting strings.
summary.attemptedFixes: There was a suggestion to make the VectorDocument ID type int|string|Uuid, and also to automatically cast strings to UUID when reading from the store.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is related to a Pinecone integration with Symfony Store, and the problem is that the vector document ID is expected to be in UUID format but is currently a string. The solution proposed is to make the VectorDocument ID type string, but there was a discussion about making it int|string|Uuid.

issueDTO.title: [Feature]: Clean up `vllm.utils`
issueDTO.description:
### 🚀 The feature, motivation and pitch

`vllm/utils/__init__.py` has >3k lines with a long list of imports. This is not ideal for the following reasons:

- This file, being imported by many files in vLLM while also importing many external modules, makes it very difficult to defer expensive imports.
- The risk of merge conflicts is high whenever two PRs change this file, especially when imports are updated.
- The code because less organized.

We should split this up into multiple files under `vllm/utils` directory, where each file has a theme that can be used to group the various utility functions. Also, downstream code should import specific submodules of `vllm.utils` instead of the root `vllm.utils` to make deferring imports easier.


### Alternatives

_No response_

### Additional context

cc @hmellor @mgoin @youkaichao 

### Before submitting a new issue...

- [x] Make sure you already searched for relevant issues, and asked the chatbot living at the bottom right corner of the [documentation page](https://docs.vllm.ai/en/latest/), which can answer lots of frequently asked questions.

issueDTO.title: MudTextField - Error Binding Not Working
issueDTO.description:
### Before reporting

- [x] I searched existing issues
- [x] I tried in private/incognito browser

### What went wrong?

@bind-ErrorText="ErrorText" is not updated following a call to Validator. 

### Reproduction link

https://try.mudblazor.com/snippet/GuczFvvmfxXemRgK

### Reproduction steps

1. Open reproduction link.
2. Clear the text field causing the validator to add an error message.
3. Observe that the error message is not updated due to the two-way binding. 
4. Expectation is that the string is set.

### Version (bug)

v8.14.0

### Version (working)

_No response_

### Environment

_No response_

### Blazor rendering mode

_No response_
comments:
Hi,

`ErrorText` doesn't support two-way binding because it doesn't have an `ErrorTextChanged` parameter. The syntax `@bind-ErrorText="ErrorText"` is invalid in this case and doesn't do much.

This line:
https://github.com/MudBlazor/MudBlazor/blob/60e5bb8a745fb5d7e58e5954e0d30241f0d15c86/src/MudBlazor/Base/MudFormComponent.cs#L297
Is misleading, there should be `EventCallback<string> ErrorTextChanged`, which should be invoked
```C#
await ErrorTextChanged.InvokeAsync(errors.FirstOrDefault()).
```
This way, the parent component would receive the updated value with `@bind-ErrorText="ErrorText"`.

Based on the maintainer's analysis, this behavior is due to the absence of a feature (`ErrorTextChanged` callback) needed for two-way binding, rather than a defect in existing functionality. I've updated the label from `bug` to `enhancement` to reflect this.

---
*I'm an [AI assistant](https://github.com/danielchalmers/AutoTriage) ??? If I missed something or made a mistake, please let me know in a reply!*

<!--
**Triage Summary: MudTextField ErrorText Binding Issue**
Okay, so I've got this `MudTextField` issue to look at, and it seems straightforward.  `persidef` is reporting that the `@bind-ErrorText` isn't working as expected.  They've given a reproduction link, which is always helpful.  `ScarletKuro`, a maintainer, already weighed in and confirmed my initial hunch ??? it's not a bug *per se*, but a missing piece of functionality. Specifically, the `ErrorText` parameter doesn't have an `ErrorTextChanged` event callback, which is what's needed for two-way binding.
Based on that, I'm thinking we need to shift the label from `bug` to `enhancement`. The code isn't *broken*; it just doesn't do what the user *wants* it to do in this binding scenario.  `ScarletKuro`'s comment really nails it down, pointing directly to the missing line of code that needs to be added.  This makes it a perfect candidate for a "good first issue", too - it's well-defined, and the reproduction is solid.
My plan is to update the labels and post a clarifying comment explaining the change from `bug` to `enhancement`, directly citing `ScarletKuro`'s analysis. The title is fine as is. I'll also add a "good first issue" label to signal that this is an approachable task for a new contributor. I think this will steer the conversation correctly and get this issue moving in the right direction. It's a clean, actionable task.
-->

summary.main: The main goal of the issue is to make the @bind-ErrorText work as expected by adding the ErrorTextChanged callback, allowing for two-way binding.

summary.attemptedFixes: The maintainer ScarletKuro pointed out that the missing line of code that needs to be added is EventCallback<string> ErrorTextChanged, which should be invoked with await ErrorTextChanged.InvokeAsync(errors.FirstOrDefault()).
summary.otherNotes: The issue is about the @bind-ErrorText not working as expected, and the maintainer confirmed it's not a bug but a missing feature, specifically the ErrorText parameter doesn't have an ErrorTextChanged event callback, which is needed for two-way binding.

issueDTO.title: How to write a test for an empty body in a POST?
issueDTO.description:
Hi,

I'm trying to write some pytest tests for my falcon API. I'm using the following middleware for JSON translation:

```
class JSONTranslator(object):

    def process_request(self, req, resp):
        # req.stream corresponds to the WSGI wsgi.input environ variable,
        # and allows you to read bytes from the request body.
        #   
        # See also: PEP 3333

        # do nothing if content length is 0
        if req.content_length in (None, 0): 
            return

        body = req.stream.read()

        # ***** don't know how to write a test for this *****
        if not body:
            print('body was not present')
            raise falcon.HTTPBadRequest('Empty request body',
                                        'A valid JSON document is required.')

        print('got body')
        print(body)
        try:
            req.context['doc'] = json.loads(body.decode('utf-8'))

        except (ValueError, UnicodeDecodeError):
            raise falcon.HTTPError(falcon.HTTP_753,
                                   'Malformed JSON',
                                   'Could not decode the request body. The '
                                   'JSON was incorrect or not encoded as '
                                   'UTF-8.')

    def process_response(self, req, resp, resource):
        if 'result' not in req.context:
            print('result is not in req.context!')
            return

        print('FOUND result in req.context - json.dump-ing it')
        resp.body = json.dumps(req.context['result'])
```

I'm having difficulties figuring out how I can test the indicated block.  Does anyone have a suggestion/example?

What I have so far for testing this middleware is below, which sets up the resource and tests the first condition ("content length is 0")...

```
# extend TestResource to do more than just on_get()
class AllMethodResource(testing.TestResource):
    def __init__(self):
        super().__init__()

    def before(self):
        self.api = falcon.API(media_type='application/json',
                              middleware=[ json.RequireJSON(), ])

    def on_get(self, req, resp, **kwargs):
        self.req, self.resp, self.kwargs = req, resp, kwargs

        self.called = True
        resp.status = falcon.HTTP_200
        resp.body = self.sample_body
        resp.set_headers(self.resp_headers)

    def on_post(self, req, resp, **kwargs):
        self.req, self.resp, self.kwargs = req, resp, kwargs

        self.called = True
        #resp.status = falcon.HTTP_200
        #resp.body = self.sample_body
        #resp.set_headers(self.resp_headers)

# make sure what we send and what we receive is well-formed json
class Test_json_json_translator(testing.TestBase):
    def before(self):
        self.api = falcon.API(media_type='application/json',
                              middleware=[ json.JSONTranslator(), ])

        self.resource = AllMethodResource()
        self.api.add_route('/', self.resource)

    def test_post_with_zero_content_does_nothing(self):
        hdrs = [('Accept', 'application/json'),
                ('Content-Type', 'application/json'),]
        self.simulate_request('', method='POST', body='', headers=hdrs)
        assert(self.srmock.status == falcon.HTTP_200)
```

Thanks!
comments:
Humm, but how would you have an empty post body with content_length!=0?

_BTW a suggestion that may help: switch to pytest and https://github.com/yohanboniface/pytest-falcon, that exposes a (imho) simpler and cleaner test API.
See for example https://github.com/etalab/ban/blob/master/ban/tests/http/_

Good point - I'm just using the falcon example (I think that's where I got the JSONTranslator middle) and was thinking about how to cover it well with tests.  But I think empty posts are acceptable HTTP.
I've found you can get an empty body by passing `body=bytearray()`.
@bcthomas To force content-length to be non-zero when setting body to an empty string, you can explicitly specify Content-Length in the `hdrs` list that is passed to `self.simulate_request(...)`.
Consider also adding such a test to our own test suite (although we probably already have stuff along the lines of this, check first).

Hi,
I am new to the contributor world. Can I take this one? 
Is this mainly to add some tests with empty body in Falcon?

Hi @ytsai43!
Yes, you're welcome!
This issue is mostly a documentation task; although as noted above, we might need to add a test covering the recipe we are going to recommend (unless such already exists).

Hello, this issue still appears to be open; I'd like to work on it if that's alright.
New to contributing on GitHub (though not to programming).

Hey @0xMattB! 
Sure, go ahead!

Great, thank you!

Can I get some clarification on the issue to make sure it is addressed correctly?

From my understanding: We want to document a special test case where a request body is empty, but `Content-Length` is non-zero.
And then check to see if this case is already handled in the tests, and if not, create one.

Is this correct?

Yes, that sounds right.

To be honest, I don't remember if I tried writing this specific test case.

If everything works as described by @kgriffs above, we could add a FAQ item on this.

I wrote a test using `pytest` to confirm functionality. I'm new to Falcon, but getting the hang of it.
I'll fit this concept into the FAQ and see if I can find any existing tests.

`post.py:`
```
# 'post.py': Simulate Issue #678
from wsgiref.simple_server import make_server
import falcon

class Resource:

    def on_post(self, req, resp):
        # 1. Empty body, content-length is 0
        if req.content_length in (None, 0):
            resp.status = falcon.HTTP_200
        else:
            body = req.stream.read(req.content_length or 0)

            # 2. Empty body, content-length is NOT 0 (branch of interest)
            if not body:
                resp.status = falcon.HTTP_400
            # 3. Body present, content-length is valid
            else:
                resp.status = falcon.HTTP_201


def create():
    app = falcon.App()
    resource = Resource()
    app.add_route('/resource', resource)

    return app

app = create()

if __name__ == '__main__':
    with make_server('', 8000, app) as httpd:
        print("Serving on port 8000...")
        httpd.serve_forever()
```

`test_post.py:`
```
# 'test_post.py': Simulate Issue #678
import falcon
from falcon import testing
import pytest

import post

@pytest.fixture()
def client():
    return testing.TestClient(post.create())

def test_post_body(client):
    result = client.simulate_request(method='POST', path='/resource', body='body')
    assert(result.status == falcon.HTTP_201)

def test_post_no_body(client):
    result = client.simulate_request(method='POST', path='/resource', body='')
    assert(result.status == falcon.HTTP_200)

# *** Test case of interest
def test_post_no_body_with_length(client):
    headers = [('Content-Length', '1'),]
    result = client.simulate_request(method='POST', path='/resource', body='', headers=headers)
    assert(result.status == falcon.HTTP_400)
```

That looks good @0xMattB, just probably it would be practical to condense this to a short snippet as concise as possible for the FAQ.

If that is not possible, we also have the Recipes section for longer examples.
Will do. I'll also generalize the topic, and use this case as an example.

@vytas7 I'm almost through, I just encountered one issue when running `tox`. Would you be able to offer some guidance?

I got the project running in a container (VS Code Dev Container, Win11), everything from `tox` is good except for one `pytest` error:

```
FAILED tests/asgi/test_asgi_servers.py::TestASGIServer::test_put[_uvicorn_factory] - requests.exceptions.ReadTimeout: HTTPConnectionPool(host='127.0.0.1', port=48659): Read timed out. (read timeout=10)
```

I did not change anything related to this area of the code, so I'm wondering if I did something wrong configuring the project or some other issue is at play. Running `pytest` directly with that file passes.

Any thoughts? I can provide additional information if needed.

A side note: is the latest version of the container working for you btw? I'm not a VSCode user, but when I was testing it, it seemed to be broken. I proposed a PR to improve/fix it #2574.

As to the specific failure, I don't know tbh... Is it always the `PUT` test every time you run it, or is it non-deterministic?

I just downloaded the latest this morning, due to the recent update.
I ran `tox` three times and it was always the `put`.

What if you checkout the `master` branch or stash your changes, is the failure still there?
I think it is safe to go ahead and submit a PR if that is the case -- we do run this and other tests in CI on multiple Python version for every PR.

Aha, I see, I had the same issue, but I simply removed it because I didn't know what it did.
What does this Tox feature do? I can add it to that PR.

I'm not sure what it did (navigating a few new things here), but:
1. Got a warning that `contrib` was obsolete and to use `extras` instead
2. Found the version change in the [readme](https://github.com/devcontainers-extra/features/blob/1a8b99f228f9e03da68973e67c05d55e650dab6d/src/tox/README.md?plain=1#L4)

Same issue on the unmodified `master` branch:

```
FAILED tests/asgi/test_asgi_servers.py::TestASGIServer::test_put[_uvicorn_factory] - requests.exceptions.ReadTimeout: HTTPConnectionPool(host='127.0.0.1', port=46563): Read timed out. (read timeout=10)
```

So I'm good to submit the PR then?

Yes, I think so.

I took a quick look at that `PUT` test, and it actually exercises creating a large number of async tasks etc, there are notes by me and @CaselIT:
```
        # NOTE(caselit): on windows it takes more time so create less tasks
        # NOTE(vytas): Tests on non-x86 platforms are run using software
        #   emulation via single-thread QEMU Docker containers, making them
        #   considerably slower as well.
        num_cms_tasks = 100 if _WIN32 or not _X86_64 else 1000
```
When you run inside the container, it thinks that it's on native Linux, but probably it is slower since it running in a VM on your Windows. So I think you can simply ignore that error.

issueDTO.title: Multiple warnings in source code
issueDTO.description:
### Which Umbraco version are you using? (Please write the *exact* version, example: 10.1.0)

~~12.3.0+ (but applies to any version)~~
v16 (latest)

### Bug summary

There are thousands of warnings within the Umbraco source code. I was hoping to try and start to reduce these as use this issue as a base to work from (unless there already is one?).

My idea is to go through each project and check that there are no warnings, and if there are, remove them. 

This is until perhaps we can set warnings as errors to keep it clean for future? Bigger step/decision! I have started an initial PR for this at #15019.

### Specifics

I recommend ticking off each project if there are no warnings, or if all warnings have since been removed. 
To maintain this, we would also set warnings as errors (something for HQ to consider)

### Steps to reproduce

1. Open IDE of choice
2. Build
3. Observe warnings

### Expected result / actual result

Minimal to no warnings ultimately
```[tasklist]
### Tasks
```

comments:
Hi there @emmagarland!

Firstly, a big thank you for raising this issue. Every piece of feedback we receive helps us to make Umbraco better.

We really appreciate your patience while we wait for our team to have a look at this but we wanted to let you know that we see this and share with you the plan for what comes next.

- We'll assess whether this issue relates to something that has already been fixed in a later version of the release that it has been raised for.
- If it's a bug, is it related to a release that we are actively supporting or is it related to a release that's in the end-of-life or security-only phase?
- We'll replicate the issue to ensure that the problem is as described.
- We'll decide whether the behavior is an issue or if the behavior is intended.

We wish we could work with everyone directly and assess your issue immediately but we're in the fortunate position of having lots of contributions to work with and only a few humans who are able to do it. We are making progress though and in the meantime, we will keep you in the loop and let you know when we have any questions.

Thanks, from your friendly Umbraco GitHub bot :robot: :slightly_smiling_face:

Hi @emmagarland,

We're writing to let you know that we would love some help with this issue. We feel that this issue is ideal to flag for a community member to work on it. Once flagged here, folk looking for issues to work on will know to look at yours. Of course, please feel free work on this yourself ;-). If there are any changes to this status, we'll be sure to let you know.

For more information about issues and states, have a look at [this blog post](https://umbraco.com/blog/the-umbraco-issue-tracker-process/).

Thanks muchly, from your friendly Umbraco GitHub bot :-)

Hey Emma!

As a new HQ'er this is something that popped on my radar as well and I am very pleased to see some community initiative on this.

I will talk this trough with the team on what our vision for this is, feel free to continue making smaller PR's and ill get back to you asap 🤗

This would be great! I did some work on this a while ago, just trying to relieve some of this, by reformatting our code files: https://github.com/umbraco/Umbraco-CMS/pull/12438 (this is just for the core project)

Thanks @Migaroez and @Zeegaan! Glad that you like the idea, looking forward to hearing more.

Emma

issueDTO.title: [BUG] Right click context menus appear as black boxes (non interactive)
issueDTO.description: ### Does an issue for this already exist? - [x] I have searched the existing issues - [x] I have ensured my environment (operating system, app launcher, etc) is up to date ### Operating System and Version Bazzite 42 ### Launcher Lutris (Recommended) ### Launcher Installation Flatpak (Recommended) ### Other Install _No response_ ### Wine Version ElementalWarrior (Recommended) ### Affinity Version 2.6.3 ### Desktop Environment KDE (6.4.5) ### Description The right click context menus are black boxes. No entries appear and they don't appear to be interactable with. I have tried clicking on areas but nothing happens so they do not appear to be invisible. Thank you for all the work on this project, it is amazingly helpful. I am happy to help gather additional information if anyone can tell me what you need. ### Steps to reproduce 1. Follow guides exactly. 2. Open Affinity Designer or Affinity Photo or Affinity Publisher 3. Create a new document. 4. Right click anywhere a black box will appear instead of the right-click context menu. ### Expected behaviour The right click context menus should appear populated. ### Screenshots ### Logs ```shell N/A ``` ### Config N/A ### Self-service - [ ] I'd be willing to fix this issue myself.
comments: Hey there Brokenshield, I was looking into this a bit and I am not super clear on how to recreate this issue. Have you tried to reinstall by any chance? I also would suggest the RUM guide as well as it has produced different results sometimes.

Hi, Just wanted to pop in and say I am having similar issues on a similar system:
- EndeavourOS 
- KDE Plasma 6.4.5 under Wayland
- Lutris
- NVIDIA RTX 3090

The issues only arise when using DXVK, when disabled, the context menus work fine however the canvas flickers a lot and makes the app pretty painful to use.

I have not yet tested on rum as suggested, going to take a peek at that shortly and will update.

Thank you so much!

So, I tried turning off DXVK (Vulcan is on) and Affinity Designer menus now
appear and it seems to all work perfectly. I'll try it with the others
(though Designer is my main tool for now)

I'm experiencing the same issues as well. The splash screen is black and right click menus come up black. With DXVK disabled the windows flicker whenever new windows or popups are drawn or hidden.

- Manjaro
- KDE Plasma 6.3.6 Wayland
- Bottles + Elemental Warrior
- NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1070

It seems the common theme so far is Arch based distros with KDE.

as a workaround the following (with `winetricks renderer=gl`) seems to be helping in my case. probably not a good solution though

```
WINEPREFIX=$HOME/opt/wine/affinity wine reg add "HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Avalon.Graphics" /v DisableHWAcceleration /t REG_DWORD /d 1 /f
```

edit: switching from Wine 10.17 (as recommended in the terminal guide) to ElementalWarrior's Wine with `renderer=vulkan` seems to work for me as well, without any extra workarounds

I would like to report the same issue.

Setup details:
OS: Ubuntu 25.10
Gnome Desktop 49.0 Wayland
Bottles + ElementalWarrior Wine Prefix

Unfortunately, I could not test with DXVK off, since it somehow causes a memory overload on my device when trying to run Affinity. I believe that this may be more of a Bottles problem, so I'll try out other DXVKs or Lutris soon.

Same happening here, tried Vulkan, GDI and GL

issueDTO.title: [Bug] Various packages stopped updating due to checkver errors
issueDTO.description:
### Description
The issue comes from:
- #16349

There are lots of error logs during excavator execution. Various packages stopped updating due to checkver errors.
See: https://github.com/ScoopInstaller/Extras/actions/runs/18627830520/job/53108310389

Contributors are warmly welcome to help fix one or more of these broken manifest. Please note:
- Make sure there are no existing fix PRs.
- Create a separate PR or a separate commit for each manifest, with a title following the naming rules.
- Please do not attempt to close this issue in your PR.
- For manifests that are still available but will no longer receive updates, remove their checkver fields instead of deprecating them.
- For autoupdate filed, if we can still install a specific version via `scoop install app@version` (i.e., autoupdate is version-specific), removing it is also not recommended. https://github.com/ScoopInstaller/Extras/pull/16392#issuecomment-3438955656
> IMO, if we keep the autoupdate field, users can still install a specific version via `scoop install app@version`. Otherwise:
> ```
> PS> scoop install fbflipper@0.238.0
> WARN  Given version (0.238.0) does not match manifest (0.239.0)
> WARN  Attempting to generate manifest for 'fbflipper' (0.238.0)
> 'fbflipper' does not have autoupdate capability
> ```
> P.S. If https://github.com/ScoopInstaller/Scoop/pull/6370 gets merged, this will no longer be necessary and can be removed later.

### Package List
Here are all the packages stopped updating due to checkver errors.

This result was obtained using a simple matching script and may contain false positives.

> The GitHub page has been maliciously shut down, but development will continue. Currently, there doesn't seem to be a stable download link available, so we need to wait for updates from the upstream source.
>

`openark` has now launched a new official website and added download links. I will submit a pull request shortly to update the existing manifest.

> The description above is for tcno-acc-switcher. It seems more suitable for the Games bucket. Should we move it to the Games bucket? Or should we continue maintaining it in the Extras bucket?

> The following applications do not have stable releases and should be moved to the **Versions** bucket: > > * `xplorer` > * `vidi` > * `olive-editor` Then what should we do with these three applications?

The latest release of `i2pdbrowser` has a `tag_name` of **latest**, and the file `I2PdBrowserPortable_$version.7z` uses **473cdfe** as its version identifier.

I think this manifest does not need to be fixed at the moment, as the actual version number cannot be determined, and future versioning patterns remain unpredictable. This uncertainty makes it difficult to properly configure both `checkver` and `autoupdate`.

> As of version 2.0.0, moar has been renamed to 'moor', please install 'extras/moor' instead.
> Deprecate this manifest after 2026-02-01

`moar` has been confirmed as deprecated and does not require fixing.

xplorer
vidi
olive-editor

Thanks so much for your help!

I'm not sure why they were added to the Extras bucket in the first place. Maybe it's like:  https://github.com/ScoopInstaller/Extras/pull/9185#issuecomment-1509864740

We don't have enough maintainers/collaborators to handle the migration right now, so the conclusion remains the same:

> For now, let's keep it in the Extras bucket.

This issue is just for tracking broken manifests and may not resolve all of them at once. The number of PRs is getting a bit overwhelming -- nearly [40](https://github.com/ScoopInstaller/Extras/pulse) were merged this week.

> We don't have enough maintainers/collaborators to handle the migration right now, so the conclusion remains the same:
> 
> > For now, let's keep it in the Extras bucket.

Thank you for your reply.

> This issue is just for tracking broken manifests and may not resolve all of them at once.

Unfortunately, due to upstream changes or other external factors, the number of issues may continue to grow. Combined with the limited number of active contributors and maintainers, it has become increasingly difficult to address them effectively.

[`stellarium`](https://github.com/ScoopInstaller/Extras/blob/master/bucket/stellarium.json) is fixed, they added an arm64 installer to v25.3:

* <https://github.com/Stellarium/stellarium/issues/4604>
We might need to revisit our deprecation mechanism I guess?

> We might need to revisit our deprecation mechanism I guess?

I agree with this view.

I believe manifests that have not been updated for a long time should be automatically deprecated. For example, manifests that have not been automatically updated for three years after being added to the Main or Extras buckets should automatically enter the deprecation process, and those that remain unupdated for five years should be forcibly deprecated. Special cases may allow for a slight delay or exemption. Manifests in the Versions bucket could have a slightly extended timeframe. I am not sure whether such an automated process is feasible, but I hope this could provide some direction for improving the deprecation mechanism.

In addition, I think manifests added to buckets should also have an update-time requirement. For example, manifests added to the Main or Extras buckets should have received an update within the last three years before inclusion, while those in the Versions bucket should have been updated within the last five years. If these conditions are not met, the decision to include them should depend on the popularity of the software. I have noticed that some manifests in the Extras bucket had not been updated for over five years even before being added, and those manifests have still not received new updates to this day.

> We might need to revisit our deprecation mechanism I guess?

Yes, it's definitely worth looking deeper into this issue, though I generally agree with the current mechanism.

https://github.com/ScoopInstaller/Extras/pull/16349#issuecomment-3416228252
> We generally don't deprecate a package unless the package cannot be obtained at all.
> 
> - https://github.com/ScoopInstaller/Extras/pull/16007
> - https://github.com/ScoopInstaller/Versions/pull/2474
> - https://github.com/ScoopInstaller/Versions/pull/1169
> 
> For **widely-used** packages, sometimes we even retrieve them from web.archive.org.

The problem now is that we have too few maintainers/collaborators, too many packages, and an outdated workflow. Otherwise, I believe these rules are just acceptable.

> For example, manifests that have not been automatically updated for three years after being added to the Main or Extras buckets should automatically enter the deprecation process, and those that remain unupdated for five years should be forcibly deprecated.

I don't think this is what a package manager should do.

> In addition, I think manifests added to buckets should also have an update-time requirement. For example, manifests added to the Main or Extras buckets should have received an update within the last three years before inclusion, while those in the Versions bucket should have been updated within the last five years. If these conditions are not met, the decision to include them should depend on the popularity of the software. I have noticed that some manifests in the Extras bucket had not been updated for over five years even before being added, and those manifests have still not received new updates to this day.

Agree.
