issueDTO.title: Support generate input schema from  "Args" part of func doc with decorater @mcp.tool()
issueDTO.description:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Current decorator @mcp.tool can only get the function doc as the function description which indicates what the function does.
but the "Args" part is not extracted to generate the parameter schema. this missing leads the client side unable to call the tool with correct parameters. 

**Describe the solution you'd like**
although it can be implemented with @server.list_tools, but since the mcp.tool() decorator already add tool in a tool manager, implementing it in @mcp.tool() will be more convenient and readable.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
server.list_tools may be a alternative, but I don't know if it will be conflict with the mcp.tool() decorator, and the mixing is not beautiful at all

**Additional context**
Add any other context or screenshots about the feature request here.
comments:
The maintainers might want to look at [how Pydantic AI solves this](https://ai.pydantic.dev/tools/#function-tools-and-schema). 

> PydanticAI extracts the docstring from functions and (thanks to [griffe](https://mkdocstrings.github.io/griffe/)) extracts parameter descriptions from the docstring and adds them to the schema.
Looking forward to this feature

repository.description: The official Python SDK for Model Context Protocol servers and clients
repository.name: python-sdk

summary.main: The main goal of the issue is to support generating input schema from the 'Args' part of the function doc with the @mcp.tool() decorator, to enable correct parameter calls from the client-side.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The validation or requirement is to extract the 'Args' part from the function doc to generate the parameter schema.
summary.attemptedFixes: The author has considered implementing the solution with @server.list_tools, but is unsure if it will conflict with the mcp.tool() decorator and prefers a more convenient and readable solution within the @mcp.tool() decorator.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is related to a problem where the current decorator @mcp.tool can only get the function doc as the function description, missing the 'Args' part to generate the parameter schema, leading to client-side issues with correct parameter calls.

issueDTO.title: Add default /docs route to list information about the SSE MCP server
issueDTO.description:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Would be useful to have an equivalent to something like how FastAPI generates OpenAPI docs and are automatically accessible at /docs route. 

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Add a /docs route to the starlette app that provides information about the mcp server (available tools, prompts, resources, version, etc.)

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
none

**Additional context**
Basic example I currently use:
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/5de6a8b2-923e-481f-85ef-c2c606b63cd5)
comments:
I have developed web servers that integrate MCP SSE functionality:

- Using FastAPI: [fastapi_mcp_sse](https://github.com/panz2018/fastapi_mcp_sse/)
- Using Starlette: [starlette_mcp_sse](https://github.com/panz2018/starlette_mcp_sse)

These servers can be extended with custom routes while retaining full MCP SSE capabilities. For the FastAPI, you can find the OpenAPI docs after starting the server:
- Documentation (Swagger UI): http://localhost:8000/docs
- Documentation (ReDoc): http://localhost:8000/redoc

@mconflitti-pbc If I'm understanding correctly, you're looking for an autogenerated UI similar to an swagger/redoc UI that clearly lists the tools, prompts, and resources based on what is defined by the server developer? I'm happy to take a stab at this - will share a proposal.

> [@mconflitti-pbc](https://github.com/mconflitti-pbc) If I'm understanding correctly, you're looking for an autogenerated UI similar to an swagger/redoc UI that clearly lists the tools, prompts, and resources based on what is defined by the server developer? I'm happy to take a stab at this - will share a proposal.

Exactly! Could be neat to even provide a way to test out the various tools. That could be just a form submission or even a locally running LLM with tool support that uses webgpu to run the tool e2e.

OpenAPI docs are for developers to learn more about how to use the api. Since the main target for an MCP server is an LLM and the secondary target is for the person, it may make sense to just provide the various tool descriptions and examples of prompts that would trigger those tools.

If there was a way to define an html or md file that the MCP server code or fastmcp code can ingest and display. That could be a mechanism for the MCP developer to provide instructions on how to set up that particular MCP as well.

I could see these docs being served for both SSE and STDIO transports.
While SSE specifically is deprecated, this could be beneficial for Streamable HTTP.

issueDTO.title: Using /.well-known/ OAuth endpoints behind custom path on GKE
issueDTO.description:
### Question

I am running a simple MCP server (built with FastMCP) behind a gateway on GKE with an custom path defined by an HttpRoute. I am attempting to use the /.well-known/ endpoints for OAuth authentication and authorization. Unfortunately, it seems that the routes for the /.well-known/ endpoints; as well as the other OAuth endpoints /authorize, /token, /register, and /revoke, are all hardcoded in the MCP SDK within mcp/server/auth/routes.py within the create_auth_routes() function.

So, for example...

If my MCP server is deployed at https://{my-gateway}/custom/path/
However, the well-known endpoints are pointing to https://{my-gateway}/.well-known/*, which are obviously returning 404 Not Found responses.

When starting my server, I am passing the 'path' parameter in the mcp.run() command.  Using my example above, my run command would look like -- mcp.run(transport="http", host="0.0.0.0", port=8080, path="/custom/path/mcp").  However, this path parameter seems to have zero effect on the OAuth well-known endpoints.

So, the question is... Is this expected behavior, and if so, how should we run MCP servers that use well-knonw OAuth endpoints behind API Proxies (Apigee, APIM, etc) or GKE Gateways that require a custom path?

### Additional Context

mcp version  -- 1.13.1
fastmcp version -- 2.11.4.dev128+5b433f5
comments: ~I think it is related with this pull request: https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/python-sdk/pull/1288~

Thanks @shulkx for the pull request link.  However, the listed Expected Behavior in this pull request states: "The .well-known/oauth-protected-resource endpoint should always be served at the root path (/.well-known/oauth-protected-resource) regardless of the resource_server_url configuration".  That seems the exact opposite of what would be needed in use cases like mine where the MCP server must run at a custom path.  When attached to a GKE gateway (or Api proxy such as Apigee), serving the well-known endpoints from the root path is always going to return 404 responses.

Hi @whitewg77 - The root cause is because the well-known URL generated for WWW authenticated header (used to tell the client where the well-known endpoint is) and the real well-known route endpoint are mismatched.

For WWW authenticated header, the existing implementation appends the `.well-known/oauth-protected-resource` directly after the resource_server_url.

```
http://0.0.0.0:8000/custom/path/mcp/.well-known/oauth-protected-resource
```

For route endpoint generation, it append the `.well-known/oauth-protected-resource` directly after the root URL.

```
http://0.0.0.0:8000/.well-known/oauth-protected-resource
```

Therefore, if we have customized path, it will cause a mismatch between those two and lead to 404.


I have implemented a fix for this https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/python-sdk/pull/1407.

repository.description: The official Python SDK for Model Context Protocol servers and clients
repository.name: python-sdk

summary.attemptedFixes: A fix has been implemented in https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/python-sdk/pull/1407
summary.otherNotes: MCP server is running behind a gateway on GKE with a custom path defined by an HttpRoute. OAuth well-known endpoints are hardcoded in the MCP SDK. The path parameter in the mcp.run() command has no effect on the OAuth well-known endpoints.

issueDTO.title: Update _client_info on the ClientSession upon initialization with serverInfo
issueDTO.description:
### Description

Currently, when a ClientSession is created and no client_info arg is passed, it uses the default client info object. My expectation would be that upon session initialization, the clientinfo data is updated with the value returned from the MCP server it connected to. This information is available within the InitializationResult but not used by the SDK so the only way to get that info is to grab it during initialization manually.

Example of grabbing info like the name defined by the MCP server when the client connects:
```python
            transport = await self.exit_stack.enter_async_context(
                streamablehttp_client(server_url, headers=headers)
            )
            self.read, self.write, _ = transport
            self.session = await self.exit_stack.enter_async_context(
                ClientSession(self.read, self.write)
            )

            server = await self.session.initialize()
            self.name = server.serverInfo.name  # <====
```

ClientSession does the following:
```python
class ClientSession(
    BaseSession[
        types.ClientRequest,
        types.ClientNotification,
        types.ClientResult,
        types.ServerRequest,
        types.ServerNotification,
    ]
):
    def __init__(
        self,
        read_stream: MemoryObjectReceiveStream[SessionMessage | Exception],
        write_stream: MemoryObjectSendStream[SessionMessage],
        # ...
        client_info: types.Implementation | None = None,
    ) -> None:
        super().__init__(...)
        self._client_info = client_info or DEFAULT_CLIENT_INFO # <<<<<<
       # ...

    async def initialize(self) -> types.InitializeResult:
        # ...
        result = await self.send_request(
            types.ClientRequest(
                types.InitializeRequest(
                    method="initialize",
                    params=types.InitializeRequestParams(
                        protocolVersion=types.LATEST_PROTOCOL_VERSION,
                        capabilities=types.ClientCapabilities(
                            sampling=sampling,
                            experimental=None,
                            roots=roots,
                        ),
                        clientInfo=self._client_info,
                    ),
                )
            ),
            types.InitializeResult,
        )
        # ...
        return result
```

The result is returned but ClientSession._client_info is not updated with the values coming from the result. The simplest thing would just be to set _client_info to serverInfo.

### References

_No response_

repository.description: The official Python SDK for Model Context Protocol servers and clients
repository.name: python-sdk

summary.validationOrRequirement: The client_info arg should be updated with the value returned from the MCP server it connected to
summary.attemptedFixes: The simplest thing would just be to set _client_info to serverInfo
summary.otherNotes: The issue is about updating the _client_info on the ClientSession upon initialization with serverInfo. It's not being updated with the values coming from the result.

issueDTO.title: Suboptimal instruction sequence when operands are reordered
issueDTO.description:
```c
int foo(int t) {
    return t - (1 - 5 * t);
}

int bar(int t) {
    return t - 1 + 5 * t;
}

int baz(int t) {
    return t + 5 * t - 1;
}
```

$ riscv64-clang -O3

```asm
        .text
        .attribute      4, 16
        .attribute      5, "rv64i2p0_m2p0_a2p0_f2p0_d2p0_c2p0"
        .file   "example.c"
        .globl  foo                             # -- Begin function foo
        .p2align        1
        .type   foo,@function
foo:                                    # @foo
# %bb.0:
        slliw   a1, a0, 2
        addw    a1, a1, a0
        addw    a0, a0, a1
        addiw   a0, a0, -1
        ret
.Lfunc_end0:
        .size   foo, .Lfunc_end0-foo
                                        # -- End function
        .globl  bar                             # -- Begin function bar
        .p2align        1
        .type   bar,@function
bar:                                    # @bar
# %bb.0:
        slliw   a1, a0, 2
        addw    a1, a1, a0
        addw    a0, a0, a1
        addiw   a0, a0, -1
        ret
.Lfunc_end1:
        .size   bar, .Lfunc_end1-bar
                                        # -- End function
        .globl  baz                             # -- Begin function baz
        .p2align        1
        .type   baz,@function
baz:                                    # @baz
# %bb.0:
        li      a1, 6
        mulw    a0, a0, a1
        addiw   a0, a0, -1
        ret
.Lfunc_end2:
        .size   baz, .Lfunc_end2-baz
                                        # -- End function
        .ident  "clang version 16.0.0 (https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project.git 06c02d5dbb13f6d2a10eaa75c236f3c61cdf5b91)"
        .section        ".note.GNU-stack","",@progbits
        .addrsig
```

In the last case `mulw` is generated.

Aarch64 also has this issue

$ arm64-clang -O3


```asm
        .text
        .file   "example.c"
        .globl  foo                             // -- Begin function foo
        .p2align        2
        .type   foo,@function
foo:                                    // @foo
        .cfi_startproc
// %bb.0:
        add     w8, w0, w0, lsl #2
        add     w8, w8, w0
        sub     w0, w8, #1
        ret
.Lfunc_end0:
        .size   foo, .Lfunc_end0-foo
        .cfi_endproc
                                        // -- End function
        .globl  bar                             // -- Begin function bar
        .p2align        2
        .type   bar,@function
bar:                                    // @bar
        .cfi_startproc
// %bb.0:
        add     w8, w0, w0, lsl #2
        add     w8, w0, w8
        sub     w0, w8, #1
        ret
.Lfunc_end1:
        .size   bar, .Lfunc_end1-bar
        .cfi_endproc
                                        // -- End function
        .globl  baz                             // -- Begin function baz
        .p2align        2
        .type   baz,@function
baz:                                    // @baz
        .cfi_startproc
// %bb.0:
        mov     w8, #6
        mul     w8, w0, w8
        sub     w0, w8, #1
        ret
.Lfunc_end2:
        .size   baz, .Lfunc_end2-baz
        .cfi_endproc
                                        // -- End function
        .ident  "clang version 16.0.0 (https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project.git 06c02d5dbb13f6d2a10eaa75c236f3c61cdf5b91)"
        .section        ".note.GNU-stack","",@progbits
        .addrsig
```

In the last case `mul` is generated.

However, X86 generates the same instruction sequence for all three
```asm
        .text
        .intel_syntax noprefix
        .file   "example.c"
        .globl  foo                             # -- Begin function foo
        .p2align        4, 0x90
        .type   foo,@function
foo:                                    # @foo
        .cfi_startproc
# %bb.0:
                                        # kill: def $edi killed $edi def $rdi
        lea     eax, [rdi + 4*rdi]
        add     eax, edi
        dec     eax
        ret
.Lfunc_end0:
        .size   foo, .Lfunc_end0-foo
        .cfi_endproc
                                        # -- End function
        .globl  bar                             # -- Begin function bar
        .p2align        4, 0x90
        .type   bar,@function
bar:                                    # @bar
        .cfi_startproc
# %bb.0:
                                        # kill: def $edi killed $edi def $rdi
        lea     eax, [rdi + 4*rdi]
        add     eax, edi
        dec     eax
        ret
.Lfunc_end1:
        .size   bar, .Lfunc_end1-bar
        .cfi_endproc
                                        # -- End function
        .globl  baz                             # -- Begin function baz
        .p2align        4, 0x90
        .type   baz,@function
baz:                                    # @baz
        .cfi_startproc
# %bb.0:
                                        # kill: def $edi killed $edi def $rdi
        lea     eax, [rdi + 2*rdi]
        add     eax, eax
        dec     eax
        ret
.Lfunc_end2:
        .size   baz, .Lfunc_end2-baz
        .cfi_endproc
                                        # -- End function
        .ident  "clang version 16.0.0 (https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project.git 06c02d5dbb13f6d2a10eaa75c236f3c61cdf5b91)"
        .section        ".note.GNU-stack","",@progbits
        .addrsig
```
comments: @llvm/issue-subscribers-backend-risc-v
@llvm/issue-subscribers-backend-arm

The IR for @foo looks silly @rotateright 

```llvm
define dso_local i32 @foo(i32 noundef %0) local_unnamed_addr #0 {
  %2 = mul i32 %0, -5
  %3 = xor i32 %2, -1
  %4 = add i32 %3, %0
  ret i32 %4
}
```
The instructions are the same for X86 but the operands are not. The lea for baz uses `2*`. The others use `4*`

We do better with Zba. We manage a 2 instruction serial dependency for @baz

```asm
foo:                                    # @foo
        sh2add  a1, a0, a0
        add     a0, a0, a1
        addi    a0, a0, -1
        ret
bar:                                    # @bar
        sh2add  a1, a0, a0
        add     a0, a0, a1
        addi    a0, a0, -1
        ret
baz:                                    # @baz
        sh1add  a0, a0, a0
        li      a1, -1
        sh1add  a0, a0, a1
        ret
```

> The IR for @foo looks silly @rotateright
> 
> ```llvm
> define dso_local i32 @foo(i32 noundef %0) local_unnamed_addr #0 {
>   %2 = mul i32 %0, -5
>   %3 = xor i32 %2, -1
>   %4 = add i32 %3, %0
>   ret i32 %4
> }
> ```

Yeah, I didn't step through the transforms, but I think we want to reduce all of these to baz() form in IR since that's shortest:
https://alive2.llvm.org/ce/z/oZqFop

That means the backend needs more mul expansion smarts if we are trying to avoid the mul in asm.

> However, X86 generates the same instruction sequence for all three

This comment is not correct:

>         lea     eax, [rdi + 4*rdi]
>         add     eax, edi
...
>         lea     eax, [rdi + 4*rdi]
>         add     eax, edi
...
>         lea     eax, [rdi + 2*rdi]
>         add     eax, eax

In the baz() case, it decomposed as (3*x) + (3*x), but the others were 5*x + x. I don't think that makes a perf difference on any recent CPU, but it does show that we could do better at canonicalizing in codegen too?

> This comment is not correct:

Yeah, missed it. But w.r.t. performance all three will be similar while for Arm and Riscv there is difference.

> I don't think that makes a perf difference on any recent CPU, but it does show that we could do better at canonicalizing in codegen too?

agreed!
Fixes AArch64 part with https://reviews.llvm.org/D132322

On the IR side, we could generalize the factoring to patterns with no constants:
https://alive2.llvm.org/ce/z/mbsDdE
That's likely better in IR since it eliminates a use of 'x', but it's probably worse in codegen for most targets (especially if they have a 'madd' instruction).

> On the IR side, we could generalize the factoring to patterns with no constants: https://alive2.llvm.org/ce/z/mbsDdE That's likely better in IR since it eliminates a use of 'x', but it's probably worse in codegen for most targets (especially if they have a 'madd' instruction).

On 2nd thought, madd codegen looks fine either way (at least for aarch64):
```
src:
	add	w8, w0, w2
	madd	w0, w0, w1, w8
tgt:
	madd	w8, w0, w1, w0
	add	w0, w8, w2
```

The 'tgt' form with dependent ops might have a longer critical path without madd, but that should be invertible in codegen.

Proposal to improve canonicalization in IR:
https://reviews.llvm.org/D132412

> The IR for @foo looks silly @rotateright

That part should be fixed in IR at least with:
f7ab70cf8df6117312a

D132412 was initially going to change the bar() IR, but that patch ended up fixing another pattern, and we still miss bar().

It's still up to the backend to decompose the mul if that's better for the target.
This issue is still exist for the 2nd function **bar**, https://godbolt.org/z/vjree4xfY
Proposal to improve canonicalization in IR of **bar** , https://reviews.llvm.org/D136623

> Proposal to improve canonicalization in IR of **bar** , https://reviews.llvm.org/D136623

@vfdff It seems like the patch was abandoned? are you still planning to work on it?

issueDTO.title: Effect Author string discards all characters after "<"
issueDTO.description:
### System Information

Arch LInux, GNOME

### LMMS Version(s)

master

### Most Recent Working Version

_No response_

### Bug Summary

The email addresses of effect authors are not visible in the effect browser, despite them being specified in the code. But it's not just email addresses, anything you put after a "<" will not show up in the final string.

# Examples

## Amplifier
```cpp
Plugin::Descriptor PLUGIN_EXPORT amplifier_plugin_descriptor =
{
	LMMS_STRINGIFY(PLUGIN_NAME),
	"Amplifier",
	QT_TRANSLATE_NOOP("PluginBrowser", "A native amplifier plugin"),
	"Vesa Kivim??ki <contact/dot/diizy/at/nbl/dot/fi>",
	0x0100,
	Plugin::Type::Effect,
	new PluginPixmapLoader("logo"),
	nullptr,
	nullptr,
} ;
```

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d8da8a52-c41c-4c53-8f3d-e330a6cde946)

## Compressor
```cpp
Plugin::Descriptor PLUGIN_EXPORT compressor_plugin_descriptor =
{
	LMMS_STRINGIFY(PLUGIN_NAME),
	"Compressor",
	QT_TRANSLATE_NOOP("PluginBrowser", "A dynamic range compressor."),
	"Lost Robot <r94231@gmail.com>",
	0x0100,
	Plugin::Type::Effect,
	new PluginPixmapLoader("logo"),
	nullptr,
	nullptr,
} ;
```

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/571e66b9-a497-45ba-9ee5-b419d1817443)

## Random characters to test
```cpp
Plugin::Descriptor PLUGIN_EXPORT oscilloscope_plugin_descriptor =
{
	LMMS_STRINGIFY(PLUGIN_NAME),
	"Oscilloscope",
	QT_TRANSLATE_NOOP("PluginBrowser", "Oscilloscope plugin to display the incoming audio waveform"),
	"Keratina<yayfhs 89 :) Keratin <a35246@yay.com> hii",
	0x0100,
	Plugin::Type::Effect,
	new PluginPixmapLoader("logo"),
	nullptr,
	nullptr,
} ;
```

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/f23d911e-80d8-4014-915f-9cbda2446e61)


### Expected Behaviour

All characters in the author should be shown, including "<".

### Steps To Reproduce

Press "Add Effect" on the mixer, and search for a native LMMS effect, and compare the author string to the one provided in the code.

### Logs




### Screenshots / Minimum Reproducible Project

_No response_

### Please search the issue tracker for existing bug reports before submitting your own.

- [x] I have searched all existing issues and confirmed that this is not a duplicate.
comments:
OH I just realized why it's happening.

We use some kind of html-like language when creating the `EffectSelectDialog`, and `<`/`>` are special characters.

Also for some reason Andy Wingo's email address is only partially cut off. It doesn't occur in 1.2.2, neither (or maybe partially) in a recent appimage build I have.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d7ef0f4e-6a58-431f-b8b3-b3d3494fede0)
I think using [`QString::toHtmlEscaped`](https://doc.qt.io/qt-6/qstring.html#toHtmlEscaped) in `EffectSelectDialog::rowChanged` may help
Hi! I'll attempt to fix this issue

issueDTO.title: Export chat not exporting LLM costs incurred
issueDTO.description:
### What happened?

When I export a chat prompt and response the cost is not saved with the export.  This is a design flaw.  We need to be able to know the cost of each specific prompt and response pair to be able to analyze and control costs with this tool.  

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/f7a8eb94-3e5f-4545-ae71-370e9e2899d2)

As is, it is too expensive to use.  Costs must be monitored carefully.

### Steps to reproduce

1. run prompt.
2. get completion response.
3. export chat transcript and response.  


### Relevant API REQUEST output

```shell
CLINE_TESTING/exports.txt
CLINE_TESTING/aline-main-by-debug-dream.zip
Errors_to_fix/dataframe-misalignment-problem-in-chapter_07_RSL_WIP_Adj_Close_Problem.ipynb (output).txt
</environment_details>
```

### Operating System

Windows 10 Pro

### Cline Version

3.1.7

### Additional context

_No response_
comments: Hi, I'm a new contributor and would like to give this issue a try. Could you please assign it to me?

@cline-triage Please look into this issue. Is this still a real problem in the current version? We are many versions away from this particular build. I would like you to please carefully review their stated problem and look for similar github issues as well. Perhaps we already fixed this problem a in a previous update.  Really focus on determining root cause yourself by reviewing the code

Thank you for reporting this issue! 🙏

I've completed my analysis and this is a valid **enhancement request**. Here's what I found:

## Research Findings

**Root Cause:** The export functionality (located in `src/integrations/misc/export-markdown.ts`) currently only exports the conversation history as markdown. It does **not** include task metadata such as:
- Total API cost (`totalCost`)
- Token usage (`tokensIn`, `tokensOut`)
- Cache metrics (`cacheWrites`, `cacheReads`)

While this metadata is tracked and displayed in the UI (visible in `TaskHeader.tsx` and `HistoryView.tsx`), it's not passed to the export function.

## Triage Score: 72/100

| Criteria | Score | Notes |
|----------|-------|-------|
| Clarity & Reproducibility | 21/25 | Clear steps and expected behavior |
| Evidence | 8/25 | Screenshot provided, sufficient for an enhancement |
| Location Confidence | 20/20 | Code located and analyzed |
| Root Cause | 15/20 | Clear understanding of what's missing |
| Fix Feasibility | 8/10 | Straightforward implementation |

## Implementation Approach

The fix would involve:
1. Modifying the `downloadTask` function to accept task metadata (costs, tokens, cache metrics)
2. Adding a metadata header section to the exported markdown
3. Formatting the cost/token data in a readable format for tracking

This is indeed a valuable enhancement for cost monitoring and analysis. The fix is localized and shouldn't require breaking changes.

**Labels updated:**
- ??? Added: `enhancement`
- ??? Removed: `Investigation Needed`
- ??? Keeping: `Good First Issue` (straightforward implementation)

If you'd like to contribute this enhancement, I'd be happy to provide more specific implementation guidance! 😊

issueDTO.title: [ci]: Metrics comparison is flaky
issueDTO.description:
### What happened?

During CI we run a comparison of metrics emitted from binaries in e2e tests. Since most changes do not affect which metrics are emitted we expect 0 changes, but the comparison often fails on spurious differences, e.g. here https://github.com/jaegertracing/jaeger/pull/7616#issuecomment-3445133896

### Steps to reproduce

This is intermittent, but quite likely due to us using randomized namespaces in e2e tests and they are being included in the metric labels and flagged as differences.

### Expected behavior

No differences if no changes to metrics is done.

### Proposal

Analyze which labels are causing issues and substitute them to stable strings before running comparisons.
comments:
Hey @yurishkuro I was looking into this issue. Looking into various PRs current and previous ones where the difference in metrics is listed by the bot and found that the flaky ones are from this particular test run in all cases https://github.com/jaegertracing/jaeger/actions/runs/18818245243/job/53689725757 . Looking at the diffs listed with the `503` status code it could likely be that it's just service has not started but the metrics collection endpoints are being hit in some runs.

Thanks

> Hey [@yurishkuro](https://github.com/yurishkuro) I was looking into this issue. Looking into various PRs current and previous ones where the difference in metrics is listed by the bot and found that the flaky ones are from this particular test run in all cases https://github.com/jaegertracing/jaeger/actions/runs/18818245243/job/53689725757 . Looking at the diffs listed with the `503` status code it could likely be that it's just service has not started but the metrics collection endpoints are being hit in some runs. 
> 
> Thanks

@yurishkuro can you please have a look at this finding and suggest if this can be a cause of this flakiness in metrics report or not?

issueDTO.title: Give an indication in container events for probe failure as to whether the failure was ignored due to FailureThreshold
issueDTO.description:
Probes of all kinds currently support FailureThreshold (and SuccessThreshold), these properties allow a user to specify that Kubernetes should not take action in response to a failed probe unless it fails a successive number of times.

This is useful for  end-users as it allows them to mitigate the effects of any probes that "flake" by requiring successive failure.

When a probe fails in Kubernetes, we emit a container event indicating this here: https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/pkg/kubelet/prober/prober.go#L110 and end-users can consume these events via the API for their own purposes. This event is emitted regardless of whether the FailureThreshold has been reached or not.

Currently when a user consumes a probe failure event they have no way of knowing whether the event resulted in action on the control plane (because the event can be ignored due to FailureThreshold, and information on this is not included in the event). This can lead to users assuming there is a problem and a container/pod was restarted when nothing occurred.

I think we should expose the keepGoing value from https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/pkg/kubelet/prober/worker.go#L203 in the emitted event somehow, my preferred solution is to emit the probe failure event in the worker rather than where it currently sits in https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/pkg/kubelet/prober/prober.go#L110 - there is also the option of passing some information down the stack into the prober from the worker (such as making the FailureThreshold/SuccessThreshold decision in the prober) but I'm worried about separation of concerns, happy to hear what other folks think :)

Also of note is that FailureThreshold/SuccessThreshold is the only filter I can see where a probe can be ignored after being run (and therefore emitting a container event)

I???m happy to write this PR once we???re confident in our approach :)

issueDTO.title: Create WebSocket server trough WebSocket plugin
issueDTO.description:
Hello 👋🏻 

I have checked the documentation and seems like the WebSocket plugin can only be used to implement a client. I would like to ask if it can have the ability to create a server instance as well without depending on external dependencies that could have a side effect.

The reasoning behind needing a server is to allow external apps to have a communication way between Tauri FE and client. This range is not restricted to only other apps, it creates the possibility to communicate with any type of browser extensions and also websites that opens in a browser or even a small IOT device that can use a WebSocket client through the same network. The reasoning is limitless at this point.

Additionally:
For browser extensions, it is also possible to use [Native Messaging](https://developer.chrome.com/docs/extensions/develop/concepts/native-messaging) concept, but that it not too clear and isn't open as WebSocket protocol.

+1 for this

issueDTO.title: Improve the `ERR_AMBIGUOUS_MODULE_SYNTAX` error message
issueDTO.description:
```js
module.exports;

await 1;
```

The above code snippet causes an `ERR_AMBIGUOUS_MODULE_SYNTAX` error, since `module.exports` cannot be used (CJS) in an ESM file. However, the error logged to the console, shown below, incorrectly assumes the error stems from the use of a `require()`

```
ReferenceError: Cannot determine intended module format because both require() and top-level await are present. If the code is intended to be CommonJS, wrap await in an async function. If the code is intended to be an ES module, replace require() with import.
```
comments:
A more fitting error would be
```
ReferenceError: Cannot determine intended module format because both CommonJS and ES module syntax are present
```

> A more fitting error would be
> 
> ```
> ReferenceError: Cannot determine intended module format because both CommonJS and ES module syntax are present
> ```

There's no such thing as "CJS syntax", it's just JavaScript ??? in this case, if the file cannot be loaded as ESM is not a syntax problem, but the use of an undeclared identifier that does not map to a global.
The current message is more more correct ??? except that it mentions `require()` instead of `module`.

I agree with @aduh95 - the proposed version wasn't correct either. The correction should probably be something like

> ReferenceError: Cannot determine intended module format because both a global reference to `module` and top-level `await` are present. If the code is intended to be CommonJS, wrap await in an async function. If the code is intended to be an ES module, do not use an undefined global reference to `module`.

(i.e. changing `require()` to `module`, or if it's `exports`, `__filename__` etc., adjust accordingly).

Marking it as a first good issue, I think it can be fixed by updating

https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/c742220be9c456485f26fdc4adc458dd97de3326/lib/internal/modules/esm/module_job.js#L78-L85

And replace `require()` in the message with what gets detected by `isCommonJSGlobalLikeNotDefinedError()` as the undefined global. Also, the last instruction should change depending on exactly what undefined global is referenced. `require`/`__filename__`/`__dirname__` may have alternatives in ESM, but `module.exports`/`exports` don't necessarily (only writes to them have equivalents, reads to them do not)

I noticed this issue. Have you tried checking the error logs or console output? That might help narrow down the root cause. I'd be happy to help investigate if you can share more details about your environment (OS, version, etc.).

I'd like to work on this issue. I'll update the error message in `lib/internal/modules/esm/module_job.js` to reference the actual undefined global as suggested.

--

I've opened PR. The changes include:
- Updated error messages to reference the actual undefined global (require, module, exports, __filename, __dirname)
- Added context-specific migration advice for each type of global
- Added test coverage for the new error messages
can you assign it to me

repository.description: Node.js JavaScript runtime ???🐢🚀???
repository.name: node

summary.attemptedFixes: The author has opened a PR with changes to update the error messages to reference the actual undefined global, add context-specific migration advice for each type of global, and add test coverage for the new error messages.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is about improving the error message for `ERR_AMBIGUOUS_MODULE_SYNTAX` error, which is caused by using `module.exports` in an ESM file. The current error message incorrectly assumes the error stems from the use of `require()`. The proposed solution is to update the error message to reference the actual undefined global.

issueDTO.title: Internationalization (i18n) / Multi-language Support
issueDTO.description:
Hello Probo Team,

I propose adding Internationalization (i18n) support to Probo. This feature would significantly increase the global reach and adoption of the platform, especially among non-English-speaking startups interested in achieving security compliance.

Value Proposition
Global Compliance Adoption: Standards like GDPR, ISO 27001, and SOC 2 are relevant worldwide. Localizing the Probo interface and general documentation would make the process far more accessible to global teams.

User Experience: A localized interface minimizes ambiguity and reduces the cognitive load for compliance managers, leading to higher accuracy and adoption rates.

Key Consideration: Framework-Specific Localization
It is important to consider that while the UI/App experience should be localizable (e.g., in Spanish for a user in Mexico), the content of specific compliance frameworks might need to remain in a required language for external auditing.

For example, a user may wish to manage their ISO 27001 documentation in Spanish, but their SOC 2 Type II report and underlying artifacts might still need to be generated or maintained in English because most specialized auditors require it.

Therefore, the ideal i18n solution would allow:

UI Language: Set per-user or globally (e.g., Spanish).

Framework/Content Language: Set per-framework (e.g., ISO 27001 in Spanish, SOC 2 in English).

My Contribution
I am willing to contribute the initial Spanish localization files for the UI and work on translating key elements once an i18n framework has been implemented.

Could the team please evaluate the feasibility of integrating i18n with this distinction in mind?
comments: Ok I've taken a look at [CONTRIBUTING.md](https://github.com/getprobo/probo/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md) file and now I have an idea how to proceed with it, I got [my fork](https://github.com/iecoding/probo) and let's see what's comming next.

Having translations available on the platform would be fantastic! We haven???t explored how the translation framework would fit into everything yet, but at least on the frontend, we already have a mock setup that supports gettext and UI translations: https://github.com/getprobo/probo/tree/main/packages/i18n

If there???s any way we can help bring this feature to the platform, just let us know!

It suggests considering framework-specific localization and proposes a solution that allows setting UI language and framework/content language separately.

issueDTO.title: Implement OAuth relying on Authlib
issueDTO.description:
### Description

Hello, 
I would like to validate here before I start the implementation that we want to use Authlib as a Oauth implementation to support more use case in the future and reduce the cost of maintenance of the Oauth stack.
Please can maintainers comment so I don't initiate a long work for nothing.

Thanks a lot !

cc @Kludex @ochafik

### References

_No response_
comments:
Hi @yannj-fr, thanks for checking in and offering your help!

Reducing maintenance cost sounds like a great objective indeed!

I'm not familiar w/ Authlib (not sure I understand their licensing model, looks like it takes a [commercial license](https://authlib.org/plans?utm_source=docs) to get on their security mailing list). At what level were you thinking of integrating it?

The pattern used in https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/python-sdk/pull/882 (extending httpx.Auth) could potentially be used, even outside the SDK itself. Whether things make it into the SDK might instead be a question for the protocol itself / e.g. [this SEP](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/modelcontextprotocol/issues/1046) suggests adding client credentials

Discussed with the maintainers there:
The license is open source for everyone, there is a possibility to gain support through commercial license.
They provide a httpx implementation here https://docs.authlib.org/en/latest/client/httpx.html

My idea is to contribute to authlib for all rfc we need so we have minimum support to do here

I proposed it on Discord, so... I'm happy.

The license is [BSD-3-Clause](https://github.com/authlib/authlib/blob/main/LICENSE), the same as Starlette.

I'm onboard with this. My one wish would be to do it in a way that's pluggable, so if someone does not want to use authlib, they can swap in something else.

the httpx approach seems like a good hook to make this generic.

For example, if we are prototyping around an RFC not supported in authlib, I'd like to be able to easily swap in an implementation rather than have to patch authlib and cross-link etc.

I suggest we modernize and modularize the OAuthProvider implementation with the following goals in mind:

Composable workflow: Design the provider to expose a simple, override-friendly flow. This allows contributors and integrators to easily test or swap in custom behavior without duplicating the whole logic.

Leverage Authlib: Instead of implementing OAuth/OIDC specs manually, we should rely on authlib to handle protocol compliance. This reduces maintenance burden and ensures adherence to standards, unless we're handling custom flow control.

Configurable flows: Structure parameterization so that each officially supported OAuth flow (e.g., Authorization Code, Client Credentials, etc.) can be easily configured via clean, declarative settings.

Extensibility: Leave room for additional/custom parameters in the configuration. This makes it easier to extend or override specific parts of the provider logic while keeping the configuration accessible and consistent.
That all sounds great to me

issueDTO.title: Specifying capabilities w/ FastMCP Server
issueDTO.description:
### Question

I noticed that the FastMCP server does not have the options to manually specify the capabilities of the server, however it is possible to do so with the low-level server. 

My current workaround to advertise the capabilities is like so:

```py
mcp = FastMCP("test-server")

# Manually set notification options
lowlevel_server: Server = mcp._mcp_server
lowlevel_server.notification_options.resources_changed = True
lowlevel_server.notification_options.tools_changed = True

# Now, we override the mcp.run()
async def main():
    async with stdio_server() as (r, w):
        init_opts = lowlevel_server.create_initialization_options(
            lowlevel_server.notification_options,
            {}
        )
        await lowlevel_server.run(r, w, init_opts)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    anyio.run(main)
```

Is there any other way to specify the capabilities of the FastMCP server? Is there a reason not to?

Thanks!

### Additional Context

_No response_
comments: This is fair and we might want to add some sane defaults versions of these methods - currently FastMCP doesn't have these.

issueDTO.title: MCP server: AccessToken class should have field for subject claim ("sub")
issueDTO.description:
### Description

I'm proposing to add `subject` to `AccessToken` in `mcp/server/auth/provider.py`, which can be used to store the `sub` JWT claim that usually corresponds to the user ID:
```
class AccessToken(BaseModel):
    token: str
    client_id: str
    scopes: list[str]
    expires_at: int | None = None
    resource: str | None = None  # RFC 8707 resource indicator

    # Proposed:
    subject: str | None = None  # Subject (user ID)
```

Then we can implement a token verifier as follows:

```
class MyTokenVerifier:
    async def verify_token(self, token: str) -> AccessToken | None:
        try:
            token_claims = decode_and_validate_jwt(token)
        except ...:
            return None

        return AccessToken(
            token=token,
            ...
            subject=token_claims["sub"],
        )
```

and directly retrieve the user ID from the auth token in the context:

```
from mcp.server.auth.middleware.auth_context import get_access_token

user_id = get_access_token().subject
```

### References

_No response_
comments:
Exactly! I want the same. 

I would only add that the subject should also be injected in the Context class, then the higher level APIs can easily access the user id.
But why not adding all claims? The JWT specification (RFC 7519) defines only a small set of reserved claim so in the end is very normal that companies add custom claims.

This has an initial attempted implementation by @robertofalk https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/python-sdk/pull/1165 but has been closed for inactivity - new PRs welcome if this is still an issue to the folks here.

issueDTO.title: Context.log does not actually accept or pass forward extra kwargs
issueDTO.description:
The utility methods on Context for logging all document `**extra` as being passed forward to the logger. However, `Context.log` does not actually allow any additional kwargs to be passed. This results in errors such as 

```
Context.log() got an unexpected keyword argument 
```
 
**To Reproduce**
Any usage of the context methods with extra kwargs will produce the error, for example

```python
await context.info(
    "request finished",
    channel_id=channel_id,
    status=response.get("ok"),
)
```

**Expected behavior**
The `Context.log` method is documented with 
```
Args:
  level: Log level (debug, info, warning, error)
  message: Log message
  logger_name: Optional logger name
  **extra: Additional structured data to include
```

This (and the helper methods) should either be documented as _not_ supporting additional structured data _or_ the log message `data` needs to be structured, for example, something like this 

```python 
    async def log(
        self,
        level: Literal["debug", "info", "warning", "error"],
        message: str,
        *,
        logger_name: str | None = None,
        **extra: Any
    ) -> None:
        """Send a log message to the client.

        Args:
            level: Log level (debug, info, warning, error)
            message: Log message
            logger_name: Optional logger name
            **extra: Additional structured data to include
        """
        log_data = {
           "message": message, **extra
        }
        await self.request_context.session.send_log_message(
            level=level, data=log_data, logger=logger_name
        )
```
comments: Hi @LucasRoesler is this still an issue for you?
@felixweinberger yes, it is still a problem. It seems that either the log methods should accept additional structure data or the common log method needs to accept and handle the additional kwargs

issueDTO.title: Support low-level interface for modifying the underlying Uvicorn server
issueDTO.description:
It would be great to have an API to interact with the MCP's underlying Uvicorn server.


More specifically, It would be great to have a leaky interface, that can act as a bridge with the abstraction of the underlying Uvicorn server, a way to configure it, or maybe just allowing us to pass arguments/kwargs to the Uvicorn server.

## Problem

As a start, there is no clean way to close a Uvicorn server programmatically/gracefully, there are some hacks to go around it, here are some related issues: 

**Uvicorn cannot be shutdown programmatically** - https://github.com/encode/uvicorn/discussions/1103 
**Uvicorn cannot be shutdown programmatically** - https://github.com/encode/uvicorn/issues/742
**Running multiple Uvicorn servers simultaneously hangs on shutdown** - https://github.com/encode/uvicorn/issues/1773
**Uvicorn eats SIGINTs, does not propagate exceptions** - https://github.com/encode/uvicorn/issues/1579

And so on.... 


## Idea

You might say that, we already have access to the server and low-level API with

```python
from mcp.server.lowlevel.server import Server
```

However just to handle a graceful shutdown, not being able to handle all the out-of-box features that  `FastMCP` class provides, feels like re-inventing the wheel.


So one of the easiest way(s) to do it is, passing the `timeout_graceful_shutdown=0` to the `uvicorn.Config` which solves the (partially) hanging server problem. 


Uvicorn is configurable via environment variables, when they are prefixed with [`UVICORN_`](https://www.uvicorn.org/settings/#settings), so in a similar way, when we pass values to:

```python
FastMCP(
    "some_server",
    lifespan=app_lifespan,
    debug=True, # no prefix, for the Settings class
    uvicorn_timeout_graceful_shutdown=0, # uvicorn prefix, for UvicornConfig?
)
```

We can buffer this, similar to `**settings` then we can pass to the initialization of the server, would it be feasible? 

I'm sure there will be other use cases for this, also I'm not sure if the example above is the best way to handle that,  just to give you a brief idea.
comments:
All the issues you pointed out were solved in Uvicorn's side, that's why they are all closed.

The `UVICORN_` env var can only be passed if uvicorn is called via CLI, since it leverages click entrypoint.

As per the issue itself, I think it makes sense to provide some kind of way to interact with uvicorn, but I believe the real issue is that FastMCP is not an ASGI application. I believe it's not because MCP specified 2 transports: `stdio` and `sse` - which I also believe it was not the best decision, given that it mixes too very different _ways_ of doing things.

It's nice to see you Marce!

Yes, I'm aware that we can't use ENV vars with `UVICORN_` prefix with MCP, otherwise I wouldn't have requested this feature :)

You're probably right about the core problem though, but both `SseServerTransport` and `stdio_server` are leaked abstractions, so I can't really complain about them combining in the `FastMCP` class implementation for a simplified high-level API.

In my case, I'd just love to keep the being able to use the high-level `FastMCP` interface and not having to rewrite boilerplate code again and be able to modify `uvicorn.Config`.

issueDTO.title: Improving how function docstring gets converted to tool's jsonschema for FastMCP
issueDTO.description:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Tool descriptions are not parsed as expected from the function docstring when using FastMCP. This affects tool calling performance.

Currently, FastMCP does some function inspection to create the docstring here: 
- https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/python-sdk/blob/775f87981300660ee957b63c2a14b448ab9c3675/src/mcp/server/fastmcp/tools/base.py#L55-L59
- https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/python-sdk/blob/775f87981300660ee957b63c2a14b448ab9c3675/src/mcp/server/fastmcp/utilities/func_metadata.py#L105-L174

From my understanding, it creates a FuncMetadata model in pydantic which then gets converted to jsonschema.

**Current behaviour:**
If we have a tool such as:
```
def add_numbers(a: float, b: float) -> float:
    """
    Adds two numbers and returns the result.

    Args:
        a (float): The first number.
        b (float): The second number.

    Returns:
        float: The sum of a and b.
    """
    return a + b
```

it gets parsed into:
```
>>> func_arg_metadata = func_metadata(add_numbers)
>>> parameters = func_arg_metadata.arg_model.model_json_schema()
>>> parameters
{'properties': {'a': {'title': 'A', 'type': 'number'}, 'b': {'title': 'B', 'type': 'number'}}, 'required': ['a', 'b'], 'title': 'add_numbersArguments', 'type': 'object'}

>>> add_numbers.__doc__  
'\nAdds two numbers and returns the result.\n\nArgs:\n    a (float): The first number.\n    b (float): The second number.\n\nReturns:\n    float: The sum of a and b.\n'
```

**Describe the solution you'd like**
It'd be nicer to follow one of the python docstring styles and parse out the argument descriptions from the docstring. 
```
{
  "name": "add_numbers",
  "description": "Adds two numbers and returns the sum.",
  "parameters": {
    "type": "object",
    "properties": {
      "a": {
        "type": "number",
        "description": "The first number to add."
      },
      "b": {
        "type": "number",
        "description": "The second number to add."
      }
    },
    "required": ["a", "b"]
  }
}
```

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
we used to do this in a previous python version of goose: https://github.com/block/goose/blob/eccb1b22614f39b751db4e5efd73d728d9ca40fc/packages/exchange/src/exchange/utils.py#L82-L107

here are some test examples: https://github.com/block/goose/blob/eccb1b22614f39b751db4e5efd73d728d9ca40fc/packages/exchange/tests/test_utils.py#L32-L136

**Additional context**
I am happy to add this in - wanted to post this first to check that you're okay with enforcing a docstring style (`"google", "numpy", "sphinx"`)  & adding `griffe` as a dependency.
comments:
+1, ran into this issue while making client/server just now. I'm happy to provide a PR updating our examples to use properly formatted docstrings if this gets merged.

Oh, and I'm team Sphinx :)

It should infer the docstring format. PR welcome.

Implementation can be copied from pydantic AI.

Hi @Kludex, thanks for the reply, I'd love to make a PR. Would you prefer me:

1. Update func_metadata to fit the JSONSchema for tool calling?
2. Make a utility function to convert the existing func_metadata model into to the tool calling JSONSchema?
3. Another approach?
Have there been any updates on this topic? Although we can add the parameter's description in the tools' description, it would be better to give AIs the accurate hint for each parameter.

issueDTO.title: support logging to stderr in Jupyter Notebook Environments.
issueDTO.description:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
I want to make mcp python-sdk jupyter notebook compatible. When running in a notebook environment, MCP work but do not output stderr as it does normally.

For instance in jupyter notebook:

```python
import mcp
import os
from mcp.client.stdio import stdio_client

serverparams = mcp.StdioServerParameters(
    command="uv",
    args=["--quiet", "run", "../src/echo.py"],
    env={"UV_PYTHON": "3.12", **os.environ},
)

async with stdio_client(serverparams) as (read, write):
    async with mcp.ClientSession(read, write) as session:
        await session.initialize()
        tools = await session.list_tools()
        print(tools)
```
Outputs:
```
meta=None nextCursor=None tools=[Tool(name='echo_tool', description='Echo the input text\n\n    Args:\n        text (str): The text to echo\n\n    Returns:\n        str: The echoed text\n    ', inputSchema={'properties': {'text': {'title': 'Text', 'type': 'string'}}, 'required': ['text'], 'title': 'echo_toolArguments', 'type': 'object'})]
```

while running the server without jupyter notebook:

```bash
??? uv run --quiet src/echo.py
starting echo server
```

stderr is correctly displayed.

This is a big problem mostly because if the server is crashing or the command is wrong you have no way to know what's wrong: nothing is logged and the jupyter notebook cell just hangs.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
I found the culprit being the use of:

```python 
process = await anyio.open_process(
        [server.command, *server.args],
        env=server.env if server.env is not None else get_default_environment(),
        stderr=sys.stderr,
 )
```
In particular sys.stderr here is not working in the jupyter / ipython context. Instead I would suggest a working change as follow:

1. remove the stderr params from the process and handle process.stderr in an async function as stdout / stdin is handled.
2. to that effect, use a `stderr_reader` async function  like the following:

```python
    async def stderr_reader():
        assert process.stderr, "Opened process is missing stderr"
        try:
            async for line in process.stderr:
                if is_jupyter_notebook():
                    print(f"\033[91m {line.decode().strip()}")
                else:
                    # redirect to stderr as before
                    print(line.decode().strip(), file=sys.stderr)
        except anyio.ClosedResourceError:
            await anyio.lowlevel.checkpoint()
```

This would result in the same behavior as before while allowing the stderr to be logged in the jupyter notebook context.

**Additional context**
Jupyter notebook support support is also requested for mcpadapt which bring MCP server tools in any agentic framework, as many agentic framework demonstrate usage in jupyter notebooks.
https://github.com/grll/mcpadapt
comments: @dsp-ant if that sounds reasonable to you happy to put together a PR

actually another simpler solution is also just to explicitly set stderr to None:

```python
process = await anyio.open_process(
        [server.command, *server.args],
        env=server.env if server.env is not None else get_default_environment(),
        stderr=None,
 )
```

@grll Thanks for reporting this. I am curious as to 'why' jupyter notebooks have problems with capturing sys.stderr? I am open for fixes assuming they are not breaking backwards compatibility.

Notable, jupyter integration should probably rely on [Logging](https://spec.modelcontextprotocol.io/specification/2024-11-05/server/utilities/logging/) to correctly capture and display logs. Now sadly, no server actually correctly implements this and we likely need better integration with standard logging facilities in Python.

issueDTO.title: Context logging function types are not spec compliant
issueDTO.description:
**Describe the bug**

According to the MCP spec, the data that may be logged can be of any type.


```js
    /**
     * The data to be logged, such as a string message or an object. Any JSON serializable type is allowed here.
     */
    data: unknown;
```

[MCP Schema](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/specification/blob/main/schema/2025-03-26/schema.ts#L833C1-L836C19)

You can even see an example [here](https://spec.modelcontextprotocol.io/specification/2025-03-26/server/utilities/logging/#log-message-notifications).

However, `ctx.info` and friends have message typed as `str`:

```python
async def info(self, message: str, **extra: Any) -> None:
```

Even so, the underlying `ServerSession.send_log_message` does indicate that data is `Any` type:

```python
    async def send_log_message(
        self, level: types.LoggingLevel, data: Any, logger: str | None = None
    ) -> None:
```

And so does `LoggingMessageNotificationParams`:

```python
    data: Any
    """
    The data to be logged, such as a string message or an object. Any JSON serializable
    type is allowed here.
    """
```

Also, it is unclear what the `extra` parameters should be for.

**To Reproduce**
Just look at the source file:

https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/python-sdk/blob/main/src/mcp/server/fastmcp/server.py#L703

**Expected behavior**
This library should follow the spec and allow any JSON serializable type to be logged.

For example, this should work without giving a type error:

```python
ctx.info({"test": "Hello World!"})
```

MCP servers can use logging to send rich notifications back to the client.

**Screenshots**
If applicable, add screenshots to help explain your problem.

**Additional context**

`mcp 1.4.1`
comments: Do you mind taking a stab at it and sending a PR

Hey @dsp-ant, 
can I contribute to this issue?


Plan on contributing to `mcp` in the future as well.
This `good first issue` will help me start capture a good understanding of the repo
@AshwanthramKL Just signed on to do it but saw your PR. Awesome - thank you for contributing! 👍
is this issue still up?

> is this issue still up?

yes. The pull request has not been merged yet. #400

> Also, it is unclear what the `extra` parameters should be for.

The built-in Python logger takes an `extra` parameter, "which can be used to pass a dictionary which is used to populate the `__dict__` of the `LogRecord` created for the logging event with user-defined attributes" (link to docs [here](https://docs.python.org/3/library/logging.html#logging.Logger.debug)). While the Python logger doesn't have built-in support for JSON, many logging libraries like AWS Powertools and `loguru` do, and they add the `**extra` kwargs to the output JSON log. For example `logger.debug("My log message.", foo="FOO")` is written as `{"message": "My log message.", "foo": "FOO"}`. 

I'm not sure if it's within the scope of this Issue, but as the `modelcontextprotocol` code currently stands, `Context.debug` and friends pass the `**kwargs` through to `Context.log`, which doesn't take a `**kwargs`. Calling `Context.debug("My log message, foo="FOO")` results in a `TypeError: Context.log got an unexpected keyword argument 'foo'`. The PR above, https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/python-sdk/pull/400, does not fix this bug and anyway it looks like a bot closed the issue without merging. 😿 

I can see several ways to fix the bug.

1. Add `**kwargs` to the `log` method and, if any `**kwargs` are passed in, make the entire log message a single JSON object.

```python
class Context:
    async def log(
        self,
        level: Literal["debug", "info", "warning", "error"],
        message: str,
        *,
        logger_name: str | None = None,
        **kwargs: Any
    ) -> None:
            await self.request_context.session.send_log_message(
                level=level,
                data={"message": message, **kwargs} if kwargs else message,
                logger=logger_name,
                related_request_id=self.request_id,
        )
```

2. Remove the `**kwargs` from the logging helper methods and change `message: str` to `message: Any` as in https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/python-sdk/pull/400 .
Hi @alejandro5042 checking in here whether this issue is still relevant? Checking as it's been a while since this issue has been opekn

summary.validationOrRequirement: The data to be logged should be of any type, as specified in the MCP spec
summary.attemptedFixes: There are two ways to fix the bug: 1. Add **kwargs to the log method and make the entire log message a single JSON object, 2. Remove the **kwargs from the logging helper methods and change message: str to message: Any
summary.otherNotes: The issue is unclear about the extra parameters and the built-in Python logger's extra parameter is used to pass a dictionary which is used to populate the __dict__ of the LogRecord created for the logging event with user-defined attributes

issueDTO.title: C++20 todos
issueDTO.description:
A list of improvements that get unlocked once Sorbet is on C++20 (#8466)

- [ ] Use default member initializers for bit-fields, e.g.

    https://github.com/sorbet/sorbet/blob/733e34a0ef15e93c4e87b3fd9f2e9d043d519881/ast/Trees.h#L820-L821

- [ ] Weaken `std::reinterpret_cast`s to `std::bit_cast` where possible, e.g.

    https://github.com/sorbet/sorbet/blob/733e34a0ef15e93c4e87b3fd9f2e9d043d519881/core/Symbols.h#L96-L97

- [ ] Replace `std::remove_if`+`std::vector::erase` with just `std::erase_if` e.g.

issueDTO.title: Throttle logger should periodically report dropped log count
issueDTO.description:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe

Currently, when the [throttle logger](https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/blob/7c99b710aa8c32dac31027a1953f0e058b8c44e5/lib/logger/throttler.go#L56) is used, logs may be silently dropped to avoid flooding. However, this can mislead users who rely on logs for debugging or operational insight. They might assume the log output represents the full picture when it's not true. 

Related to https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/issues/9447

### Describe the solution you'd like

To improve transparency, the throttle logger should periodically emit a message indicating how many log entries were dropped. This provides a hint to users that they might not be seeing the full log stream and helps them make better-informed decisions during troubleshooting.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

_No response_

### Additional information

_No response_
comments:
>To improve transparency, the throttle logger should periodically emit a message indicating how many log entries were dropped.

I'm not sure about the extra log message, it could be hard for users to connect it with the logs that were/were not throttled.
How about attaching the throttled log count to the original printed log message? For example:
>victoriametrics  | 2025-07-15T18:58:10.950Z     warn    VictoriaMetrics/lib/protoparser/opentelemetry/stream/streamparser.go:94 unsupported delta temporality for xxx: skipping it. **Simialr %d logs have been throttled in the last 5 seconds.**

> How about attaching the throttled log count to the original printed log message? For example:

The issue with this approach is that there could be many distinct original log messages. Should we attach `Similar %d xxx` to all of them, or one picked at random? Also, this could make it harder to query or filter logs consistently, since log patterns might differ from time to time (because of `Similar %d xxx` part attached).


I think it should be a separate message or event. It???s not ideal, it could still be overlooked, but it???s better than nothing. A careful log investigator would notice it and get the hint.

>The issue with this approach is that there could be many distinct original log messages. Should we attach Similar %d xxx to all of them, or one picked at random? 

It depends on which log message wins the "fight" in log throttler. Since the initial idea of log throttler was to skipping similar logs, so either one is fine.

>I think it should be a separate message or event. It???s not ideal, it could still be overlooked, but it???s better than nothing. A careful log investigator would notice it and get the hint.

I think the separate log messages are hard to be connected/noticed by users. For example, we exposes logs like:
```
victoriametrics | 2025-07-15T18:58:10.950Z warn VictoriaMetrics/lib/protoparser/opentelemetry/stream/streamparser.go:94 unsupported delta temporality for xxx: skipping it.

victoriametrics | 2025-07-15T18:58:10.950Z warn VictoriaMetrics/xxxx otlp_skipped_sample: suppressed %d log messages during the last 1m.
```
It's likely users won't know the connection between the `otlp_skipped_sample` log throttler and the `unsupported delta temporality` message, unless they check the code.

The good thing about attaching `Similar %d xxx` is that it???s easy to be noticed. As I understand, the current biggest issue is that users may not realize their logs have been throttled.

After reviewing the discussion between @makasim and @haleygo, I agree that there are two possible approaches to improving log transparency.

Add a separate periodic message
For example:

suppressed 120 log messages similar to "unsupported delta temporality for xxx" during the last 1m.


Pros:

Keeps the original log message consistent and unchanged.

Easier to search, parse, and filter programmatically.

Cons:

It might be harder for users to immediately connect which original log the suppressed count refers to.

This approach seems cleaner and less disruptive to existing log processing pipelines, even if it sacrifices a bit of direct visibility.

> > The issue with this approach is that there could be many distinct original log messages. Should we attach Similar %d xxx to all of them, or one picked at random?
> 
> It depends on which log message wins the "fight" in log throttler. Since the initial idea of log throttler was to skipping similar logs, so either one is fine.
> 
> > I think it should be a separate message or event. It???s not ideal, it could still be overlooked, but it???s better than nothing. A careful log investigator would notice it and get the hint.
> 
> I think the separate log messages are hard to be connected/noticed by users. For example, we exposes logs like:
> 
> ```
> victoriametrics | 2025-07-15T18:58:10.950Z warn VictoriaMetrics/lib/protoparser/opentelemetry/stream/streamparser.go:94 unsupported delta temporality for xxx: skipping it.
> 
> victoriametrics | 2025-07-15T18:58:10.950Z warn VictoriaMetrics/xxxx otlp_skipped_sample: suppressed %d log messages during the last 1m.
> ```
> 
> It's likely users won't know the connection between the `otlp_skipped_sample` log throttler and the `unsupported delta temporality` message, unless they check the code.
> 
> The good thing about attaching `Similar %d xxx` is that it???s easy to be noticed. As I understand, the current biggest issue is that users may not realize their logs have been throttled.

Can  We continuously receive log events (maybe in batches from a component), and we maintain a live count of throttled/skipped logs for that batch. When the batch finishes, we emit a separate summary log for that batch
shall i implement this ?

> The good thing about attaching Similar %d xxx is that it???s easy to be noticed. As I understand, the current biggest issue is that users may not realize their logs have been throttled.

I doubt it would be easier to notice since only one of many messages would include the `Similar %d xxx` suffix (if we throttle, then there are many similar-looking messages in logs). Even if someone comes across that specific message, they???d have to read the entire line carefully to spot the suffix. When skimming through logs, it???s easy to overlook it.

> It's likely users won't know the connection between the otlp_skipped_sample log throttler and the unsupported delta temporality message, unless they check the code.

This part is valid. Without the source code, it would be hard to connect the dots. It could be improved IMO. Instead of printing `otlp_skipped_sample`, it can print a part of the original message being throttled.

I realized that nothing stops a developer from using the throttle logger with different kinds of messages. I don't know if this is the case; I've not checked the code. Should be considered.

I???ve reviewed the throttle implementation. It works differently than I thought. In practice, we emit one message per throttle `name` for each `throttle` time interval. Given that, @Haleygo  approach makes perfect sense: we can append a suffix to the message that???s passed through, indicating how many were dropped.

Let???s proceed with @Haleygo`s approach.

The PR https://github.com/VictoriaMetrics/VictoriaMetrics/pull/9752 has been merged. Now the logged message would contain additional information on how many similar messages have been throttled. It should simplify debugging. The change will be available in next release

issueDTO.title: Replace git2::Exception with Result
comments: If I understand correctly, this is to replace `git2::Exception` with a `Result` type defined in `Rustify/Result.hpp` right?
Yes, correct
Can???t we just return Result from git2 and propagate it via Try?

getAuthor is not our interest in this issue. We???d like to modify git2 to use/return result, and all use of git2 will need to handle the returned result from git2 appropriately. In theory, we can make almost all functions in gut2 noexcept as a good side effect.

@ken-matsui Hello! How do you choose a return type for function? I mean when to return raw value or return a value wrapped in result? For example: should all public methods for classes return result or there is some other logic?
Hey @bekard, I think any function that calls `git2Throw` wants to return a value wrapped by `Result`. For constructors, static factory functions might be suitable.
why not use std::expected instead of Result? I think they are the same.

I???m using features that are only available to Result, not std::expected, such as the Try macro, anyhow, and thiserror. Not sure if we can replace the underlying result type with std::expected. Check out https://github.com/loliGothicK/mitama-cpp-result.

issueDTO.title: Separate Site and Shield Settings from History in Clear Private Data
issueDTO.description:
On iOS in Settings > Shields & Privacy under `Clear Private Data` if you have `Browsing History` selected we will remove/reset Site and Shield Settings (Site-specific shields preferences, zoom level, and wallet dApp permissions). We should separate these to align with desktop, adding a new `Site and Shield Settings` toggle. It will default off to align with desktop, but similar to the other toggles, once it's toggled on it will remain on after user has tapped `Clear Data Now`.


### Steps to Reproduce

1. Connect to an ethereum dApp, ex. https://app.uniswap.org/
2. Change the zoom level
3. In the Shields panel, change some shield preferences
4. Visit Settings > Shields & Privacy, under `Clear Private Data` disable all toggles except `Browsing History`
5. Tap `Clear Data Now`
6. Visit the dApp site again and notice the dApp connection is removed, zoom level is reset, and Shield panel preferences are reset to defaults / global preferences.


### Additional Info

Site and Shield Settings was originally included here: https://github.com/brave/brave-ios/issues/5134
comments: HEy @ShivanKaul i want to work on this issue

Great! Just a reminder that this is an iOS issue. You will need to follow https://github.com/brave/brave-browser/wiki/iOS-Development-Environment to get set up. Please let us know when you have a PR that we can take a look at.
Okk sure

I have this running over a secure site (https through Caddy) so that doesn't appear to be the issue. **Describe alternatives you've considered** Obsidian, StackOverflow, CodePen, etc. **Additional context** Add any other context or screenshots about the feature request here. issueDTO.title: Onion site won't load if TOR settings set to "Safer" or "Safest" must be "Standard"
issueDTO.description: Using TOR Browser 14.5.8 tried to load the main onion URL (`RoboSatsy56bwqn...`) and it just kept spinning with no progress. "Looking for robot parts..." "Hiding in 2^256 bits of entropy..." I tried different networks, VPN's, Firewall settings. Nothing fixed it. Eventually found the cause to be TOR Security Level settings. I had it set to the middle "Safer" level. Changing it to "Standard" would then load the site. I'm not sure if you can detect if the loading has taken too long or if certain things are being blocked by the user settings and provide guidance in that case. Or perhaps a quick fix is just add into that loading screen a help link "Site taking too long to load?" that takes them to a FAQ on how to change their TOR browser settings. If the site loads normally, they probably wouldn't have time to see/click the link.
comments: On "Safest" level (JS completely deactivate) this warning shows up. Yeah would be nice if this also shows up in "Safer" if possible.

@sixside I hope this helps. I know its a bit of a hack but the failure I saw when running in safer mode was wsm failing to load. Safest mode was already defaulting to error message but the spinner never went away. The pr only displays the main div when js is enabled and wsm is found (both being true only happens when in standard mode on tor from what I understand). One thing to take into consideration is the dependency on wsm. I am new to this project but if there is a future where wsm is not a requirement then it could end up being undefined and standard mode would display the error message by default. This would likely be caught in that case. I am happy to address any concerns and I look forward to digging through the project to see where else I could be helpful. Let me know what you guys think and if you would need an extra pair of hands/eyes anywhere

@KoalaSat @f321x apologies for the ping, I don't know what your pr review process is like or how you prefer to tackle propesed changes/bugfixes/etc. So if this is a bother, my apologies. I just know things get lost in my inbox sometimes and a ping could be helpful. That is all I intended but if its an annoyance just say the word. All the best!

issueDTO.title: Feature Request: Be able to choose what disks to monitor
issueDTO.description: **Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.** Follow-up on #2591. The disks now fit on screen but on hosts running Proxmox for example, there is a lot of disks shown here. **Describe the solution you'd like** It would be nice if in the configuration screen for the infrastructure monitor you could select which disks to monitor. For this to make sense, having the mointpoint be shown is essential. Otherwise I don't know what disk 1 or disk 32 is and if I want to monitor it or not. It could for example look like this in the interface. However I am not entirely sure how I feel about the layout just yet... The mountpoint can be quite long and this might not be the best way to display it since it wraps quite quickly due to lack of space. Other people might be able to chime in here. **Describe alternatives you've considered** Have not been able to figure out an alternative since I can't just go and disconnect disks. :) **Additional context** The best way would be to add Capture agents to all containers and VM's on the hosts but monitoring the host itself for disk space utilization is also very usefull. Since 3 VM's with 100 GB disk each will not know that the host disk of 200 GB is running out of space.

The answer is: **Yes** ???

We can filter the disks by device or mount point. Capture already exposes a field `device` but it's not shown in the infrastructure dashboard.

```shell
# Capture Response
# Disk Array 'device' key
data.disk[0].device "/dev/nvme0n1p1"
```

| Device Name ( 🟢 )| Mount Point |
|---------------------|-------------------|
| /dev/nvme0n1p1 | / |
| /dev/nvme0n1p2 | /boot/efi |
| /dev/nvme0n1p3 | /home |
| /dev/mmcblk0p2 | /mnt/somewhere |
