issueDTO.title: Consider local-ip hosts as local
issueDTO.description:
As announced in the [release 3.2.0:](https://github.com/medic/cht-conf/blob/main/release-notes.md#320)
> To detect accidental overwrites, cht-conf will generate two files - .snapshots/remote.json and .snapshots/local.json. These store the last known configuration on the server. The remote.json file should be commited with your configuration changes, and local.json should be added to the .gitignore since everyone's local environment is different. If changes are made to the configuration on the server using cht-conf or the App Management webapp without committing the remote.json file to your config repo, and then subsequently pulling the changes, then any attempt to upload configuration changes will be notified about the risk and prompted to either overwrite or cancel.


However, we only consider `localhost` as local.

https://github.com/medic/cht-conf/blob/dae31f93f9269af844569a32672c703cca5370fd/src/lib/warn-upload-overwrite.js#L29-L31

With [docker-helper](https://docs.communityhealthtoolkit.org/hosting/cht/app-developer/#cht-docker-helper) & [nginx-local-ip](https://docs.communityhealthtoolkit.org/community/contributing/code/core/dev-environment/#nginx-local-ip), now we can have local instances like this: `https://192-168-0-3.local-ip.medicmobile.org:8443`.

We might want to consider them as local so that `remote.json` is reserved for remote instances.
comments:
🤔 Is there any particular reason to store snapshots of just `local`/`remote` instead of having a separate snapshot for _each_ URL that is targeted?  

The main difference I can think of when it comes to a normal app dev workflow is that currently if there is remote dev/prod instances, then the `remote` snapshot is getting reused for both.  Perhaps that leads to some desirable outcome/behavior?  Otherwise, I feel like it would be fine (maybe even useful) to have separate snapshots for each).  

Either way, I agree that `local-ip` snapshots should probably not override the `remote.json`.

repository.description: A command-line interface for configuring Community Health Toolkit applications
repository.name: cht-conf

summary.main: Consider local-ip hosts as local, to detect accidental overwrites and avoid overriding `remote.json` with local-ip snapshots
summary.validationOrRequirement: none mentioned
summary.attemptedFixes: none mentioned
summary.otherNotes: Is there any particular reason to store snapshots of just `local`/`remote` instead of having a separate snapshot for _each_ URL that is targeted?

The release of create-plugin v6 stopped the update command from automatically updating all dependencies. This decision was made to try to reduce unwanted changes, noise in PRs, and breakages in tooling / scripts.

issueDTO.title: Add a @medic/constants shared library
issueDTO.description:
## Description

We have a bunch of magic strings spread throughout the app.
One of the prominent ones being `mm-online`: https://github.com/search?q=repo%3Amedic%2Fcht-core+mm-online&type=code
This is not the only example. 

## Goals

- [ ] Collect all reused magic strings and add them to a shared library. 

## Expected Outcome

There should be a single source of truth for the magic numbers, strings, etc. used throughout `cht-core` which is `shared-libs/constants`.

## Implementation Details

Welcome, First-time contributor! Here's how you can succeed in this task.
First, some background. Shared libraries are those collections of code that are available to be used throughout the `cht-core`. They are located in `cht-core/shared-libs`. This task wants you to create another shared library called `constants` where all the constants of `cht-core` will be stored as a single source of truth.

1. Create a new folder in `cht-core/shared-libs` called `constants`.
2. Create a new folder `src` inside the folder created above with an `index.js` file.
3. Create a `package.json` file inside the `constants` folder. Add some mandatory fields like `name`, `version`, `description`, etc. Other shared libraries can be a good reference for this. Keep this file minimal.
4. Start adding constant values in the `src/index.js` file. Refer to this [comment](https://github.com/medic/cht-core/issues/9621#issuecomment-2464647266) as to what values are to be converted to constants. Also, you can do some research and add constants as required.
5. Replace the values in the code with the `constants` library values. The way to use a library from a shared library is:
    ```javascript
    const constants = require('@medic/constants');

    // use
    constants.a;
    constants.b;
    ...
    ```
6. After you replace a value in the `cht-core` code, with a constant value, be sure to run the tests to make sure that nothing has changed. The tests can be run using the `npm` commands: `npm run integration-all-local` for integration tests, `npm run unit` for unit tests and `npm run wdio-local` for automation tests.

## Product Name

Community Health Toolkit: CHT Core

## Organisation Name

Medic

## Domain

Healthcare

## Tech Skills Needed

JavaScript, Typescript, Mocha, Node.js

## Organizational Mentor

@sugat009

## Complexity

Low

## Category

Maintenance
comments:
Examples I can think of...

- `mm-online`
- `X-Request-Id`
- `_local/transitions-seq`
- `_local/background-seq`
- doc types, eg: `translations`
- doc IDs, eg: `service-worker-meta`

Thanks for adding to the list. I agree with all these suggestions. 
We also have `X-Medic-Service` header that we pass to haproxy in both api and sentinel. 
For doc ids, we can also make it return translation doc names like (code) => `messages-${code}`. 
Same applies to form names, other docs that have prefixes (`org.couchdb.user:`). 

I think we're going to end up with a sizeable list.

issueDTO.title: BUG: Landing Page Repository Input Not Connected to CodeGraph Indexing
issueDTO.description:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### What happened?

## 📌 Issue Overview  

**Landing Page Repository Input Not Connected to CodeGraph Indexing**

The landing page allows users to enter a GitHub repository URL, but clicking "Analyze Repository" fails because the frontend calls a non-existent backend API endpoint (`/api/repo-stats`). The repository indexing functionality with FalkorDB exists in the codebase but is not exposed via the REST API for the web frontend.

---

## 🔍 Steps to Reproduce  

1. Go to the landing page (`LandingPage.tsx`)  
2. Enter a valid GitHub repository URL (e.g., `https://github.com/AOSSIE-Org/Devr.AI`) 
3. Click on "Analyze Repository" button  
4. See the error toast: "Failed to fetch repository stats. Please check the URL or backend server."

---

## 🎯 Expected Behavior  

1. User enters a GitHub repository URL in the landing page
2. Frontend sends the URL to backend API endpoint
3. Backend calls `RepoService.index_repo()` to index the repository using FalkorDB CodeGraph
4. Repository is cloned, analyzed, and stored as a graph in FalkorDB
5. Indexing metadata (status, node count, edge count) is saved to Supabase
6. User receives success message with repository stats
7. User is navigated to the dashboard showing the indexed repository data

---

## 🚨 Actual Behavior  

1. User enters a GitHub repository URL in the landing page
2. Frontend attempts to POST to `http://localhost:8000/api/repo-stats` (line 23 in `LandingPage.tsx`)
3. Request fails with 404 - endpoint does not exist in the backend
4. User sees error toast message
5. No repository indexing occurs
6. User cannot proceed to dashboard

**Technical Details:**

The frontend makes this call:
```typescript
const response = await axios.post('http://localhost:8000/api/repo-stats', { repo_url: repoUrl });
```

But `/api/repo-stats` endpoint is **not defined** in:
- ??? `backend/app/api/router.py`
- ??? `backend/app/api/v1/` (no repositories endpoint)

**However, the infrastructure exists:**
- ??? `backend/app/services/codegraph/repo_service.py` - Complete `RepoService` class
- ??? `RepoService.index_repo()` method works (tested via Discord bot)
- ??? FalkorDB integration functional
- ??? Supabase database with `indexed_repositories` table
- ??? Just missing the REST API layer to expose this functionality

---

### Files to Modify:
- `backend/app/api/v1/repositories.py` (create new file)
- `backend/app/api/router.py` (add router registration)
- `frontend/src/components/landing/LandingPage.tsx` (update API endpoint)

### Record

- [x] I agree to follow this project's Code of Conduct
- [ ] I want to work on this issue
comments: Later on we can extend this functionality to provide the repository stats too including with the functionality to index repositories.
@smokeyScraper Interested in taking this up. Assign me if available

Hi @smokeyScraper,
I'd like to pick up Issue #170.My proposed approach is to: 
1) Create a new POST /api/v1/repositories/index endpoint to handle the repo_url.
2) Have this endpoint validate the URL, enqueue the RepoService.index_repo() job, and persist the metadata in Supabase.
3) Update LandingPage.tsx to call this new API and show success/error feedback to the user.
Please assign this to me if it sound okay to you!
@smokeyScraper sir please assign it to me
Assigning to @Vaibhaviitian. Sorry @Bhup-GitHUB, @OmRatnaparkhe, but this issue was proposed by @Vaibhaviitian himself, that's why assigning it to him.
No worries

issueDTO.title: Show preview images in `st.file_uploader`
issueDTO.description:
### Checklist

- [X] I have searched the [existing issues](https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/issues) for similar feature requests.
- [X] I added a descriptive title and summary to this issue.

### Summary

When uploading an image in `st.file_uploader`, it shows a generic file icon for the uploaded image, see below. We could show a little preview of the image instead. 

![CleanShot 2024-04-28 at 04 00 25@2x](https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/assets/5103165/a2ff47e7-f05b-4075-9140-2517176cdcb9)


### Why?

Just a nice little UX improvement :)

### How?

Whenever the uploaded file is an image, replace the file icon in the file uploader with a preview image. We could also do the same thing for documents, e.g., if you upload a PDF, show a preview of the first page. 

### Additional Context

issueDTO.title: [textfield] Typings for `formHelperText` slot missing data attributes
issueDTO.description:
### Steps to reproduce Steps: 1. Open this link to live example: https://stackblitz.com/edit/e8yxd8yt?file=src%2FDemo.tsx 2. Observe the error in the editor. ### Current behavior There is an error on `slotProps` -> `formHelperText` -> any data attribute. This error doesn't occur for `htmlInput`. ### Expected behavior No error, data attributes should be added to the typings, as they are for other slotProps. ### Context It's important to remember that this is purely a typings issue. At run-time it works perfectly. ### Your environment
npx @mui/envinfo ``` System: OS: Windows 10 10.0.19045 Binaries: Node: 22.21.0 - C:\Program Files\nodejs\node.EXE npm: 11.6.2 - C:\Program Files\nodejs\npm.CMD pnpm: Not Found Browsers: Chrome: 142.0.7444.135 Edge: Chromium (141.0.3537.99) Firefox: 144.0.2 - C:\Program Files\Mozilla Firefox\firefox.exe ```
I'm using Firefox 144 (not that it matters) **Search keywords**: formHelperText data attributes
comments:
I just found the same problem exists for `Select` -> `slotProps` -> `input`. It too doesn't allow data-attributes as far as the typings go.

Live example has been updated to show this.
@ZeeshanTamboli I would like to work on this issue

@ZeeshanTamboli Thank you. I was able to make it work with your suggestions.

To be fair though, it does add hairyness to the project. Another workaround for something that should probably work by itself. I say that because of your remark:

> We won't support it directly for now

I think MUI should support this. It's the only way to get extra HTML attributes into the underlaying elements. And as you might be able to tell, these are data attributes used for Cypress (well, our implementation of Cypress that is), which needs *some* predictable selector in order to know what's what, and `data-cy` is a common way of achieving that. So, broadly supporting data-attributes to be passed like this, would be quite helpful.

> I think MUI should support this. It's the only way to get extra HTML attributes into the underlaying elements. And as you might be able to tell, these are data attributes used for Cypress (well, our implementation of Cypress that is), which needs _some_ predictable selector in order to know what's what, and `data-cy` is a common way of achieving that. So, broadly supporting data-attributes to be passed like this, would be quite helpful.

That is being tracked in #33175. See reason for why it isn't decided yet: https://github.com/mui/material-ui/issues/33175#issuecomment-1219422754.
@ZeeshanTamboli  could u assign this issue to me , would love to work on it
@Oashe02 It's already been taken by @rithik56

issueDTO.title: [RFC]: add `symbol/split`
issueDTO.description:
### Description

This RFC proposes adding the package `symbol/split`.

The package should be very similar to the following existing packages:

- `symbol/has-instance`
- `symbol/iterator`
- `symbol/async-iterator`
- `symbol/is-concat-spreadable`

The primary difference is that the package should export `Symbol.split` if it exists.

### Related Issues

None.

### Questions

No.

### Other

When adding this package, one should do the following:

- copy one of the existing packages mentioned above
- rename the copied package
- find and replace the package name (e.g., `has-instance` => `split`)
- find and replace the variable name (e.g., `HasInstanceSymbol` => `SplitSymbol`)
- ensure the copyright years are 2025
- update the descriptions according to the symbol's purpose (see MDN)
- update examples to reflect the symbol's purpose (see existing packages for inspiration)
- run tests, benchmarks, and examples to ensure that everything passes
- go back through and check that there are no copy-paste mistakes

### Checklist

- [x] I have read and understood the [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/stdlib-js/stdlib/blob/develop/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md).
- [x] Searched for existing issues and pull requests.
- [x] The issue name begins with `RFC:`.
comments:
# :wave: Important: PLEASE READ :wave:

This issue has been labeled as a **good first issue** and is available for anyone to work on.

If this is your first time contributing to an open source project, some aspects of the development process may seem unusual, arcane, or some combination of both.

1.  **You cannot "claim" issues.** People new to open source often want to "claim" or be assigned an issue before beginning work. The typical rationale is that people want to avoid wasted work in the event that someone else ends up working the issue. However, this practice is not effective in open source, as it often leads to "issue squatting", in which an individual asks to be assigned, is granted their request, and then never ends up working on the issue. Accordingly, you are encouraged to communicate your intent to address this issue, ideally by providing a rough outline as to how you plan to address the issue or asking clarifying questions, but, at the end of the day, we will take running code and rough consensus in order to move forward quickly.
2.  **We have a very high bar for contributions.** We have very high standards for contributions and expect all contributions???whether new features, tests, or documentation???to be rigorous, thorough, and complete. Once a pull request is merged into stdlib, that contribution immediately becomes the collective responsibility of all maintainers of stdlib. When we merge code into stdlib, we are saying that we, the maintainers, commit to reviewing subsequent changes and making bugfixes to the code. Hence, in order to ensure future maintainability, this naturally leads to a higher standard of contribution.

Before working on this issue and opening a pull request, please read the project's [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/stdlib-js/stdlib/blob/develop/CONTRIBUTING.md). These guidelines and the associated [development guide](https://github.com/stdlib-js/stdlib/blob/develop/docs/contributing/development.md) provide important information, including links to stdlib's [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/stdlib-js/stdlib/blob/develop/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md), license policy, and steps for setting up your local development environment.

To reiterate, we **strongly** encourage you to refer to our contributing guides **before** beginning work on this issue. Failure to follow our guidelines significantly decreases the likelihood that you'll successfully contribute to stdlib and may result in automatic closure of a pull request without review.

Setting up your local development environment is a critical first step, as doing so ensures that automated development processes for linting, license verification, and unit testing can run prior to authoring commits and pushing changes. If you would prefer to avoid manual setup, we provide pre-configured [development containers](https://github.com/stdlib-js/stdlib/tree/develop/.devcontainer) for use locally or in GitHub Codespaces.

We place a high value on consistency throughout the stdlib codebase. We encourage you to closely examine other packages in stdlib and attempt to emulate the practices and conventions found therein.

-   If you are attempting to contribute a new package, sometimes the best approach is to simply copy the contents of an existing package and then modify the minimum amount necessary to implement the feature (e.g., changing descriptions, parameter names, and implementation).
-   If you are contributing tests, find a package implementing a similar feature and emulate the tests of that package.
-   If you are updating documentation, examine several similar packages and emulate the content, style, and prose of those packages.

In short, the more effort you put in to ensure that your contribution looks and feels like stdlib???including variables names, bracket spacing, line breaks, etc???the more likely that your contribution will be reviewed and ultimately accepted. We encourage you to closely study the codebase **before** beginning work on this issue.

:sparkles: Thank you again for your interest in stdlib, and we look forward to reviewing your future contributions. :sparkles:

issueDTO.title: Match the PML properties to beam path material
issueDTO.description:
## Feature request 💡
The Perfect Matching Layer currently assumes that the beam is going through vacuum. If the material is changed to something with $\sigma \neq 0$ S/m or $\epsilon_r \neq 1$ and $\mu_r \neq 1$ then the PML layers are not adapted to the simulation domain, creating discontinuities in the field computation.


#### 🔍 Describe the solution you'd like  
The $\sigma$, $\epsilon^{-1}$ and $\mu^{-1}$ tensors should have the layers corresponding to the PML automatically adapting their parameters with respect to the beam path material.
comments: When using a non-vacuum material for the beam path, the PML cell properties computation remain the same as for vacuum. This creates discontinuities in the field propagation. Here with $\epsilon_r = 10, \mu_r=1, \sigma=0.2\ S/m$ we clearly see the discontinuity in the $E_z$ field ![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/92525a44-40c1-41b1-81ed-c84abc73d75c) The discontinuity in $\sigma$ over the PML domain can clearly be seen: Now with the same material for the beam path, but with the adapted PML, the $E_z$ field looks nicer: ![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/107996ad-9863-4179-804b-82c86204298c) The conductivity of the PML cells is now correctly adapted:

repository.description: 3D electromagnetic time-domain solver, specialized in wake potential and beam-coupling impedance computation for particle accelerators
repository.name: wakis

summary.main: The goal is to match the PML properties to the beam path material, ensuring that the PML layers adapt to the simulation domain and avoid discontinuities in the field computation.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The PML layers should automatically adapt their parameters with respect to the beam path material, with $ho$, $ rac{1}{ho}$ and $ rac{1}{ho}$ tensors having the layers corresponding to the PML.
summary.attemptedFixes: The images provided show the discontinuity in the $E_z$ field and the conductivity of the PML cells when using a non-vacuum material for the beam path.
summary.otherNotes: The PML cell properties computation remains the same as for vacuum when using a non-vacuum material for the beam path, creating discontinuities in the field propagation. The conductivity of the PML cells should be correctly adapted to the beam path material.

issueDTO.title: Publish a docker image for the `kubetail` CLI tool
issueDTO.description:
To support users who want to use Kubetail locally running inside a docker container as well as users who want to use the `kubetail` CLI tool inside their clusters or in custom docker images we should create a `kubetail-cli` docker image and integrate it into our release workflow.

The `kubetail-cli` docker image should have the following features:
* The `kubetail` binary should be static
* The base image should be based on busybox and we should publish these tags/variants:
    ```
    kubetail-cli:${VERSION}
    kubetail-cli:${VERSION}-alpine
    kubetail-cli:latest
    kubetail-cli:latest-alpine
    ```

In addition:
* We should publish the images to docker hub and to ghcr.io
* We should sign the images using cosign

Currently the CLI release workflow is located in [`.github/workflows/release-cli.yml`](https://github.com/kubetail-org/kubetail/blob/main/.github/workflows/release-cli.yml) but I think it might be better to put the CLI docker-specfic release workflow in [`.github/workflows/release-docker.yml`](https://github.com/kubetail-org/kubetail/blob/main/.github/workflows/release-docker.yml).

issueDTO.title: Add `hide_index` to `st.table`
issueDTO.description:
### Checklist

- [X] I have searched the [existing issues](https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/issues) for similar feature requests.
- [X] I added a descriptive title and summary to this issue.

### Summary

need Static tables hide index

### Why?

I am a perfectionist, and I will collapse when I see useless indexes

### How?

st.table(df,hide_index=True)

### Additional Context

_No response_
comments:
**To help Streamlit prioritize this feature, react with a 👍 (thumbs up emoji) to the initial post.**

Your vote helps us identify which enhancements matter most to our users.

![Views](https://api.views-badge.org/badge/st-issue-9251)

The `df.style.hide()` method is supposed to hide the index column. It does work if we display the dataframe with `st.html(styler.to_html())`, but not with `st.table(styler)` or `st.dataframe(styler)`.

Here is a code example:
```py
import pandas as pd
import streamlit as st

df = pd.DataFrame({"a": [1, 2, 3]})
styler = df.style

st.html(styler.to_html())  # Works as expected
st.dataframe(styler)  # Works as expected
st.table(styler)  # Works as expected

styler.hide()  # Hide the index column

st.html(styler.to_html())  # Works as expected
st.dataframe(styler, hide_index=True)  # Works as expected
st.dataframe(styler)  # Index column is still visible
st.table(styler)  # Index column is still visible
```
Would you like me to create a separate issue for the above "bug" with `st.table(df.style.hide())`? Maybe @lukasmasuch?
@JosephMarinier yep, I think a feature request for adding support to hide columns, indices, and rows via Pandas Styler in `st.table` would be good.

Hi!
I'd like to start working on this, will raise a PR soon.
Please let me know if someone else has taken this up already, thanks!

Hey there,
I noticed this issue hasn???t had any updates recently ??? just wanted to check if anyone is currently working on it.
If it???s still open, I???d love to take a stab at it!

I???ve looked through the st.table() code path and have a rough idea of how to add a hide_index argument, update the rendering logic, and add some tests + docs.

Totally fine if someone else is already on it ??? just wanted to ask before starting.

issueDTO.title: [community] Improving docstrings and type hints
issueDTO.description:
There are many instances in the codebase where our docstring/typing convention is not followed. We'd like to work on improving this with your help!

Our convention looks like:

```python3
def function_name(parameter_1: Union[str, List[str]], parameter_2: Optional[int] = None, parameter_3: float = 42.0) -> Civilization:
    r"""
    Function that creates a simulation.

    Args:
        parameter_1 (`str` or `List[str]`):
            Description of game level.
        parameter_2 (`int`, *optional*):
            Kardashev scale of civilization.
        parameter_3 (`float`, defaults to `42.0`):
            Difficulty scale.

    Returns:
        [`~simulations.objects.Civilization`]
            A civilization simulation with provided initialization parameters.
    """
```

Some examples that don't follow the docstring convention are:
- [this](https://github.com/huggingface/diffusers/blob/c4a8979f3018fbffee33304c1940561f7a5cf613/src/diffusers/models/embeddings.py#L89): missing explanations
- [this](https://github.com/huggingface/diffusers/blob/33fafe3d143ca8380a9e405e7acfa69091d863fb/src/diffusers/pipelines/stable_diffusion_3/pipeline_stable_diffusion_3.py#L132): does not contain mixin-related documentation whereas as [this](https://github.com/huggingface/diffusers/blob/33fafe3d143ca8380a9e405e7acfa69091d863fb/src/diffusers/pipelines/stable_diffusion/pipeline_stable_diffusion.py#L154) does
- [this](https://github.com/huggingface/diffusers/blob/c4a8979f3018fbffee33304c1940561f7a5cf613/src/diffusers/utils/import_utils.py#L672): function explanation after "Args", but should be before
- [this](https://github.com/huggingface/diffusers/blob/c4a8979f3018fbffee33304c1940561f7a5cf613/src/diffusers/pipelines/deepfloyd_if/pipeline_output.py#L14): same reason as above
- [this](https://github.com/huggingface/diffusers/blob/c4a8979f3018fbffee33304c1940561f7a5cf613/src/diffusers/models/embeddings.py#L518): incorrect indentation

There are also many places where docstrings are completely missing or inadequately explained. If you feel something needs an improvement, you can open a PR with your suggestions too! Additionally, type hints are not appropriate/correctly used at many occurrences and mismatch the accompanying docstrings - these could use an improvement too!

Please limit your PRs to changes to a single file in each PR. Changes must be only related to docstrings/type hints. Feel free to ping either @yiyixuxu, @stevhliu or me for reviews.

issueDTO.title: Add email bulk delete option with checkboxes on email list page.
comments: Hi, i am interested in resolving this issue.

> Hi, i am interested in resolving this issue.

Hi @Pantex9, thanks for your interest! Your help would be very much appreciated! 👍 

Feel free to take a try at it and submit a PR. If you have any questions regarding the project structure or need help in setting up your environment let me know and I'll gladly help out.

Really need this one, allowing users to delete mails in bulk without opening each one and then deleting them one by one.
I get e-mail newsletters, which get accumulated, making the inbox cluttered AND I'M LAZY enough to push this to a later date.
Really hoping for a quicker resolution to this issue but I can't be too demanding as a _freeloader_.
😊

Hi @lanedirt,

I've begun implementation on the bulk email deletion feature and expect to have a development branch ready for your review soon. Before creating the pull request, I wanted to discuss a few key design points to ensure alignment.

### The API design proposal


The proposed solution utilizes a single endpoint designed for partial success, which prioritizes throughput and client resilience.

#### Contract Models (Shared)

To facilitate future bulk actions (mark as read/unread, archive), I've created two generic models:

- `EmailBulkRequest`: `List<int>` of email IDs to process.
- `EmailBulkResponse`:
  - `successfulEmailIds`: `List<int>` of successfully processed IDs.
  - `errors`: `Dictionary<int, string>` where the key is the failed ID and the value is the error message.

#### Endpoint Definition

- Method: `DELETE`
- Path: `/v1/Email/bulk`
- Request Type: `EmailBulkRequest`
- Response Type: `EmailBulkResponse`

 Sample request:

```json
{
 "ids": [ 1, 2, 3 ]
}
```

- Sample response:

```json
{
 "successfullEmailIds": [ 1, 2 ]
 "errors": [
    { "3": "Failed to delete email 3: reason here!" }
 ] 
}
```
####  UI Changes

- Added a checkbox to each row (`EmailRow`).
- Implemented a "Delete all selected" button on the `/emails` action bar, visible only when emails are checked.

----

### Pros & Cons

This partial-success model offers significant benefits, accepting minor complexity trade-offs:

#### Rationale and Benefits

- Partially Successful Operations: Prevents a single invalid ID from rolling back the entire batch, which enhances throughput and resilience.

- Efficiency in Mobile Environments: Gaining throughput is especially valuable on mobile where initiating multiple connections can be computationally expensive.

- Idempotence and Retries: The detailed response allows clients to safely retry only the failing IDs after an intermittent network or server failure.

#### Concessions and Trade-Offs

We accept three main drawbacks:

- Server-Side Complexity: The server requires more complex logic to isolate errors within a loop, track the status of each item, and aggregate the comprehensive success/error results. Multiple rounds to the database are expected.

- Client-Side Complexity: The client must always parse the HTTP 200 OK response body to check for errors, instead of simply relying on the status code (like a 204 or 400).

- Protocol Deviation: We are using a request body with the `DELETE` method, which is non-standard. If this is a concern, we can switch the method to `POST /v1/Email/bulk-delete` or another approach.

----

### Open questions

#### SpamOK integration
I noticed that for the single email deletion we have a [special treatment for emails hosted on SpamOK.com](https://github.com/aliasvault/aliasvault/blob/main/apps/server/AliasVault.Client/Main/Components/Email/EmailPreview.razor#L187-L194), where it calls its API instead of AliasVault one.

I am assuming that for the bulk delete we need to take this in consideration as well, right?

Does the SpamOK API have a bulk deletion endpoint we can utilize? If so, can you please share the documentation/contract details so I can read it?

#### Feature scope

Is it acceptable for you if we launch this feature first for the `AliasVault.Client` module only?
We can track the implementation for the `mobile-app` module under a separate, follow-up issue, if you agree.


#### Internationalization (I18n) concerns

I've added new keys keys to the `.resx` files. Could you confirm the workflow for translations? Are you using an AI tool for initial generation, and is there a subsequent human review process to ensure quality?

----

Thanks for your guidance on these points.

Hi @daniloguimaraes, thanks for looking into this!

Thanks for the detailed write-up, the approach looks solid overall. A few notes and clarifications below:  

> Does the SpamOK API have a bulk deletion endpoint we can utilize? If so, can you please share the documentation/contract details so I can read it?

No, SpamOK does not provide a bulk delete endpoint.  Also good to take into account: SpamOK emails are only shown in the credentials page ???recent emails??? block, not on the `/emails` page. This is because SpamOK doesn???t support bulk retrieval either. As the bulk delete functionality only applies to the `/emails` page, SpamOK emails do not have to be taken into account.

> Is it acceptable for you if we launch this feature first for the AliasVault.Client module only?
We can track the implementation for the mobile-app module under a separate, follow-up issue, if you agree.

Yep, sounds good! We can create separate issues for the other client apps.

> I've added new keys keys to the .resx files. Could you confirm the workflow for translations? Are you using an AI tool for initial generation, and is there a subsequent human review process to ensure quality?

Adding new strings to the `en.resx` files is sufficient. Translations are handled via **Crowdin**, which automatically populates or creates the corresponding `.resx` files for other languages.  

--

Additional comment for your proposed API response: detailed per-ID errors are not necessary in my opinion. If an email is already deleted or doesn???t exist, that???s fine and shouldn???t be treated as an error.  So a simple `HTTP 200 OK` (or `500` for total failure) is acceptable to me. So this can be simplified. But if you prefer to keep the detailed logging, that???s also fine, I'll leave that up to you.  

Thanks again for looking into it. Looking forward to the PR!

Great, @lanedirt . Thanks for the considerations. 👍 

And regarding the detailed per-ID errors response, I gonna drop it and respond with a simple `200 OK`. Less is more 😄 . If someday we understand that detailed information is needed, them we can revisit it.

issueDTO.title: loc with one row cause error
issueDTO.description:
```
let data = { "Name": ["Apples", "Mango", "Banana", "Pear"],
            "Count": [21, 5, 30, 10],
            "Price": [200, 300, 40, 250] }

let df = new dfd.DataFrame(data, {index: ["a", "b", "c", "d"]})
df.print()
let sub_df = df.loc({rows: ["a"]})
sub_df.print()
```

In browser, this will cause error:

Uncaught Error: IndexError: Specified index (a) not found
    at t._loc (startup:4:47)
    at t.loc (startup:4:47)
    at pen.js?key=pen.js-8a2f7821-cb23-e0d2-07e7-2b53e94c09e0:7:17


This will only happen when the rows have exactly one element, if it's let sub_df = df.loc({rows: ["a", "b"]}), then it is normal.
comments:
I can confirm this bug. 

In function _loc, when rows.length == 1 && typeof rows[0] == "string", the implementation check if  ```":"``` not exist then assumes rows is a number, then casts it to Number(), so in your case {rows: ["a"]} results in NaN row index thus the exception.

This is business logic flaw I'll send a fix.

repository.name: danfojs

summary.main: loc with one row cause error
summary.validationOrRequirement: rows.length == 1 && typeof rows[0] == "string"
summary.attemptedFixes: I can confirm this bug.
summary.otherNotes: This is business logic flaw I'll send a fix.

issueDTO.title: Bad type annotation when documenting an optional parameter value
comments:
Wow. I didn't know the compiler would even allow this syntax of putting the parameter's name in square brackets.

If you also supply the "=default" part AFAICT the compiler completely throws that away.

The only test for this syntax is called `testUnsupportedJsDocSyntax1()`

https://github.com/google/closure-compiler/blob/3ff3fd061e164dbd825def388d53f3c63d341ed4/test/com/google/javascript/jscomp/parsing/JsDocInfoParserTest.java#L5073

I'm guessing that this `[name=defaultValue]` syntax is something that exists in the OpenSource JSDoc standard,
which is definitely not the same as the JSDoc that closure-compiler uses.
I think some little effort must have been made to support this bit of that syntax years ago.
Unsurprisingly, there's a bug in it.

issueDTO.title: [Story]: Replace examples of sensitive values with explicit placeholders
issueDTO.description:
### Overview

**As a** user,
**I want** clear placeholders for examples,
So that I can update my code accordingly.

**As a** security expert,
**I want** placeholders for examples,
**So that** my scanning tools do not give false positives.

### Which product or products does this request relate to?

Other

### Description

Across the NGINX documentation sets, there are many instances of example values being given to represent user-specific information such as credentials or desired configuration options. Some of the example values look like plausibly sensitive information, either by accident or because they were generated in a test environment.

A generic pattern should be adopted and enforced across all documentation to make it abundantly clear what fields are placeholders, ensuring that the users know exactly what to replace, and to reduce the risk of the wrong information being used or perceived.

### Acceptance criteria

- The user should be able to clearly tell when an example has placeholder values
- The user should be able to tell what the placeholder value is meant to represent
- The user should not think the placeholder could represent any sensitive production information

issueDTO.title: Enable Even More PyDocStyle Checks
issueDTO.description:
### Description

Followup to https://github.com/apache/airflow/issues/10742

We use Ruff to enforce docsting style
https://github.com/apache/airflow/blob/23b8e839a35e84d57c5cf38b0b21171ac3bd1ecc/pyproject.toml#L47-L74

We follow pep257 style (http://www.pydocstyle.org/en/stable/error_codes.html) for checks.

Currently, we ignore the following rules and should work towards enabling them:


**Missing Docstrings**
--

- [x] D100 | Missing docstring in public module https://github.com/apache/airflow/pull/40741
- [x] D102 | Missing docstring in public method https://lists.apache.org/thread/lcvocwxnrrzq9ofrg4b4hj0yvpzbnygf
- [x] D103| Missing docstring in public function https://lists.apache.org/thread/lcvocwxnrrzq9ofrg4b4hj0yvpzbnygf
- [x] D104 | Missing docstring in public package https://github.com/apache/airflow/pull/40741
- [x] D107 | Missing docstring in `__init__` https://lists.apache.org/thread/lcvocwxnrrzq9ofrg4b4hj0yvpzbnygf
- [x] D214 | Consistent multi-line docstring indentation
- [x] D215 | Enforce number of underscores if you use underlines in a multi-line docstring
- [x] PT004 | Fixture does not return anything, add leading underscore
- [ ] PT006 | @pytest.mark.parametrize names should be a tuple
- [x] PT007 | @pytest.mark.parametrize values should be a tuple
- [ ] PT011 | pytest.raises() is too broad, set the match parameter
- [x] TCH003 | stdlib imports which are only used for typechecking go in to TYPE_CHECKING block


It would be good if we can enable them one by one -- separate PRs are ok

**Rough process to fix these**
--

0.  Set up your dev environment [[docs](https://github.com/apache/airflow/blob/main/contributing-docs/README.rst)]
0.5. Go to your `airflow` directory and run `ruff check`.  Write down the number of failures.  Mine currently says 8.  This step is just to make sure it's working and give you a baseline.

1. Open `/airflow/pyproject.toml`
2. In the `ignore` list (currently starting on [line 301](https://github.com/apache/airflow/blob/main/pyproject.toml#L301)) comment out the rule you intend to work on
3. In a terminal, go to the `airflow` directory and run `ruff check` again.  It should now fail with WAY more errors.  Mine currently says 863.  If the number didn't go way up, something is wrong with your setup.
4. Have a quick scroll through that list, paying attention to which ones failed because of the rule you just enabled.
5. Come up with a rough plan to break that down into bites.  Maybe pick one directory that has a bunch of failures and start fixing there.
6. After you have a handful of fixes done: remove your comment (so it is ignored again) and submit a PR with that chunk of changes (see the Contributing docs in step 0)

PLEASE submit these in many small PRs.  If you do it all at once it will turn into a 3000-line PR and nobody will review it.  Eventually, on the last chunk you'll just remove that line from the ignore list entirely when there are no more violations to fix. 


Let me know if you need any help, or ask in the Slack server.
comments: I included D107 in the list because it was part of the original plan in https://github.com/apache/airflow/issues/10742, but I'd like to argue for dropping it.    I don't feel that a docstring in every `__init__` method is helpful at all.  We're going to just copy/paste something like "Construct the {Class Name} object." a billion times.
Hi Ferruzzi, Can I take up this issue?
Feel Free.

Please do!    You don't even need to take the whole thing.  In fact, this is much easier to do in small chunks.   Fix all the D100 changes in one area, submit the PR, fix another area, submit that pr, etc. then move on to D102 and start over, etc.   Small PRs are easier for folks to review and more likely to get merged quickly.  

This could (should?) easily be a team project for a bunch of people, just take bites out of it when and where you can.

Feel free to hit me up on Slack if you need a hand getting started.
You know what, I'm just going to make the call and drop D107 off this list.  If someone wants to do it, they are welcome to but I won't consider it a requirement to close this project.  :+1:

After some discussion [on the mailing list ](https://lists.apache.org/thread/lcvocwxnrrzq9ofrg4b4hj0yvpzbnygf) it looks like D102 and D103 are minimal benefit, but we do have a few others we'd like to enable and a couple that are still being discussed.   I'll update the original description with details.

I can make a PR for:
- D214 | Consistent multi-line docstring indentation

> 
> * D214 | Consistent multi-line docstring indentation

Update: I believe `D214` can be marked as complete. I ran `ruff check` with the `D214` commented out in the ignore list and there were no additional errors. Verified that my environment was working by manually changing the spacing of a couple of function header docstrings to trigger errors.

Same with `D215`
Looks like you are correct, I'll check them off on the list here.  Can you submit a PR with those two removed from the ignore list so they are enabled, please?

issueDTO.title: Specific structure name can cause shadowing of globally defined lambda, causing "struct::operator()" to be called instead of "lambda::operator()"
comments: Agreed that this happens, but it sure feels like UB due to using the nonstandard identifier as the name of the structure.

TBH I found it by looking for a way to purposefully  break or alter expected lambda behaviour.

Main issue I see with it is that you can technically hijack code execution without ever having to call that struct explicitly in a codebase, anywhere. It just have to exists in some header, and only warning you get is one about using a '$' sign in a name.

ooof... this is troublesome.  Note this is not limited to just operator(), this could be ANYTHING we generate for lambdas that could be highjacked, including default, copy, and move construction, move/copy assignment, the `__invoke` function, destructor, and function-pointer conversion operators (of which we then have others based on calling convention).

We have basically 2 options here:

1- Break ABI and change the generated name of our lambdas (and anything else we generate with a '$' in the name).  We could change to `__$_<Num>` instead which is a reserved name in the C languages (note the leading double underscore).  At that point we should ALSO just hard-error on any attempt to name a struct (or perhaps a variable?  Or perhaps ANY identifier?) with a name of that pattern.

2- Names with `$` are implementation defined.  They are pretty common in generated code though, so changing our behavior on them is probably out of the question.  We could just change the 'implementation defined' behavior in this case and just hard-error on any attempt to declare a struct (or variable, or identifer, etc?) with a name that fits the troublesome pattern of `$_<NUMBERS>`.  This is perhaps going to break code for many, as this is perhaps a common pattern.  But the suggestion is that `$_0` would be ill-formed, and `$_0a` would be fine (since it isn't just `$_<NUMBERS>`).

@zygoloid for his opinion.  This is a tough one that I find myself saying "I need an adult" on.

Personally, I think we should take the ABI break in this case, but I don't think we need the hard error on attempts to name a struct with that pattern. Once we're using reserved identifiers, the user deciding to play shenanigans with their identifiers gets what they get because they hit UB when using the reserved identifier. I can live with "play silly games, win silly prizes" in that case, but it's less palatable when we're technically using an identifier that is not reserved.

> Personally, I think we should take the ABI break in this case, but I don't think we need the hard error on attempts to name a struct with that pattern. Once we're using reserved identifiers, the user deciding to play shenanigans with their identifiers gets what they get because they hit UB when using the reserved identifier. I can live with "play silly games, win silly prizes" in that case, but it's less palatable when we're technically using an identifier that is not reserved.

I think the hard error is DEFINITELY needed in either case.  The submitter alluded to how this is actually a pretty insidious attack vector (though they have to modify a header file).  Using reserved names is historically a fairly innocuous 'UB', this is a pretty horrifying 'UB', so the diagnostic is incredibly necessary.

This feels like it could be abused through third party headers and then makes taking over lightly maintained packages a more attractive target.

I would be okay w/ some sort of hard error.

> 1- Break ABI and change the generated name of our lambdas

I don't think this is a "real" ABI break. The Itanium ABI specifies a different mangling (used by Clang) for closure types that may be defined in more than one translation unit. The closure types that use the mangling affected by the current problem do not cross translation unit boundaries.

Indeed, we don't need a new mangling. We can just use the Itanium ABI mangling consistently.

> > 1- Break ABI and change the generated name of our lambdas
> 
> I don't think this is a "real" ABI break. The Itanium ABI specifies a different mangling (used by Clang) for closure types that may be defined in more than one translation unit. The closure types that use the mangling affected by the current problem do not cross translation unit boundaries.
> 
> Indeed, we don't need a new mangling. We can just use the Itanium ABI mangling consistently.

Ah, interesting.  That might actually be a pretty trivial fix to this. it might not actually have this problem at all, at the expense of slightly longer names.

https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/blob/f475ccd3794ebce22950b707ad390fae7e235b46/clang/lib/AST/ItaniumMangle.cpp#L1661-L1687

This whole block of code needs to be replaced by the content of the `if` statement, so that what's in the `if` block happens unconditionally.

Then there are about 120 test files to inspect (mostly codegen/filecheck tests) and fix.
It's tedious work but it should be fairly doable without much knowledge of clang internals.

So I am going to tentatively put a good-first-issue label on that if anyone is keen on trying that sort of tedious work. But you have been warned, it's not fun :D

Hi!

This issue may be a good introductory issue for people new to working on LLVM. If you would like to work on this issue, your first steps are:

1. Check that no other contributor has already been assigned to this issue. If you believe that no one is actually working on it despite an assignment, ping the person. After one week without a response, the assignee may be changed.
1. In the comments of this issue, request for it to be assigned to you, or just create a [pull request](https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/pulls) after following the steps below. [Mention](https://docs.github.com/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issues/linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue) this issue in the description of the pull request.
1. Fix the issue locally.
1. [Run the test suite](https://llvm.org/docs/TestingGuide.html#unit-and-regression-tests) locally. Remember that the subdirectories under `test/` create fine-grained testing targets, so you can e.g. use `make check-clang-ast` to only run Clang's AST tests.
1. Create a Git commit.
1. Run [`git clang-format HEAD~1`](https://clang.llvm.org/docs/ClangFormat.html#git-integration) to format your changes.
1. Open a [pull request](https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/pulls) to the [upstream repository](https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project) on GitHub. Detailed instructions can be found [in GitHub's documentation](https://docs.github.com/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pull-requests/proposing-changes-to-your-work-with-pull-requests/creating-a-pull-request). [Mention](https://docs.github.com/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issues/linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue) this issue in the description of the pull request.

If you have any further questions about this issue, don't hesitate to ask via a comment in the thread below.

> > [@zygoloid](https://github.com/zygoloid) for his opinion.
> 
> I don't think this is really much different from
> 
> int f();
> extern "C" int _Z1fv() { return 42; }
> // Returns 42.
> int main() { return f(); }
> 
> In both cases, the programmer stepped into a world of reserved / implementation-defined names, and managed to create a mangling collision. So they get what they asked for.
> 
> Per the Itanium ABI, names containing `$` are [reserved for private implementation use](https://itanium-cxx-abi.github.io/cxx-abi/abi.html#mangling-general), and while we provide a [non-conforming](https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/issues/128939) extension that allows `$`s to be used in identifiers, that doesn't change the fact that these names are reserved -- we don't guarantee they won't collide with other manglings. So I think the fact that mangling collisions can be created here is not a bug.
> 
> _However_, I think changing the mangling to use the standard mangling for a lambda is the right thing to do anyway -- it will improve the quality of demangled names when the mangling involves an internal-linkage lambda. As others have noted, this should only affect internal-linkage symbols, so it's not an ABI break.

I think there is a world of difference between 'implementation-defined' names and 'standard says using these are UB' names, but otherwise don't have an opinion contrary to this.

> I think there is a world of difference between 'implementation-defined' names and 'standard says using these are UB' names, but otherwise don't have an opinion contrary to this.

I don't think there's any UB here in either case. Use of names reserved by the C++ standard is IFNDR, in order to allow implementations to use them for whatever purpose they want (such as, as manglings). And names containing `$` are reserved by the Itanium ABI in order to allow implementations to use them for whatever purpose they want (such as, as manglings).

In addition to changing the mangling used for lambdas to be more demangler-friendly, I think we should turn off `-fdollars-in-identifiers` by default. Providing that mode makes sense given that GCC historically has done so, and there's probably some entrenched reliance on it in some codebases, but it seems like the wrong default -- especially since it's no longer even a conforming extension.

> I think we should turn off -fdollars-in-identifiers by default. Providing that mode makes sense given that GCC historically has done so, and there's probably some entrenched reliance on it in some codebases, but it seems like the wrong default -- especially since it's no longer even a conforming extension.

Strong +1 to this. There was sentiment to try that when this topic was discussed at today's C and C++ Language Working Group meeting.

> > I think we should turn off -fdollars-in-identifiers by default. Providing that mode makes sense given that GCC historically has done so, and there's probably some entrenched reliance on it in some codebases, but it seems like the wrong default -- especially since it's no longer even a conforming extension.
> 
> Strong +1 to this. There was sentiment to try that when this topic was discussed at today's C and C++ Language Working Group meeting.

I think it makes sense but I have a feeling folks are using it and it will take some time. I know LLDB uses the extension during expression evaluation but I don't think that particular case will be hard to deal with.

Hi! Just to be sure the idea is still as @cor3ntin mentioned: to update ItaniumMangle.cpp to drop the $_ fallback and switch to the ABI-compliant mangling, use lamda mangling for every lamda and then update all tests that depend on it?

If that's the case, I'd like to take the issue.
I believe that using the ABI mangling form for all closure types is still the plan.

hello,

i'm currently working on the change to replace all the old `$_` fallback with the proper ABI mangling. all unnamed types now go through `Ut`, and all lambdas through `Ul`, following the ABI.

most of the transition worked fine, but i started noticing weird behavior on some targets like windows, where the lambda numbering starts at 1 instead of 0. in some of these cases, lambdas seem to get treated as unnamed types, and that leads to inconsistencies in the mangling.

i'm still looking into it, but i'm starting to wonder if the goal was really to fully replace `$_` with `Ut`, even in cases where the type was originally a lambda

https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/compare/main...bonsthie:llvm-project:clang-mangle-lambda-abi-134049
Hi! I would like to work on this issue. Could you please assign it to me if it's still available? Thanks!

> Hi! I would like to work on this issue. Could you please assign it to me if it's still available? Thanks!

Typically we don't assign these as it discourages folks from picking them up if the initial person doesn't do anything with them for a while.  That said, feel free to work on it, and submit a PR.

repository.description: The LLVM Project is a collection of modular and reusable compiler and toolchain technologies.
repository.name: llvm-project

summary.main: The main goal of this issue is to fix the problem of the compiler using the structure's "operator()" instead of the one defined for a global lambda when a structure is defined with a naming convention used by the compiler for lambda expressions.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The issue requires validation of the naming convention used by the compiler for lambda expressions and the effect it has on the compiler's behavior. It also requires a change to the `ItaniumMangle.cpp` file to drop the `$_` fallback and switch to the ABI-compliant mangling.
summary.attemptedFixes: The issue has been discussed and some attempts have been made to fix it, but it's still open. Some people have suggested using the ABI mangling form for all closure types, and others have suggested turning off `-fdollars-in-identifiers` by default.
summary.otherNotes: This issue is about defining a structure with a naming convention used by the compiler for lambda expressions, which causes the compiler to use the structure's "operator()" instead of the one defined for a global lambda. The issue has been discussed at the C and C++ Language Working Group meeting and it's recommended to turn off `-fdollars-in-identifiers` by default. The plan is to update `ItaniumMangle.cpp` to drop the `$_` fallback and switch to the ABI-compliant mangling, use lambda mangling for every lambda, and then update all tests that depend on it.

issueDTO.title: `T.let` autofixes involving `T.attached_class` do not work, redux
issueDTO.description:
#### Input

[??? View on sorbet.run](https://sorbet.run/#%23%20typed%3A%20strict%0A%0Aclass%20IDLType%0A%20%20extend%20T%3A%3ASig%0A%0A%20%20sig%20%7Breturns%28String%29%7D%0A%20%20attr_reader%20%3At%0A%20%20sig%20%7Breturns%28T.untyped%29%7D%0A%20%20attr_reader%20%3Adefault%0A%0A%20%20sig%20%7Bparams%28t%3A%20String%2C%20default%3A%20T.untyped%29.void%7D%0A%20%20def%20initialize%28t%2C%20default%29%0A%20%20%20%20%40t%20%3D%20t%0A%20%20%20%20%40default%20%3D%20default%0A%20%20end%0A%20%20%0A%20%20BOOLEAN%20%3D%20new%28%22bool%22%2C%20false%29%0Aend)

```ruby
# typed: strict

class IDLType
  extend T::Sig

  sig {returns(String)}
  attr_reader :t
  sig {returns(T.untyped)}
  attr_reader :default

  sig {params(t: String, default: T.untyped).void}
  def initialize(t, default)
    @t = t
    @default = default
  end
  
  BOOLEAN = new("bool", false)
end
```

#### Observed output

```
editor.rb:17: Constants must have type annotations with T.let when specifying # typed: strict https://srb.help/7027
    17 |  BOOLEAN = new("bool", false)
                    ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  Autocorrect: Use -a to autocorrect
    editor.rb:17: Replace with T.let(new("bool", false), T.attached_class (of IDLType))
    17 |  BOOLEAN = new("bool", false)
                    ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
Errors: 1
```

The suggested autocorrect has incorrect syntax, and applying the autofix results in incorrect syntax.

#### Expected behavior

The autocorrect is correct.

I think this is #9268, just in a different context.

issueDTO.title: Create examples/topic_message.py
issueDTO.description:
🐣 Good First Issue
This issue is reserved for people who have never or only recently contributed to [Hiero](https://hiero.org/) or any open source project in general.
We know that creating a pull request (PR) is a major barrier for new contributors.
The goal of this issue and all other issues labeled by ['good first issue'](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+org%3Ahiero-ledger+archived%3Afalse+label%3A%22good+first+issue%22+) is to help you make your first contribution to Hiero.

🧠 Problem
src/hiero_sdk_python/consensus/topic_message.py defines the `TopicMessageChunk` class.  
It???s a core utility for working with Hedera Consensus Service (HCS)

Currently, we do not have an example demonstrating how to use this class.  
SDK users, AI models, and contributors would benefit from an example showing how to create, parse, and convert `TopicMessageChunk` objects.  

We **don???t** need an end-to-end example that interacts with the network or creates real topics ??? this class is purely for Info

def mock_consensus_response(message: bytes, seq: int = 1, is_chunked: bool = False, total_chunks: int = 1):
    """
    Create a lightweight mock of ConsensusTopicResponse.
    Only implements fields needed for TopicMessage.
    """
    class MockTS:
        def __init__(self, seconds: int):
            self.seconds = seconds
            self.nanos = 0

    class MockChunkInfo:
        def __init__(self):
            self.number = seq
            self.total = total_chunks
            self.initialTransactionID = None

        def HasField(self, field_name: str):
            return False

    class MockResponse:
        def __init__(self):
            self.message = message
            self.runningHash = b'\x00' * 48
            self.sequenceNumber = seq
            self.consensusTimestamp = MockTS(1736539200)
            self.chunkInfo = MockChunkInfo() if is_chunked else None

        def HasField(self, field_name: str):
            return self.chunkInfo is not None and field_name == "chunkInfo"

    return MockResponse()
```

issueDTO.title: Create examples/account_info.py
issueDTO.description:
🐣 Good First Issue
This issue is reserved for people who have never or only recently contributed to [Hiero](https://hiero.org/) or any open source project in general.
We know that creating a pull request (PR) is a major barrier for new contributors.
The goal of this issue and all other issues labeled by ['good first issue'](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+org%3Ahiero-ledger+archived%3Afalse+label%3A%22good+first+issue%22+) is to help you make your first contribution to Hiero.

🧠 Problem
src/hiero_sdk_python/account/account_info.py is the AccountInfo class.
It's a key class used in lots of other transactions, such as AccountInfoQuery.
We don't have an example for account_info.py likely because sdk users don't tend to use it -- instead we do have examples for AccountInfoQuery, for example.

However, sdk developers and AI's might benefit from understanding how to use AccountInfo class, therefore, we can benefit by adding an example to it.

💡 Solution
Add examples/account_info.py

Explain how to use the methods in AccountInfo class

This should demonstrate:
- [ ] How to manually create an AccountInfo instance (no network calls)
- [ ] How to populate key fields (account ID, Hbar balance, memo, owned NFTs, etc.)
- [ ] How to inspect or print the data

We don???t need an end-to-end example that connects to the Hedera network - because this doesn't really get used in a transaction ??? we just need a lightweight example showing how it works locally. That means we can mock data we need.

👩???💻 Implementation Steps
- [ ] Read src/hiero_sdk_python/account/account_info.py to understand the AccountInfo class and its attributes.
- [ ] Create examples/account_info.py
- [ ] Import the files you'll be using e.g.
from hiero_sdk_python.account.account_info import AccountInfo
from hiero_sdk_python.account.account_id import AccountId
- [ ] Implement simple functions like:

def create_mock_account_id() -> AccountId:
    """Create a mock AccountId."""
    return AccountId.from_string("0.0.1234")

def create_mock_public_key() -> PublicKey:
    """Generate a random ED25519 public key for demonstration."""
    return PublicKey.generate_ed25519()


def create_mock_balance() -> Hbar:
    """Return a mock account balance."""
    return Hbar(100)


def create_mock_expiration_time() -> Timestamp:
    """Return a sample expiration timestamp (arbitrary future date)."""
    return Timestamp(seconds=1736539200)


def create_mock_auto_renew_period() -> Duration:
    """Return a 90-day auto-renew period."""
    return Duration(seconds=7776000)


def create_mock_token_relationship() -> TokenRelationship:
    """Create a sample token relationship with a mock token."""
    token_id = TokenId.from_string("0.0.9999")
    return TokenRelationship(token_id=token_id, balance=50)

def build_mock_account_info() -> AccountInfo:
    """Construct a complete AccountInfo instance manually (no network calls)."""
    return AccountInfo()..

def print_account_info(info: AccountInfo) -> None:
    """Pretty-print key AccountInfo fields."""
    print("📜 AccountInfo Example (Mock Data)")
    print(f"Account ID: {info.account_id}")...

def main():
    """Run the AccountInfo example."""
    info = build_mock_account_info()
    print_account_info(info)


if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()



Use this as a rough guide - make it as a good as possible!

🧰 Requirements
- [ ] These examples must be able to be run! and must run! uv run examples/account_info.py works
- [ ] To help you identify if your methods are valid or invalid, please read docs/sdk_developers/pylance.md, and install pylance, this helps you spot errors. Refer to other /examples for each transaction type to see how to do the transactions you need - AI will get it wrong as the python sdk is slightly different to other sdks on the web!
- [ ] All functions you need to pull and use in this example must be called at the top of your script - make sure the path is correct (see project_structure.md), for example 

from hiero_sdk_python.tokens.token_associate_transaction import TokenAssociateTransaction

🧾 To Merge
In order for your PR to be able to be merged it needs:
- [ ] DCO and GPG key signing (git commit -S -s -m ".....") <- view docs/sdk_developers/signing.md
- [ ] A changelog entry <-- view docs/sdk_developers/changelog_entry.md

Read CONTRIBUTING.md for more information

??? Acceptance Criteria
- examples/account_info.py is created
- examples/account_info.py demonstrates methods in AccountInfo class
- All existing tests pass
- CHANGELOG entry added
- Commits are DCO + GPG signed

🙋????????? Next Steps
- Comment below to be assigned to this issue.
- Read the [CONTRIBUTING.md](https://github.com/hiero-ledger/hiero-sdk-python/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md)
- Fork the repository and start implementing.
- When ready, submit your PR!

issueDTO.title: Generate correct LD_FLAGS in the in-tree Kamaji image
issueDTO.description:
The in-tree Kamaji image is built with [this Dockerfile](https://github.com/cozystack/cozystack/blob/fbc2c45e7f1701e568de33ca926ae370930d9d91/packages/system/kamaji/images/kamaji/Dockerfile#L16), but the environment variables on the linked line are never actually set as build args.

#1338 fixes the more immediate issue of correcting the reference to the migration image (by default, generated from the git tag), but it would be helpful to properly populate the build metadata with all variables, perhaps using the git data of Cozystack's repository.

This is how the variables are calculated in upstream ([link](https://github.com/clastix/kamaji/blob/9ed00b98e601a9a4dc24d1f6da2222532bdd9544/Makefile#L203-L216)).

Similar logic could be implemented in the Makefile [for Kamaji](https://github.com/cozystack/cozystack/blob/7acd8a2a805c6f80d0ab020b163233f6ac332820/packages/system/kamaji/Makefile) or even in one of the [common includes](https://github.com/cozystack/cozystack/blob/7acd8a2a805c6f80d0ab020b163233f6ac332820/scripts/common-envs.mk), as something potentially useful for other components too.

issueDTO.title: [2.0] Add array, vector overloads to `createVector()` for consistency
issueDTO.description:
## [2.0] Add array, vector overloads to `createVector()` for consistency

Currently, vector operations often allow vectors to be specified in three ways: separate number arguments, a number array, or a vector instance. For example, `add()`, `sub()`, `mult()`, `div()`, and `rem()` all work this way. Ideally, we would always allow users to specify vectors in the same ways, so they don't need to guess which vector features accept which overloads. We already do this with color features like `fill()` and `stroke()`, which have a consistent set of overloads for specifying colors.

~~If adding array and vector overloads to `createVector()` sounds good, then we might also consider deprecating the `copy()` method, as it would no longer be needed: `v.copy()` could be replaced by `createVector(v)`.~~

**Edit:** We don't plan to deprecate `copy()`. See [this comment](https://github.com/processing/p5.js/issues/8157#issuecomment-3412088907).

Tasks:
- [ ] Reach consensus on adding overloads
- [ ] Implement and document
comments: Hii @GregStanton , i would love to work on this issue as my first contribution to the organization , could you please assign it to me ?
hi @GregStanton could you please assign me this issue ?

Hey @GregStanton,
I???d like to work on this issue.
We can use x instanceof p5.Vector to handle vector inputs and Array.isArray(x) for array inputs  inside createVector().
Could you please assign this issue to me so I can implement it?

+1 for allowing more overloads in `createVector`. I think `.copy()` maybe has enough of a separate use that it doesn't need to be deprecated though. Because vectors can't use regular math operations and rely on methods, users make extensive use of method chaining. A `.copy()` fits well into the feel of this, and having to wrap something in `createVector(...)` breaks that flow. Also using `createVector(...)` to create a copy, while it makes sense that it should work, feels like a slight indirection from an initial intent of "I want to create a copy of this object." Those are all fairly minor points, but between that and the heavy use of `.copy` in the wild, I'm not sure API simplification alone is strong enough to justify deprecation.

> I think .copy() maybe has enough of a separate use that it doesn't need to be deprecated though.

Excellent point, thanks Dave! I think that makes sense.
@GregStanton I'd like to work on this. Please assign it to me if it's available. Thanks

Hi @kunal-595, @ayushman1210, @lokesh-singhal, and @avinxshKD! Thank you all for offering to help. We first need to reach consensus on the changes that need to be made, since these would affect the user-facing API. However, I suspect adding overloads to `createVector()` will be uncontroversial, since it's for consistency with many other methods that already have the same overloads. If you think we don't need further consensus @davepagurek, then we could assign the issue to @kunal-595, as they were the first to volunteer.

Hi @GregStanton,

It's been 2-3 weeks since @kunal-595 volunteered, and I'd love to take on this issue if it's still available. I've reviewed the implementation approach (using `instanceof p5.Vector` and `Array.isArray()` checks) and I'm ready to implement, test, and document the changes.

@kunal-595 - Let me know if you're still working on this! Otherwise, I'm happy to proceed.

Hi @kunal-595! Thank you so much for your help and patience! I went ahead and assigned this issue to you, but I'm still hoping to get final approval for this change before implementation begins, since it affects the user-facing API. Do you think we can go forward on this @davepagurek?
This is good to go ahead, thanks @kunal-595!

Hi @GregStanton 👋,

I???m Shubham Kahar, and I???m interested in contributing to p5.js as a new contributor.  
I see this issue (#8157) is already assigned to @kunal-595 ??? just wanted to say this is a really interesting enhancement idea and aligns with my skills in JavaScript and vector math.  

I???d love to help with testing, documentation, or similar upcoming issues related to `p5.Vector` or p5.js 2.0 features.  
Please keep me in mind if there???s another related task or beginner-friendly issue I could take on. 😊

Thank you!

Hi @Shubhamkahar196! Thank you so much for your interest. You can follow the broader stabilization effort for `p5.Vector` in the umbrella issue #8149. All current issues can be found there, and additional planned issues will be posted there as well. All current issues that are unassigned are blocked, since we need final approval on some core policies before work can proceed. 

If you'd like to help out, the best thing you can do is to add a comment to the issues below, to indicate whether or not you support the proposals they contain. This will help the maintainer team to assess community consensus.

* #8153 
* #8155 
* #8159

Once these issues are approved, work will become possible on a range of existing and planned `p5.Vector` issues. (A fourth blocking issue is #8156, but public discussion of that issue is currently on hold, per the discussion in PR #8203).

We typically assign work on a first come, first served basis. If you'd like to be notified when new `p5.Vector` issues are posted, you can subscribe to the umbrella issue #8149. I also recommend subscribing to the sub-issues #8152, #8155, #8158, and #8159, as these may get new sub-issues of their own. Thanks again for your interest Shubham!

Hi everyone 👋  

I'm **Shubham Kahar**, a new contributor interested in helping with the **p5.Vector stabilization effort** for p5.js 2.0.  
I have experience in **JavaScript, vector math, and frontend development**, and I find this area particularly exciting because consistent and predictable vector behavior directly improves both performance and creative coding workflows.  

After reviewing the current proposals, I support the plan to:
- Standardize the `x`, `y`, `z`, and `w` fields for clear API consistency.
- Clarify or document the `dimensions` field to reduce ambiguity.
- Define a uniform policy for **dimension mismatches**, which will make function chaining and overloads far more robust.

I've subscribed to this umbrella issue and the related sub-issues (`#8153`, `#8155`, `#8159`, etc.) and will be happy to assist with **testing**, **documentation updates**, or **implementation** once the blocking issues are approved.  

Looking forward to learning from everyone here and contributing to the p5.js 2.0 evolution 🚀

issueDTO.title: Include target-type annotation in IngressClassParams
issueDTO.description:
**Is your feature request related to a problem?**
Currently, the only way to set the target-type is through the Ingress annotation: `alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/target-type: ip`

This makes each declarative Ingress unnecessarily verbose even when using a custom IngressClass + IngressClassParams.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Include it as a spec parameter within the IngressClassParams.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
This can also be an annotation on the custom IngressClass.

issueDTO.title: [Remove Vuetify from Studio] Saved searches dialogs
issueDTO.description: 🙂 Looking for an issue? Welcome! This issue is open for contribution. If this is the first time you???re requesting an issue, please: - **Read Contributing guidelines** carefully. **Pay extra attention to [Using generative AI](https://learningequality.org/contributing-to-our-open-code-base/#using-generative-ai)**. **Pull requests and comments that don???t follow the guidelines won???t be answered.** - **Confirm that you???ve read the guidelines** in your comment. Sub-issue of https://github.com/learningequality/studio/issues/5060. **Complexity: Low** ## Summary Migrate the following two dialogs in _Edit channel > Import from other channels_ from Vuetify to Kolibri Design System. Several `VList...` components, `VDivider`, and `MessageDialog` and `ActionLink` built with several Vuetify components, are currently used. **Remove these dependencies on Vuetify in this specific location by:** - Replace `MessageDialog` by `KModal` - Replace `ActionLink` with the most suitable [KDS button or link components](https://design-system.learningequality.org/buttons#) - Replace `VList...` and `VDivider` by custom styles and _semantic_ markup **Ensure that the dialog work exactly as before. Do not modify `ActionLink` or `MessageDialog`. Do not refactor any other areas.** ## How to get there - Login as `a@a.com` with password `a` - Go to _Channels > Imported channel_ - Click _Add > Import from channels_ - Search for _"video"_ - Click _Save search_ - Click _Saved searches_ - Click _Delete_ search icon ## Guidance - Find detailed guidance with many code examples in [KDS documentation](https://design-system.learningequality.org/) - Read [the project](https://github.com/learningequality/studio/issues/5060) for more useful references ## Out of Scope - Do not refactor any other areas of the codebase - Do not modify `ActionLink` or `MessageDialog` ## Expected UI/UX changes - Minor visual differences naturally stemming from the use of KDS ## Acceptance criteria These are general acceptance criteria for the project. For each sub-issue, consider which are relevant. **General** - [ ] The specification above is followed. - [ ] Except for "Expected UI/UX changes," there are no functional or visual differences in user experience. - [ ] There are no `::v-deep` or `/deep/` selectors. - [ ] All user interactions are manually tested with no regressions. - [ ] Pull request includes screenshots. **a11y and i18n** See [the project](https://github.com/learningequality/studio/issues/5060)'s "Guidance" for useful references. - [ ] Implementation meets a11y standards - [ ] All components are LTR and RTL compliant (preview with `pnpm run devserver` since `:hot` doesn't render RTL properly) - [ ] All user-facing strings are translated properly - [ ] The `notranslate` class been added to elements that shouldn't be translated by Google Chrome's automatic translation feature (e.g. user-generated text) - [ ] Mobile experience is reasonable **Unit tests** - [ ] If there is a unit test suite already, it is meaningfully updated (even if tests don't fail) - [ ] If there is no unit test suite, a new one is created. Do not use obsolete `@vue/test-utils` approach. Instead, use `@testing-library/vue` ([Vue Testing Library](https://kolibri-dev.readthedocs.io/en/develop/frontend_architecture/unit_testing.html)).

issueDTO.title: [Feature]: Frequency Weights Task
issueDTO.description:
### Problem Statement

When??save_interactions??is on in cognee.search, every query produces??CogneeUserInteraction??nodes plus edges such as??used_graph_element_to_answer. Currenlty there???s no easy way to count how often individual graph elements are touched, so we can???t surface frequency weights to downstream retrievers or analytics.

### Proposed Solution

Build a small??memify??pipeline that iterates over recent??CogneeUserInteraction??nodes, tallies usage counts for both the interaction edges and the target nodes, and writes those counts back as properties (e.g.??frequency_weight) via the graph adapters using the same ???get ??? tweak dict ??? add??? contract.

### Alternatives Considered

1. Store the counts in a separate relational table instead of on the graph objects (rejected: harder to keep in sync and add context for retrieval).
2. Recompute weights on the fly during retrieval (rejected: too slow for every request).

### Use Case

Various downstream use cases including: ranking frequently referenced entities higher during retrieval, adjusting scoring for completion strategies, and exposing usage metrics in dashboards or audits.

### Implementation Ideas

- Add a new cognee/task that reads??CogneeUserInteraction??nodes, counts how often each node/edge is used, and hands back updates.
- Make sure that the task can be used in a custom memify pipeline entry, just like the feedback enrichment flow does, so you can run the frequency update end-to-end.
- Create an e2e example and tests
- Ensure this works with both kuzu and neo4j backends

### Additional Context

- You can use the feedback_enrichment_minimal_example.py and memify_coding_agent_example.py to understand the patterns needed for a custom memify pipeline implementation
- Some minor tweaks on adapter level may be necessary, if they turn out to be a blocker creating an implementation that works with one graph engine backend is acceptable while opening a follow up issue for the adapter work on the other backend

### Pre-submission Checklist

- [x] I have searched existing issues to ensure this feature hasn't been requested already
- [x] I have provided a clear problem statement and proposed solution
- [x] I have described my specific use case
