issueDTO.title: Split examples/account_allowance_nft.py in two examples
issueDTO.description:
🧠 Problem
We have one file called examples/account_allowance_nft.py

This demonstrates two key transactions:
1. AccountAllowanceApproveTransaction ("""Approve NFT allowance for spender""")
2. AccountAllowanceDeleteTransaction ("""Delete NFT allowance""")

This means it is hard for a user to find the right example file for the transaction
src/hiero_sdk_python/account/account_allowance_approve_transaction_nft.py
src/hiero_sdk_python/account/account_allowance_delete_transaction_nft.py

It would be easier if we refactor examples/account_allowance_nft.py into:
examples/account_allowance_approve_transaction_nft.py
examples/account_allowance_delete_transaction_nft.py
Then users can easily find the correct example for the transaction they want to study or use.

💡 Solution
Refactor examples/account_allowance_nft.py into two files:
- examples/account_allowance_approve_transaction_nft.py
- examples/account_allowance_delete_transaction_nft.py

Note:
- Each file should be runnable and work (uv run examples/account_allowance_approve_transaction_nft.py or uv run examples/account_allowance_delete_transaction_nft.py) and actually work (you'll need to set up a Hedera portal account see README.md and create a .env file with your operator key and operator id in the format of .env.example)
- Each file should go through all the preliminary steps to be able to delete or approve a transaction for nft (such as set up env, create accounts, create nft token, mint nft token)

👩???💻 Implementation Steps
- [ ] Read src/hiero_sdk_python/account/account_allowance_approve_transaction_nft.py
- [ ] Read src/hiero_sdk_python/account/account_allowance_delete_transaction_nft.py
- [ ] Create examples/account_allowance_delete_transaction_nft.py, examples/account_allowance_delete_transaction_nft.py


For examples/account_allowance_approve_transaction_nft.py you'll likely need:
def setup_client():
    """Initialize and set up the client with operator account using env vars."""

def create_account(client):
    """Create a new Hedera account with initial balance."""

def create_nft_token(client):
    """Create a new non-fungible token (NFT)."""

def mint_nft(client, token_id, metadata_list):
    """Mint NFT(s) with metadata."""

def associate_token_with_account(client, account_id, private_key, token_id):
    """Associate a token with an account."""

def approve_nft_allowance(client, nft_id, owner_account_id, spender_account_id):
    """Approve NFT allowance for a spender."""

def transfer_nft_using_allowance(client, nft_id, spender_id, spender_key, receiver_id):
    """Transfer an NFT using approved allowance."""

def main():
    """
    End-to-end demonstration:
    1. Setup client
    2. Create spender and receiver accounts
    3. Create and mint NFT
    4. Associate token with receiver
    5. Approve allowance
    6. Transfer NFT via allowance
    """
Use this as a rough guide - make it as a good and as similar to the current example as possible!

For examples/account_allowance_delete_transaction_nft.py you'll likely need:
def setup_client():
    """Initialize and set up a Hedera client using environment variables."""

def create_account(client):
    """Create a new Hedera account."""

def create_nft_token(client):
    """Create a new non-fungible token (NFT)."""

def mint_nft(client, token_id, metadata):
    """Mint a single NFT."""

def associate_token_with_account(client, account_id, private_key, token_id):
    """Associate the token with a given account.""

def approve_nft_allowance(client, nft_id, owner_id, spender_id):
    """Approve an NFT allowance for a spender."""


def delete_nft_allowance(client, nft_id, owner_id):
    """Delete an NFT allowance for all serials."""


def verify_allowance_removed(client, nft_id, spender_id, spender_key, receiver_id):
    """Try to transfer NFT after allowance removal (should fail)."""

def main():
    """
    End-to-end demonstration of NFT allowance deletion:
    1. Create spender and receiver accounts
    2. Create and mint NFT
    3. Approve NFT allowance
    4. Delete the NFT allowance
    5. Verify spender can no longer transfer
    """

🧰 Requirements
- [ ] These examples must be able to be run! and must run!
- [ ] To help you identify if your methods are valid or invalid, please read docs/sdk_developers/pylance.md, and install pylance, this helps you spot errors. Refer to other /examples for each transaction type to see how to do the transactions you need - AI will get it wrong as the python sdk is slightly different to other sdks on the web!
- [ ] All functions you need to pull and use in this example must be called at the top of your script - make sure the path is correct (see project_structure.md), for example 

from hiero_sdk_python.tokens.token_associate_transaction import TokenAssociateTransaction

🧾 To Merge
In order for your PR to be able to be merged it needs:
- [ ] DCO and GPG key signing (git commit -S -s -m ".....") <- view docs/sdk_developers/signing.md
- [ ] A changelog entry <-- view docs/sdk_developers/changelog_entry.md

Read CONTRIBUTING.md for more information

??? Acceptance Criteria
- examples/account_allowance_nft.py is deleted
- examples/account_allowance_approve_transaction_nft.py exists
- examples/account_allowance_delete_transaction_nft.py exists
- Files run successfully against Hedera Testnet
- Functionality and good stuff about account_allowance_nft is preserved
- All existing tests pass
- CHANGELOG entry added
- Commits are DCO + GPG signed

🙋????????? Next Steps
- Comment below to be assigned to this issue.
- Read the [CONTRIBUTING.md](https://github.com/hiero-ledger/hiero-sdk-python/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md)
- Fork the repository and start implementing.
- When ready, submit your PR!

issueDTO.title: FP8 Blockwise Training Tracker
issueDTO.description:
We want to support DeepSeekV3-style FP8 blockwise training in torchao for both dense and MoE models. 

# Support for dense models (linears)
We can extend the fp8 blockwise training prototype for dense models [here](https://github.com/pytorch/ao/blob/main/torchao/prototype/blockwise_fp8_training/linear.py) which has the core functionality complete, but performance is unoptimized.

The work has been broken down into the following tasks, which anyone is free to work on:

- [x] Functionality
    - [x] 1x128 quantization for LHS activations, write to row major layout
    - [x] 128x1 quantization for RHS activations, write to col major layout
    - [x] 128x128  quantization for weights, write to col major layout
    - [x] 1x128 @ 128x128 gemm, use for:
         - [x] `output = input @ weight.t()`
         - [x] `dgrad = grad_output @ weight`
    - [x] 1x128 @ 128x1 gemm, use for:
         - [x]  `wgrad = grad_output.t() @ input`
    - [x] Autograd function implementing forward and backward
    - [ ] DTensor handling for TP support
    - [ ] Custom ops around all custom kernels for `torch.compile` composability
    - [ ] Tests for FSDP, TP
    - [x] `quantize_` model conversion api peforming module swap of nn.Linear to FP8BlockwiseLinear (wraps autograd func)
    - [ ] [P1] fp8 blockwise all-gather for FSDP (would need to ensure weight-shards are padded to be divisible by 128x128 blocks, design TBD)
- [ ] Performance
    - [ ] all quantization kernels run at 80%+ of peak achievable memory bandwidth on Hopper
         - [ ] benchmark scripts for each quantization kernel 
    - [ ] all gemm kernels run at 80%+ of peak achievable TFLOPs/sec on Hopper 
         - [ ] benchmark scripts for each gemm
- [ ] Integration into torchtitan
    - [ ] Validate loss convergence virtually identical to bf16 for 3k+ steps on full size Llama3 8b/70b 
    - [ ] Validate e2e throughput (TPS) improvement in same training run as above 
- [ ] Documentation
    - [ ] README
    - [ ] torchao docsite  
- [ ] Migrate out of prototype directory, integrate into `torchao.float8` module 

# Support for MoE layers (grouped GEMMs)
We can extend the low precision MoE training code [here](https://github.com/pytorch/ao/tree/main/torchao/prototype/moe_training) to support fp8 blockwise by doing the following: 
- [ ] Functionality
    - [ ] Quantization 
        - [ ] 128x128 quantization compatible with 3d expert weights, write to per-expert col major layout (e.g. shape (E,N,K) with strides (N*K,1,N)) 
        - [ ] Per-token group 1x128 scale conversion where group boundaries are along K/contracting dim
            - [ ] Alternative: pad token group alignment to multiples of 128, like is done in torchtitan [here](https://github.com/pytorch/torchtitan/blob/bb308da6bd85ed31a2670993326322e3631af436/torchtitan/models/moe/utils.py#L52))
        - [ ]  Per-token group 128x1 scale conversion where group boundaries are along K/contracting dim
            - [ ] Alternative: pad token group alignment to multiples of 128, like is done in torchtitan [here](https://github.com/pytorch/torchtitan/blob/bb308da6bd85ed31a2670993326322e3631af436/torchtitan/models/moe/utils.py#L52))
    - [ ] GEMMs 
         - [ ] 1x128 @ 128x128 scaled grouped gemm
             - [ ] `output = input @ weight.transpose(-2,-1)`
             - [ ] `dgrad = grad_output @ weight`
         - [ ] 1x128 @ 128x1 scaled grouped gemm
             - [ ] `wgrad = grad_output.transpose(-2,-1) @ input`
    - [ ] Autograd function implementing forward and backward with dynamic quant on inputs (see [mxfp8 example](https://github.com/pytorch/ao/blob/01374eb58a4f9ba52780efbe0ef4e056e36d338c/torchao/prototype/moe_training/scaled_grouped_mm.py#L284))
    - [ ] DTensor handling for TP support
    - [ ] Custom ops around all custom kernels for `torch.compile` composability
    - [ ] Tests for FSDP, TP
    - [ ] `quantize_` model conversion api peforming module swap of nn.Linear to FP8BlockwiseLinear (wraps autograd func)
- [ ] Performance
    - [ ] all quantization kernels run at 80%+ of peak achievable memory bandwidth on Hopper
         - [ ] benchmark scripts for each quantization kernel 
    - [ ] all gemm kernels run at 80%+ of peak achievable TFLOPs/sec on Hopper 
         - [ ] benchmark scripts for each gemm
- [ ] Integration into torchtitan
    - [ ] Validate loss convergence virtually identical to bf16 for 3k+ steps on full size DeepSeekV3 671b 
    - [ ] Validate e2e throughput (TPS) improvement in same training run as above 
 - [ ] Documentation
    - [ ] README
    - [ ] torchao docsite
comments:
### Dense model Gemms benchmark

I'm getting an error running the two benchmark scripts for the the Gemms ([here](https://github.com/pytorch/ao/tree/main/benchmarks/prototype/blockwise_fp8_training)) as `torch._scaled_mm` only supports Row or TensorWise scaling, but not the blockwise scaling we are after

I also tried this with the the nightly version of Pytorch as @vkuzo suggested [elsewhere](https://github.com/pytorch/ao/pull/3306#issuecomment-3500070451) (for a diferent problem) to use the most recent `_scaled_mm`  in case the update to numerics might also solve this

Lmk if you have any suggestions if I'm missing something or otherwise how to tackle this:
1. Remove `torch._scaled_mm` from the benchmarking and just compare it to the bf16/torch.mm method
2. Figure out another thing to benchmark against

issueDTO.title: User profile page (detailed user info)
issueDTO.description:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
nothing about user account except account name can be seen.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
i would like if there is user description like in hot tasking manager which will tell user about how many datasets they have collected data from along with other features like their roles and personal information
comments:
We store very little user info in the database. 

OSM login also doesn't provide much. 

However we can track changesets in the OSM API and filter by user, so we could include info on submissions and finalised OSM data in a dashboard.

We have designed initial design of user page.

![image](https://github.com/hotosm/fmtm/assets/97273021/2439bc45-9af1-4ee3-8194-1a267d6bb760)
![image](https://github.com/hotosm/fmtm/assets/97273021/68ee337a-a161-46a9-a53a-3fcb330a2f49)

https://www.figma.com/proto/GUKooEhrNwHFTaAaEHxUcS/FMTM?type=design&node-id=2051-2511&t=fzNuMSDzvVQfYUZC-0&scaling=scale-down&page-id=1003%3A767&starting-point-node-id=1016%3A4521&show-proto-sidebar=1

@spwoodcock

I think you may need to rethink the Task Submitted section.

If you are going to list all the tasks that an individual has submitted then that could run into hundreds for a dedicated mapper.

Looks very nice @manjitapandey 👍

Good point @RAytoun !
Perhaps we either need pagination, or we limit this to something like Tasks Submitted in the past 30 days
I would prefer to limiting the task submission table to 30 days time period.
Hey @spwoodcock, I'm happy to work on this. Please could you assign this to me?
Hi @edenxcodes , Have you got chance to start the user profile page? Please reach out if you have any queries or have confusion at any point.

Thanks @manjitapandey 🙏

Eden and I have a call today to discuss some debugging on his setup 😄

How's it going @edenxcodes?

Can I help with anything / is there anything you would like to discuss?

No worries if you haven't had time to work on it! Let us know where you are it 😄
Hi @spwoodcock 😅, thanks for reaching out. I have struggled with a few things but I'm working to debug them myself. I guess I might need a call with you soon!
Hi @edenxcodes , Have you got chance to work on this page?? You can create a draft PR and still get your work going.

Hello @manjitapandey, yes I'm working on it. I had a call with Sam on Friday 14th, and we discussed some of the challenges I had on the project. I hope to make a draft PR soon. Thanks for checking in!
Hi @edenxcodes do you have any blocker working on?? We are thinking of shipping this feature asap.

As far as I can tell, there is not a lot of useful user data in Field-TM database.
So, I was considering getting all projects of a user, gathering their submissions from ODK and then making the required calculations in chunks to not use lots of resources.
Maybe we could make it a scheduled task and store the user stats in a separate table and recalculate and refresh the data maybe once a day for active users only.

We can't use the projects from s3 because currently it doesn't contain all submissions (for private, archived, completed projects).

@spwoodcock @Sujan167

Sounds like it could be good 👍

I dont think stats are that important as a starting point though.

The most useful data is which projects the user has contributed to, and which projects they have a specific role assigned for, so they can click through to the specific projects

I noticed that the submissions we get from odk don't have a unique field we can use to identify the user. The username isn't unique, since we added google login functionality for the mappers. Other fields such as submitterId and submitterName have the same data regardless of who made the submission. Even if we fixed the submitterId and submitterName being the same issue or added another field like user_sub in the submission, we still wouldn't be able to map the user data correctly for older submissions. This is for the user details page. What do you suggest we should do? @spwoodcock

> I noticed that the submissions we get from odk don't have a unique field we can use to identify the user. The username isn't unique, since we added google login functionality for the mappers. Other fields such as submitterId and submitterName have the same data regardless of who made the submission. Even if we fixed the submitterId and submitterName being the same issue or added another field like user_sub in the submission, we still wouldn't be able to map the user data correctly for older submissions. This is for the user details page. What do you suggest we should do? @spwoodcock 

Let's find a good option to indetify a unique user going forward, but dont worry too much about old projects. If we can't get the info we need, just return nothing (and we display something like: project does not support user statistics).

The deviceId for submissions should at least be unique. The username field should probably be populated with the entire user sub, and not just the user id (that was an oversight on our behalf)

If we send user sub in username field, there will be a problem for the users who want to have their contributions tracked without logging in. If they try to use other's QR code, the contribution will go to the person who shared the QR code. If they use `ODK Collect` and try to update their username, they won't know their sub either. During `Suryodaya` project, many users found it difficult to login. Some didn't even have a Google account, either.

So a possible solution might be to force every user to log in, in order to send submissions which can be tracked user wise.

Some users used their family member's device by changing their accounts. So, `deviceId` isn't reliable either.

cc: @spwoodcock @ramyaragupathy @manjitapandey @Sujan167

> If we send user sub in username field, there will be a problem for the users who want to have their contributions tracked without logging in. If they try to use other's QR code, the contribution will go to the person who shared the QR code. If they use `ODK Collect` and try to update their username, they won't know their sub either. During `Suryodaya` project, many users found it difficult to login. Some didn't even have a Google account, either.
> 
> So a possible solution might be to force every user to log in, in order to send submissions which can be tracked user wise.
> 
> Some users used their family member's device by changing their accounts. So, `deviceId` isn't reliable either.
> 
> cc: @spwoodcock @ramyaragupathy @manjitapandey @Sujan167 

Valuable feedback, thanks!

I agree if the user doesn't login then we can't provide stats. We should only be interested in generating stats for logged in users

issueDTO.title: Updater on Windows: close and install - don't restart
issueDTO.description:
On Windows. 
I'm finding myself in the need to run `update.install(bytes)` without wanting the installer to restart my app. 

**Use case**: I'm installing updates from `RunEvent::ExitRequested` so that I don't have to interrupt the user. 

The app checks and downloads the update in the background and then installs it when the user either clicks on a `Relaunch to apply update` button (and the app correctly restarts) OR when the user closes the app, where I don't want to have it restarted. 

Ideally there would be something like a `Update::install_without_restart` function or something to set on `Update`, and not so much something on `UpdateBuilder` as I don't know how the update will be installed when I "build" it. 

## Additional Context

I've seen a [`/R` flag](https://github.com/tauri-apps/plugins-workspace/blob/ea172bfa3cef8ba4021095a033d1a6f152c28c3e/plugins/updater/src/config.rs#L39-L40) is [passed to the NSIS installer](https://github.com/tauri-apps/plugins-workspace/blob/ea172bfa3cef8ba4021095a033d1a6f152c28c3e/plugins/updater/src/updater.rs#L765C21-L765C33), and a [`AUTOLAUNCHAPP=True` to MSI](https://github.com/tauri-apps/plugins-workspace/blob/ea172bfa3cef8ba4021095a033d1a6f152c28c3e/plugins/updater/src/updater.rs#L787).

issueDTO.title: deprecate DatetimeInfoExtractor
issueDTO.description:
What?
During work [on](https://github.com/azukds/tubular/issues/488), it became apparent that this transformer is doing quite a lot. The outcome of this issue was to add a separate transformer focused on extracting raw numeric datetime  values, like dt.month.

This new transformer does call into question whether DatetimeInfoExtractor needs to be maintained, as it now doesn't provide much new functionality over the new transformer followed  by MappingTransformer. It mainly just provides easy access to some common mappings for the outputs of the new transformer. 

My suggestion is that we move the default mappings out of DatetimeInfoExtractor and deprecate, and include a deprecation warning that directs users to replace this transformer with the new transformer followed by MappingTransformer using the default datetime mappings.

Why?
streamline package

How?
see above, will be dependant on the linked issue

issueDTO.title: Make improvements to our `package-healthcheck` workflow
issueDTO.description:
Currently our [`package-healthcheck`](https://github.com/kubetail-org/kubetail/blob/main/.github/workflows/package-healthcheck.yml) workflow accomplishes the very helpful task of checking the health and current version of our [published packages](https://github.com/kubetail-org/kubetail?tab=readme-ov-file#option-1-package-managers). We would like to make these upgrades to the workflow to make it even better:

* Add package checks for linux arm64
* Add package checks for macos-26, macos-15-intel
* Add package checks for windows-arm
* Do real install with macports instead of just checking the repo (see [`publish-macports.yml`](https://github.com/kubetail-org/kubetail/blob/main/.github/workflows/publish-macports.yml)
* Separate winget/chocolatey/scoop install code from each other

It would also be helpful to identify next steps for the workflow that we can work on in the future.

issueDTO.title: Inequalities between pointers do not work
comments: I guess the problem is that we have turned things into IntDomain elements when the comparison gets called, and we return `top` when getting an int domain representation of an pointer.

Stripping the casts like we do for `Eq`/`Ne` is the easy part. The hard part is that `evalbinop_base` simply doesn't have cases for `Lt`/... on the address domain at all.
For `Eq`/`Ne` those are implemented via `AD.meet` which has special behavior via `semantic_equal` of addresses and offsets. There's no easy way to get inequalities out of that. The many layers from address sets to offsets need new semantic comparison operators. Eventually it should boil down to `Offset.MakeLattice.to_index` like `semantic_equal`, but the intermediate layers need to handle ambiguous points-to-sets (like the special `AD.meet`) and all pairs of `Addr`/`NullPtr`/`UnknownPtr`/`StrPtr`.

repository.description: Static analysis framework for C
repository.name: analyzer

summary.main: Inequalities between pointers do not work, leading to imprecision in SV-COMP tasks. The issue is with the function glob2, where the loop bound pathlim is pathbuf[1], but p runs past it, and with unrolling, the loop body where p ??? pathbuf[2] is not dead.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The length of pathbuf is 2, and the loop should stop at index 1. However, since this is unknown due to the pointer inequality not working, we fail to verify memsafety.
summary.attemptedFixes: Stripping the casts like we do for Eq/Ne is the easy part. The hard part is that evalbinop_base simply doesn't have cases for Lt/... on the address domain at all.
summary.otherNotes: The problem is that pointer inequalities are not working due to turning things into IntDomain elements when the comparison gets called, and returning top when getting an int domain representation of a pointer. The hard part is that evalbinop_base doesn't have cases for Lt/... on the address domain at all. The intermediate layers need to handle ambiguous points-to-sets and all pairs of Addr/NullPtr/UnknownPtr/StrPtr.

issueDTO.title: Atomic operations support
issueDTO.description:
There are multiple families of atomic operations:
- [ ] GCC `__sync` builtins: https://gcc.gnu.org/onlinedocs/gcc/_005f_005fsync-Builtins.html.
- [ ] C11: https://en.cppreference.com/w/c/thread#Atomic_operations.

There are three aspects in which to improve precision:
- [ ] Not emitting race warnings for accesses by atomic functions. #521 only applies to variables with C11 `_Atomic`, but not the `__sync` builtins used by various benchmarks. There should probably still be access events for them, but with an additional atomicity flag to exclude them from racing.
- [ ] Performing the respective operations on values as opposed to invalidating (suggested in https://github.com/goblint/analyzer/pull/996#discussion_r1143014379).
- [ ] Treating limited statements on atomic variables as atomic altogether:
    > Built-in [increment and decrement operators](https://en.cppreference.com/w/c/language/operator_incdec) and [compound assignment](https://en.cppreference.com/w/c/language/operator_assignment) are read-modify-write atomic operations with total sequentially consistent ordering (as if using [memory_order_seq_cst](https://en.cppreference.com/w/c/atomic/memory_order)).
comments:
There's now progress in sv-benchmarks to replace some `__VERIFIER_atomic`s with C11/GCC atomics:
* https://gitlab.com/sosy-lab/benchmarking/sv-benchmarks/-/merge_requests/1548,
* https://gitlab.com/sosy-lab/benchmarking/sv-benchmarks/-/merge_requests/1549,
* https://gitlab.com/sosy-lab/benchmarking/sv-benchmarks/-/merge_requests/1554,
* https://gitlab.com/sosy-lab/benchmarking/sv-benchmarks/-/merge_requests/1556,
* https://gitlab.com/sosy-lab/benchmarking/sv-benchmarks/-/merge_requests/1557.

I haven't checked how much it affects our results, but we might have to also adapt a bit to not lose our edge for superficial reasons.

repository.description: Static analysis framework for C
repository.name: analyzer

summary.main: Implement atomic operations support in the analyzer, including support for GCC `__sync` builtins and C11 atomic operations, and improving precision in three aspects.
summary.validationOrRequirement: Implementing atomic operations support, specifically not emitting race warnings for accesses by atomic functions, performing operations on values, and treating limited statements on atomic variables as atomic.
summary.attemptedFixes: None mentioned in the issue description.
summary.otherNotes: There's now progress in sv-benchmarks to replace some `__VERIFIER_atomic`s with C11/GCC atomics: https://gitlab.com/sosy-lab/benchmarking/sv-benchmarks/-/merge_requests/1548, https://gitlab.com/sosy-lab/benchmarking/sv-benchmarks/-/merge_requests/1549, https://gitlab.com/sosy-lab/benchmarking/sv-benchmarks/-/merge_requests/1554, https://gitlab.com/sosy-lab/benchmarking/sv-benchmarks/-/merge_requests/1556, https://gitlab.com/sosy-lab/benchmarking/sv-benchmarks/-/merge_requests/1557. We might have to adapt to not lose our edge for superficial reasons.

issueDTO.title: Dedicated Context Constructions for Termination Analysis
issueDTO.description:
As #1413 and the associated regressions show, having more precise (and potentially fewer) contexts is not always beneficial when attempting to prove termination of recursive programs (when we have partial contexts).

It would be interesting to evaluate new constructions here and how helpful they are for the SV-COMP termination categories. Ideas may be:

- Baseline: Experiment with full context for all recursive functions in the termination category (disabling the autotuner that disables interval and interval set contexts in recursive calls)
- A flavor of context gas (#1340) that starts out with full context and then switches to no-interval in context for recursive procedures
- A dedicated construction to always unroll recursion k-deep (via contexts) where k could, e.g., be a function of the magnitude of the argument given to procedures identified as recursive (might capture quite a few SV-COMP style tasks).
- ...

These are quite disconnected from everything else, and could, e.g., be given to Master's students.

repository.name: analyzer

summary.main: Evaluate new constructions for termination analysis of recursive programs in SV-COMP categories, exploring different approaches and their effectiveness.
summary.validationOrRequirement: No specific validations or requirements mentioned.
summary.attemptedFixes: None mentioned in the description or comments.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is related to #1413 and its associated regressions, and is also connected to SV-COMP termination categories. It mentions potential ideas for new constructions, including baseline, flavor of context gas, and dedicated construction for unrolling recursion.

issueDTO.title: More precise float domain for `float` and `double`
issueDTO.description:
In these cases we can have a more precise interval domain `(float option * float option) option * bool` where the inner values are for the interval (None for the infinite cases), and the outer bool represents whether NaN is a possible value or not.

Currently we cannot benefit from guards such `if(5.0f < x && x < 10.0f)`: For the first part, we cannot express that x needs to be betweeen 5 and +Infinity, as our domain expresses this as `T`.

Such a treatment is only possible when we know that the type we are using to represent a value matches the concrete one. If we will participate in SV-COMP 24, that might yield some improvement in the floats category.

issueDTO.title: Proposal: Add `information_schema.fe_threads` to expose FE thread information
issueDTO.description:
## Summary

Add a new schema table, `information_schema.fe_threads`, to expose Frontend (FE) thread runtime details???mirroring the existing `information_schema.be_threads`. This enables SQL???level inspection of FE concurrency, CPU consumption, and blocking states without attaching external profilers.

## Motivation

- Today we have `information_schema.be_threads` for BE introspection but no FE equivalent.
- FE issues (e.g., scheduler stalls, high CPU from RPC pools, metadata refresh contention) are hard to diagnose without JMX, profilers, or JVM attach permissions.
- A first???class schema table brings **parity** between FE and BE observability and makes routine diagnosis scriptable via SQL.

## Scope & Non???Goals

- **In scope**: Read???only FE thread snapshot data, lightweight and safe by default.
- **Out of scope**: Live sampling profiles, heap/lock graphs, automatic kill/management of threads.

## Proposed Design

### Table

`information_schema.fe_threads`

### Columns (initial)

| Column          | Type    | Description                                                                                   |
| --------------- | ------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| `FE_ID`         | BIGINT  | ID of the FE node reporting (same semantics as other FE tables).                              |
| `GROUP`         | VARCHAR | Logical group inferred from thread name/pool (e.g., `scheduler`, `rpc-pool`, `stat-refresh`). |
| `NAME`          | VARCHAR | JVM thread name.                                                                              |
| `TID`           | BIGINT  | Native thread id (if available via `ThreadInfo`/OS MBean).                                    |
| `STATE`         | VARCHAR | Thread state: `NEW`, `RUNNABLE`, `BLOCKED`, `WAITING`, `TIMED_WAITING`, `TERMINATED`.         |
| `CPU_TIME_MS`   | BIGINT  | Cumulative CPU time from `ThreadMXBean`.                                                      |
| `USER_TIME_MS`  | BIGINT  | User CPU time from `ThreadMXBean`.                                                            |
| `BLOCKED_COUNT` | BIGINT  | Times the thread has been blocked.                                                            |
| `WAITED_COUNT`  | BIGINT  | Times the thread has waited.                                                                  |
|                 |         |                                                                                               |

> Column set is intentionally close to `be_threads` for familiarity and scripting reuse.

### Example queries

```sql
-- Top hot FE threads by CPU
SELECT *
FROM information_schema.fe_threads
ORDER BY CPU_TIME_MS DESC
LIMIT 20;

-- Identify blocking hotspots
SELECT NAME, STATE, BLOCKED_COUNT, WAITED_COUNT
FROM information_schema.fe_threads
WHERE STATE IN ('BLOCKED', 'WAITING')
ORDER BY BLOCKED_COUNT DESC
LIMIT 50;
```

repository.description: The world's fastest open query engine for sub-second analytics both on and off the data lakehouse. With the flexibility to support nearly any scenario, StarRocks provides best-in-class performance for multi-dimensional analytics, real-time analytics, and ad-hoc queries. A Linux Foundation project.
repository.name: starrocks

summary.main: Add a new schema table, `information_schema.fe_threads`, to expose Frontend (FE) thread runtime details, mirroring the existing `information_schema.be_threads`. This enables SQL-level inspection of FE concurrency, CPU consumption, and blocking states without attaching external profilers.
summary.validationOrRequirement: Read-only FE thread snapshot data, lightweight and safe by default. Out of scope: live sampling profiles, heap/lock graphs, automatic kill/management of threads.
summary.attemptedFixes: None mentioned
summary.otherNotes: The proposed design includes a table named `information_schema.fe_threads` with columns for FE node ID, group, name, thread ID, state, CPU time, user time, blocked count, and waited count. The table is designed to be similar to `information_schema.be_threads` for familiarity and scripting reuse. Example queries are provided for identifying hot FE threads by CPU and blocking hotspots.

issueDTO.title: frontend: joystick: add a "reverse" mode
issueDTO.description:
### Current behaviour

Controls are currently fixed to "forwards" style. That's fine for most users, but if a vehicle [is reversible](https://discuss.bluerobotics.com/t/reverse-rov-controls-in-qgc/11932) it can be convenient to reverse the controls.

That's technically already possible via a workaround, by duplicating a functions mapping and swapping just the desired axes, but then it's awkward to swap between them (they need to open the joystick configuration to do so, instead of just pressing a button), swapping mappings is currently [confusing](https://github.com/bluerobotics/cockpit/issues/1824), there's needless extra work to keep the button mappings in sync, and it loses the user a mapping set.

### Expected or desired behaviour

Add a "reverse" Action, to reverse the user's motion control inputs:

1. A minimal implementation could just directly reverse all the axis mapping ranges except for Z, although there may be some confusion if that change is persistent across reboots.
2. To make it more configurable the reversing status could be defined by a boolean data-lake variable (with optional value persistence?), which would then also integrate nicely with #1759, in future development.
    - Variables can be toggled, or controlled as momentary switches (e.g. while holding a joystick button), which opens some additional usage possibilities
    - This has the side benefit that it could be used to trigger an automatic switch between Views (e.g. to one with a rear-facing camera as the main display), via a custom Action
3. If we want to provide more control to the user we could allow them to select which axes are "reversible", as part of the joystick configuration interface.
    - This perhaps lends itself more into expansion to areas like [dynamic axis switching](https://discuss.bluerobotics.com/t/is-custom-dynamic-axis-switching-possible/12459)

### Prerequisites

- [x] I have checked to make sure that a similar request has not already been filed or fixed.

issueDTO.title: Distinguish between touch and mouse to pan the Flickable
issueDTO.description:
Currently, Flickable::interactive means that you can pan it with the mouse press and drag.
It is always possible to pan it with the mouse wheel.
We should in fact make sure that you can always pan it with touch event even when interactive is false.

perhaps `interactive` property should be deprecated and renamed something like `pan-with-mouse`.
Alternative is an interaction mode enum that can be  None, Normal, WithMouse.


(Relates a bit to https://github.com/slint-ui/slint/issues/2260)
comments:
Tasks:

 1. Add touch events to `slint::platform::WindowEvent`  (would be nice to support multi-touch when we're on it so  https://github.com/slint-ui/slint/issues/834 can be implemented on top) 
 2. For now, these touch event need to be sent as `i_slint_core::input::MouseEvent` to the runtime, but there one can add a flag to distinguish them
 3. Send touch event from, at least, our winit backend.  (Qt and Linuxkms will have to support them as well enventually)
 4. The flickable can use the flag in `MouseEvent` to do something different
 5. Also in `.slint`'s `TouchArea`, the `PointerEvent` could get a way to distinguish touch and mouse.
Step 1. and 2. and 3. (the winit part) from my previous comment were done in #9858

Remaining part should not be too difficult to implement either.



Proposal:
 - In Flickable: deprecate `interactive` to rename it `mouse-drag-pan-enabled` (same name as what ScrollView has) defaults to true. (It's easy to deprecate builtin property, See Rectangle::color, it's just an alias)
 - When that property is false, interaction with the mouse is disabled, but interaction with touch events continues.  (This is easy to do now with the new flag from #9858)
 - (maybe) Add `enabled` property in Flickable, when false, any interaction with anything is disabled
 - `ScrollView::mouse-drag-pan-enabled` is linking to it's inner Flickable's mouse-drag-pan-enabled, but defaults to false in all style (Only material style needs change)

repository.description: Slint is an open-source declarative GUI toolkit to build native user interfaces for Rust, C++, JavaScript, or Python apps.
repository.name: slint

summary.main: Distinguish between touch and mouse to pan the Flickable, make sure touch event can be used even when interactive is false
summary.validationOrRequirement: deprecate `interactive` property and rename it to `mouse-drag-pan-enabled`, add `enabled` property in Flickable if needed
summary.attemptedFixes: Tasks 1-3 from previous comment were done in #9858, Remaining part should not be too difficult to implement.
summary.otherNotes: This issue relates to https://github.com/slint-ui/slint/issues/2260

issueDTO.title: Evaluate Long Term Storage Implications of Keeping Templates Around (128GB SSD)
issueDTO.description:
The Workstation tries to manage distro upgrades for templates used by the workstation directly, but **it doesn't remove most of them**. Combined with the fact that the workstation aims to avoid doing clean Qubes re-installs for the purpose of upgrading. 

The purpose of this issue is to evaluate **what long-term storage implications are** to either issue an advisory on increased disk space constraints OR to reconsider the current approach.

Assumptions:
  - 128GB SSD is used ([official recommendation](https://github.com/freedomofpress/securedrop-workstation-docs/blame/95fa2f0/docs/admin/reference/hardware.rst#L11) as of 1.0.0 release)

comments:
Another thing that will probably be out of scope for this analysis is the impact of updates and overall disk writes in thin volumes (which Qubes uses). Without constant disk trimming, even if files are deleted, they the disk size will only ever grow.

I see that there is a `fstrim.service` at least on Fedora, by which I assume that there is at least some trimming going on already. But in Qubes 4.3 this [will happen after every template update](https://github.com/QubesOS/qubes-issues/issues/5055).

So I guess we really have to consider this, but it's good to have this noted down.

issueDTO.title: GitDagBundle: DAG processor fails to load versioned DAGs due to missing materialized folders
issueDTO.description:
### Apache Airflow Provider(s)

git

### Versions of Apache Airflow Providers

_No response_

### Apache Airflow version

3.0.2

### Operating System

Ubuntu 20.04.6 LTS

### Deployment

Virtualenv installation

### Deployment details

_No response_

### What happened

When using GitDagBundle with `supports_versioning=True`, Airflow DAG Processor fails to execute DAG callbacks because it cannot find the materialized code under `versions/<commit_hash>/`.

Only the tracking_repo/ folder is updated with the latest version, but when a DAG-level callback (e.g. `on_success_callback`, `on_failure_callback`) is triggered, the callback request sent to the DAG Processor points to the versioned folder (e.g. `/dag-bundles/git_xxx/versions/<commit_hash>/dag.py`), which does not exist by default.

This leads to a failure in the DAG Processor when trying to load the DAG from the file. Specifically, inside `DagFileProcessor._execute_dag_callbacks`, the following code fails:
`dag = dagbag.dags[request.dag_id]  # returns empty
`

This happens because `dagbag.process_file()` cannot find the DAG file at the specified path (versions/<commit_hash>/...), and so the DAG is never loaded, and the callback is silently skipped.

### What you think should happen instead

The DAG Processor should also materialize the correct version of the DAG source code (i.e., clone the Git repository to the appropriate `versions/<commit_hash>` path) before attempting to load and execute DAG-level callbacks.



### How to reproduce

1. Use GitDagBundle with supports_versioning=True.
2. Define a DAG-level `on_failure_callback` or `on_success_callback`.
3. Deploy a new Git version and trigger a DAG run that invokes the callback.
4. The DAG tasks execute successfully.
5. But DAG callback fails because the path in the callback request is under versions/<commit_hash>/, which is not materialized
6. As a workaround, we patched GitDagBundle.refresh() to also clone the repo into the `versions/` directory.

### Anything else

In our environment, DAGs are triggered via Asset, but this should not affect the behavior.

### Are you willing to submit PR?

- [x] Yes I am willing to submit a PR!

### Code of Conduct

- [x] I agree to follow this project's [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/apache/airflow/blob/main/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md)
comments: Thanks for opening your first issue here! Be sure to follow the issue template! If you are willing to raise PR to address this issue please do so, no need to wait for approval.
Hi @liyude-tw, can I see the error you encountered here?

I believe I have experienced the same issue, currently using Airflow 3.0.6 with versioned DAG Bundles

The DAG level callbacks never execute and the only information is this in the DAG Processor.

```
--- Supervised process Last chance exception handler ---
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/airflow/.local/lib/python3.12/site-packages/airflow/sdk/execution_time/supervisor.py", line 387, in _fork_main
    target()
  File "/home/airflow/.local/lib/python3.12/site-packages/airflow/dag_processing/processor.py", line 172, in _parse_file_entrypoint
    result = _parse_file(msg, log)
             ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/home/airflow/.local/lib/python3.12/site-packages/airflow/dag_processing/processor.py", line 188, in _parse_file
    _execute_callbacks(bag, msg.callback_requests, log)
  File "/home/airflow/.local/lib/python3.12/site-packages/airflow/dag_processing/processor.py", line 230, in _execute_callbacks
    _execute_dag_callbacks(dagbag, request, log)
  File "/home/airflow/.local/lib/python3.12/site-packages/airflow/dag_processing/processor.py", line 236, in _execute_dag_callbacks
    dag = dagbag.dags[request.dag_id]
          ~~~~~~~~~~~^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
KeyError: 'email_alert_test_dag'
```

We are experiencing the same issue as @liyude-tw. We are running 3.1.2 on python 3.11 and are using a GitDagBundle set up to track a specific branch. 
Looking at the code, it seems like in airflow-core/src/airflow/dag_processing/manager.py, in _add_callback_to_queue, we are missing a call to initialize() on the instantiated dag bundle to ensure the GitDagBundle clones the version to the /versions/<commit> path. Since this is the only place in the code where get_bundle is called with a version supplied, the dag code cannot have been cloned to the version sub-directory before, yet the processor expects the dag to be in the /versions/<commit> directory.

issueDTO.title: [DevOps] Populate Meshery Catalog with Sample Apps using meshery UI
issueDTO.description:
## Current Situation
[Meshery Catalog](https://meshery.io/catalog) has a relatively small number of published designs.

## Desired Situation

Meshery Catalog is populated with a variety of published designs, representing any number of technologies in the designs and representing different categories of designs. 

## Difficultly Level: Beginner

This is a beginner-level issue designed to both help introduce you, the contributor, to additional Kubernetes concepts and DevOps practices, and to aid in creating a robust catalog full of cloud native design patterns and sample apps in the Meshery Catalog.

## Skills Needed

1. No coding skills needed.
2. Awareness of Kubernetes.

## Implementation

1. **Identify a Kubernetes sample app**
    1. Bring your own Kubernetes manifest or Helm Chart or Docker Compose file or...
    3. ...or identify a sample app from any available in public repos ([example 1](https://github.com/AdminTurnedDevOps/kubernetes-examples), [example 2](https://github.com/kubernetes/examples), [example 3](https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/kubernetes-engine-samples)).
    1. Attempt to identify resources that can benefit both newcomers and seasoned professionals.
1. **Import Kubernetes App**
    1. Import the sample application using import modal present in toolbar, [following this guide](https://docs.meshery.io/extensions/importing-a-design). 
1. **Publish Kubernetes App**
    1. Publish your sample app into the Meshery Catalog. Guides: Using Meshery UI or [Using MeshMap](https://docs.meshery.io/extensions/publishing-a-design).
1. **[Optional] Open App in Playground**
    1. Access [Meshery Playground](https://play.meshery.io) and open your app in [MeshMap](https://docs.meshery.io/extensions/meshmap).
1. **[Optional] Share your Kubernetes App**
    1. Be social and share your imported apps on twitter or linkedin and the Meshery project accounts will repost.
1. **Repeat**
    1. Import and publish five or more sample apps.

## Acceptance Criteria
1. Five or more new sample apps have been imported into Meshery and published into the Meshery Catalog.

---
### Contributor [Guides](https://docs.meshery.io/project/contributing) and [Handbook](https://layer5.io/community/handbook)
- 🛠 [Meshery Build & Release Strategy](https://docs.meshery.io/project/contributing/build-and-release)
- 📚 [Instructions for contributing to documentation](https://github.com/meshery/meshery/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#documentation-contribution-flow)
   - Meshery documentation [site](https://docs.meshery.io/) and [source](https://github.com/meshery/meshery/tree/master/docs)
- 🎨 Wireframes and designs for Meshery UI in [Figma](https://www.figma.com/file/SMP3zxOjZztdOLtgN4dS2W/Meshery-UI)
- 🙋🏾🙋🏼 Questions: [Discussion Forum](http://discuss.meshery.io) and [Community Slack](https://slack.meshery.io)

issueDTO.title: User-friendly Hydra Head Configuration
issueDTO.description:
### Description

One of the most common errors when starting a Hydra Head with a group of friends is the `cluster ID mismatch`, which comes about through a misconfiguration, by one or more parties, of either their: peer list, or, their `--advertise` parameter.

There are other ways where people can _intend_ to start a Head, but fail due to misconfiguration (i.e. one of them used the wrong contestation period).

These mismatches are hard tedious to diagnose.

### Suggested solution

We could revamp the configuration process into two parts:

1. A shared config file with (almost) all shared information, protocol parameters, and _every_ peer (including all of your own) information, as well as the relevant files relative to some directory
2. A tiny amount of command-line arguments that: selects which peer you are; sets the basepath location for the files specified in the config.

Then there would never be a need to gain agreement on args; you would always just check if you have the exact same config file (and the corresponding files in the relevant directory.)

### Alternative

- Let our users struggle.
- Have an endpoint that exposes the list of options and can be used to help others configure (including reading all files into literal values)

### Additional context

_No response_

### Todo

- [ ] When all peers are specified (including yourself) work out how to distinguish yourself from others, so you don't try and connect to yourself
- [ ] Decide which params we can put in this config file
- [ ] Decide rough format of the file
- [ ] Decide which (absolutely minimal) set of args we keep on the command-line
- [ ] Decide what we want to do regarding backwards-compatibility
comments: @ffakenz can you edit the description to include your idea of instead _querying_ the configuration _from_ the node, as an alternative.

> [@ffakenz](https://github.com/ffakenz) can you edit the description to include your idea of instead _querying_ the configuration _from_ the node, as an alternative.

In short, the idea is to have the node expose an endpoint that allows other participants to query and retrieve configuration values that people often struggle with, depending on the mode the Hydra node is running in: offline / online.

> Keep in mind, currently, each participant is still responsible for sharing their `cardano-verification-key`, `hydra-verification-key`, as well as their `host` and `port` information through other means to all other participants, since these are required to init and join the etcd-cluster and init the hydra head.

We could expose the following configuration values depending on the mode:

* Offline mode:
The endpoint could expose `--initial-utxo` and `--ledger-genesis` as JSON objects (instead of files), and `--offline-head-seed` directly.

* Online mode:
The endpoint could easily expose the following parameters: `--hydra-scripts-tx-id`, `--contestation-period`, `--deposit-period`, and `--start-chain-from`. Now depending on the online-type:
  * Direct Cardano: share `--mainnet` or `--testnet-magic` directly.
  * Blockfrost: there???s not much to share here, as they don???t prevent users from failing due to configuration mismatches.
> Note that we already expose the ledger protocol parameters via GET /protocol-parameters, which should be used to configure `--ledger-protocol-parameters` for online mode.

With the above, the envisioned user journey to configure a hydra-node to join a party would be:

1. **One participant acts as the initiator**, collecting all peers information and member verification keys (still through other means).
2. The **initiator starts their node** with the desired mode and configuration. From this point, they can either submit the `init` transaction for others to observe or, in offline mode, specify the `--initial-utxo`.
3. **Other participants start their nodes** using their own local configurations (e.g. `--api-host`, `--monitoring-port`, `--node-socket`, `--persistence-dir`, `--hydra-signing-key`, `--cardano-signing-key`, `--listen`), along with a new configuration flag:

   * `--initiator`, which specifies the initiator???s `<host>:<port>` value.
4. **Using the newly `--initiator` configuration**, each node queries the initiator on startup to retrieve the configuration being used, including all peer information and verification keys as JSON objects (instead of files).
5. These **queries must be signed** using the peer???s signing key, allowing the initiator to verify the request and accept it only if it comes from a trusted party.
6. Last but not least, note that the initiator is the responsible to assign the `node-id` configuration for each participant, possibly depending on their cardano or hydra verification-key.

This approach allows each participant to start their node with minimal local configuration and ensuring configuration consistency across all parties while reducing friction and potential errors.

Finally, to support restarts (especially if the initiator goes offline), the node must obtain the party verification keys from its known `HeadParameters` (which are available upon observing `HeadInitialized`) and query the already-initialized etcd cluster to get all its peer information.

> Lastly, it???s worth noting that the `--start-chain-from` configuration will be overridden with the latest observed tick persisted by each participant. This prevents a restarting node from catching up from a point too far in the past, instead resuming from the latest trusted observed state.

?????? Note: This approach represents a major refactor of our node start-up module.

Very interesting idea @ffakenz .

In my opinion it's a bit too wild of a readjustment, insofar as it introduces a kind of centrality that I don't exactly think is favourable; but happy to discuss with the team at some point. Perhaps it's worth isolating your idea as it's _own_ independent issue, because it's quite a different thing, even though it does address the same problem?

issueDTO.title: Copy to clipboard button not visible in st.code
issueDTO.description: ### Checklist - [x] I have searched the [existing issues](https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/issues) for similar issues. - [x] I added a very descriptive title to this issue. - [x] I have provided sufficient information below to help reproduce this issue. ### Summary Hi,I have a st.code that has a long value that overlaps with the copy button (see attached picture) Any ideas? :-) Best Regards Alex ### Reproducible Code Example ```Python ``` ### Steps To Reproduce _No response_ ### Expected Behavior _No response_ ### Current Behavior _No response_ ### Is this a regression? - [ ] Yes, this used to work in a previous version. ### Debug info - Streamlit version: - Python version: - Operating System: - Browser: ### Additional Information _No response_
comments:
**If this issue affects you, please react with a 👍 (thumbs up emoji) to the initial post.**

Your feedback helps us prioritize which bugs to investigate and address first.

![Views](https://api.views-badge.org/badge/st-issue-12958)

Hi @alex-bork thanks for filing this issue. It seems that this is caused by having long non-wrapable text in the `st.code`. We could fix this in a few different ways:
1. Moving the copy button into the toolbar we use elsewhere 
2. Adding some padding such that the content never overlaps the copy button
3. Adjust the zIndex and background color of the copy button such that it wins the overlapping fight.

@jrieke what do you think?

Hm yeah this is tricky:

1. Toolbar might be a good option to unify this a bit more, even though it could seem like a bit of overkill for just this single button that in most cases works fine. Would probably need to see this in practice to check if it looks good. We could also have the toolbar but move it down a bit so it's inside the code block (basically same position as today). 
2. We did have that in the past at some point I think, but I never really liked it, because it created and unnaturally big padding for every code block. 
3. I tried that at some point but getting the background color right is tricky. We do also use the same code block in e.g. `st.exception` to show stacktraces, which has a red background. I couldn't figure out how to make it gray in one case and red in the other, but maybe there is a solution! 


So I think I'd probably try out 1, and if that's not good, go for 3. Probably not the most urgent issue to invest a lot of time into though...

Hi everyone! 👋 I???m new to open-source contributions and would love to take this issue as my first one. Could someone please share the exact steps or example code snippet to reproduce the overlap problem? That would really help me get started and test possible fixes.

Thanks a lot!

issueDTO.title: Enforced URL for Manual Source Type in MNTP
issueDTO.description: ### Which Umbraco version are you using? v16.1.1 ### Bug summary Hi, I have a data type set up as a multiple URL picker, which I???m using for a page navigation. The multiple URL picker itself works as expected without any issues. However, why is the Source* field mandatory? For example, when I want to enter only an anchor or a query string and choose source ??? manual, it requires me to fill in the source field, even though I don???t need it since it???s just for navigation within the page. Is it possible to make this field non-mandatory? I???ve researched and I see that it???s set as mandatory by default, but can an option be added to disable it if a user doesn???t want it? Or did I missed something while researching for the solution? ### Specifics _No response_ ### Steps to reproduce Add Link property with multiple URL picker. Click **Source*** -> Manual Enter Anchor or querystring but still I can't add it without entering **Source** field. ### Expected result / actual result _No response_ --- _This item has been added to our backlog AB#61993_
comments: I agree source shouldn't be mandatory. In fact it wasn't in Umbraco 13 and our customers frequently used it to link down the page to an anchor. It would be tedious to reference same page, which would no longer be same page if moving a block to another page.

Hi @haskichasan,

We're writing to let you know that we would love some help with this issue. We feel that this issue is ideal to flag for a community member to work on it. Once flagged here, folk looking for issues to work on will know to look at yours. Of course, please feel free work on this yourself ;-). If there are any changes to this status, we'll be sure to let you know.

For more information about issues and states, have a look at [this blog post](https://umbraco.com/blog/the-umbraco-issue-tracker-process/).

Thanks muchly, from your friendly Umbraco GitHub bot :-)

Hi @haskichasan & @bjarnef 

Thanks for your insights, it seems like a mistake that the source is required inwhen the Source Type is set to 'manual'.

I marked this issue as up-for-grabs, it should be good first contribution to remove it and test that it works well without it.

issueDTO.title: Bug: Passing data to components using the data mounting option doesn't work
issueDTO.description:
### Describe the bug

I've tried passing data to the mounted component as described here: https://test-utils.vuejs.org/guide/essentials/passing-data.html#Using-props-to-set-a-minimum-length

The data mounting option doesn't seem to have any effect.

The test in the documentation works, but it tests a scenario which passes even when no data is passed.

Is this method of setting the component state even possible or wanted anymore with Vue 3 and the composition API?

### Reproduction

https://stackblitz.com/edit/github-dcrfqtgw?file=src%2Fcomponents%2F__tests__%2FPassword.spec.ts

### Expected behavior

I've adjusted the test from the docs a little bit to make it stricter and added 2 more test cases.

1. Similar to the one from the docs
2. Passing a longer password which should should not show the error
3. Setting the value of the password on the input instead of passing it

I would expect all 3 test cases to be successful, but the 2nd one fails.

### Environment

```
  System:
    OS: Windows 11 10.0.26200
    CPU: (28) x64 13th Gen Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-13850HX
    Memory: 23.19 GB / 63.66 GB
  npmPackages:
    @vue/test-utils: ^2.4.6 => 2.4.6
    vitest: ^3.2.4 => 3.2.4
    vue: ^3.5.22 => 3.5.24
```

### Additional context

_No response_
comments:
You're right, the component shown uses script setup so this can't work. I never use it, but I think `data` only works if `data` is used by the component.

This is a regression in the docs introduced by https://github.com/vuejs/test-utils/pull/2647

Would you like to open a PR and restore the component as it was before this PR, so it'll use the Options API?
That would be greatly appreciated

> Would you like to open a PR and restore the component as it was before this PR, so it'll use the Options API?

I think it doesn't make sense to just restore the previous state of the docs, as the `props` mounting options works with the Composition API, it's just the `data` option which requires the Options API. I can suggest a doc change with an additional section for `data` using the Options API. It would take me a bit more time and I wont be able to provide proper Chinese and French translations.

Sorry if I wasn't clear: there's no need to revert the whole PR, just the modifications in the passing-data.md file for `data()`, and maybe add a warning that it only works with Options API. We'll handle the translations, no worries 👍

repository.description: Vue Test Utils for Vue 3
repository.name: test-utils

summary.main: Passing data to components using the data mounting option in Vue 3 and the composition API doesn't work as expected.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The data mounting option doesn't seem to have any effect, and the test in the documentation works but tests a scenario which passes even when no data is passed.
summary.attemptedFixes: The issue is a regression in the docs introduced by https://github.com/vuejs/test-utils/pull/2647, and the solution is to either restore the component as it was before this PR, so it'll use the Options API, or suggest a doc change with an additional section for `data` using the Options API.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is about passing data to components using the data mounting option in Vue 3 and the composition API, but it seems to not work. The test in the documentation works, but it tests a scenario which passes even when no data is passed.

@Krishiv-Mahajan Sure! Let me explain issue #2480 in detail.

## Issue Overview

**Title:** Add to company cyber dashboard: news about company  
**Type:** Feature Enhancement  
**Labels:** Good First Issue, $5 Bounty  
**Status:** Open

## What is the Company Cyber Dashboard?

The BLT application has a **Company/Domain Dashboard** that can be accessed at:
```
https://blt.owasp.org/domain/{company_name}/
```

This is a public dashboard that currently displays:
- **Company Information** - Logo, name, email, organization details
- **Recent Activity** - Lists of open and closed bug reports
- **Bug Reports** - Detailed list of security issues reported for that company
- **Top Bug Hunters** - Users who have reported the most bugs for that company

## What the Issue is Asking For

The issue wants you to **add a NEWS section** to this dashboard that displays news/announcements about the company. This would provide additional context and updates about the company alongside the bug reports.

## Technical Details

**Files you'll likely work with:**
- **View:** `website/views/organization.py` (specifically the `DomainDetailView` class)
- **Template:** `website/templates/domain.html`
- **Documentation:** `website/documents/BltCompanyDashboard.md`
- **Models:** You may need to check `website/models.py` to see if there's a News model, or you might need to integrate with an external news API

## Possible Implementation Approaches

1. **External News API Integration** - Fetch news about the company from external news APIs (like NewsAPI, Google News, etc.)
2. **Manual News Entry** - Create a News model and allow admins to add news items manually
3. **RSS Feed Integration** - Pull news from company RSS feeds or press release pages

## What Makes This a Good First Issue

- Clear scope: Add one new feature to an existing page
- Well-documented: The dashboard already has comprehensive documentation
- Good learning opportunity: You'll work with views, templates, and possibly external APIs
- Has a bounty: $5 reward upon completion

Would you like me to help you plan out the implementation approach or clarify any specific aspect of the issue?
/assign

issueDTO.title: You're breathtaking!
issueDTO.description:
It's been over 10 years now that Godot has been developed in the open, with code contributions from 2,800 users.

The total count of people who helped build Godot is actually far greater, as it should include documentation writers, testers, bug reporters, translators, moderators, content creators, users doing community support or talking at events, folks making games that credit Godot visibly, everyone supporting the project financially, and many other types of contributions which I can't keep enumerating.

All these people brought Juan and Ariel's little-engine-that-could from this:

![Screenshot of the isometric 2D demo in Godot 1.0](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/713fc73e-65ff-45f3-8ef2-e3f364355656)
*Screenshot of the isometric 2D demo in Godot 1.0.*

To this:

![Screenshot of PVKK: Planetenverteidigungskanonenkommandant in Godot 4.3](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/671ce7d3-8955-44b1-9fab-90a641e44ffc)
*Screenshot of [PVKK: Planetenverteidigungskanonenkommandant](https://store.steampowered.com/app/2956040/PVKK_Planetenverteidigungskanonenkommandant/) in Godot 4.3.*

That's no small achievement, so I encourage all contributors to take a minute to contemplate the progress that we've made together over this journey so far!

Amidst the daily churn of fixing issues, reviewing PRs, making releases, etc., it's important to remind ourselves of where we are, and how we got there.

![GIF of Cozy Space Survivors where asteroids form the word "GO???DOT"](https://forum.godotengine.org/uploads/default/original/2X/a/a5a0d1684cdd56cda6371b13f34f4b97811c1284.gif)
*GIF of [Cozy Space Survivors](https://store.steampowered.com/app/2657850/Cozy_Space_Survivors/) where asteroids form the word "GO???DOT".*

## Some stats about Godot usage on GitHub

Between our usual traditions of either [making silly jokes](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/10000) or [sharing some inspiring stats](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/30000) for round issue numbers, I picked the latter for this 100,000th issue[^1], and wanted to look a bit closer at our issue and PR numbers over time.

A lot of people coming to Godot's repository to see over 10,000 open issues and 3,000 open PRs might rightfully wonder whether this is normal, or a sign of a maintenance issue.
I will make the case that it is a bit of both :)

### Issues

![Graph showing issue count over time](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/a62a11c0-6df3-4527-b433-9687400eda04)
*Visualization from OSS Insight showing issue count over time, [see the interactive version](https://ossinsight.io/analyze/godotengine/godot#issue-history).*

The two accumulated curves show the total number of issues created over the lifetime of the repository (topmost curve), and the subset of those which have been closed (as fixed or invalid). The difference between the two curves represents the number of issues still open at a given point in time - currently exactly 11,000, out of 53,648 issues total, so roughly 20%.

This is a fairly normal percentage of yet-unresolved issues in software projects of this scale, but it can definitely be better.

I annotated the graph with some key events of Godot's development which match peaks in either reported bugs (usually at the start of a beta phase, or shortly after a stable release), or closed issues (when we do a "spring cleaning" going through old issues to check if they are still reproducible in a newly released Godot version). You can see notably two big peaks of closed issues around the 3.2 release, when we had a coordinated effort from maintainers to go through the whole backlog and ask reporters to confirm whether their issues were still valid, or had been fixed. This reduced the percentage of open issues from 29% to 19%, and it's been mostly stable since, with minor fluctuations.

We are preparing a new "spring cleaning" to properly reassess a lot of the old issues which have been opened before the 4.0 release, or in the early days of 4.0 or 4.1, and may no longer be relevant nowadays with 4.3 and soon 4.4 beta.

As the volume of issues keeps increasing steadily, but the number of active bug triagers doesn't really grow as fast, we are working on improving and documenting our workflows so that we can:

- Onboard new volunteers to help triage new and old issues;
- Spread the workload and be more consistent with our issue triage;
- Be confident that while doing so, we do increase the _quality_ of our open issues, which isn't something that can be easily tracked in numbers.

We will share more details here and on the Godot blog when this process is ready to welcome new volunteers.

In the meantime, you can already do some simple things which help greatly the existing bug triage team:
- [**Regularly re-assess your own issues**](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues?q=is%3Aissue%20state%3Aopen%20author%3A%40me) (you can bookmark that URL). Make sure that they are reproducible in the latest stable release and dev snapshots, and that there is a minimal reproduction project that contributors can use to reproduce and fix the issue. If your issue is no longer relevant, please close it with a comment explaining why.
- Feel free to apply the same process to other people's issues that you stumble upon, especially if their last update was a long time ago. In this case you can't close issues yourself, but you can suggest it by commenting that the issue is no longer reproducible in the version you tested. Bug triagers will get a notification and can double check.

### Pull Requests

![Graph showing pull request count over time](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/cf5027a6-4ad3-49bf-9834-d0e1cab2fdc9)
*Visualization from OSS Insight showing pull request count over time, [see the interactive version](https://ossinsight.io/analyze/godotengine/godot#pr-history).*

I didn't annotate this one, but a few takeaways:

- Godot gets almost the same number of new pull requests per month than new issues, roughly 600 of each per month (that's 20 PRs and 20 issues per day).
- The PR volume increased a lot over the lifetime of the project to culminate at over 700 PRs per month at the end of the 4.0 development. Since then, as the Godot userbase grew a lot and we are more careful with compatibility and API design, reviews can take a bit longer and the total monthly volume seems to have plateaued around 500-600. That's still plenty enough for a fairly small group of reviewers.
- Someone should plot this data with relative percentages, but it seems like the size/complexity of pull requests is slightly increasing recently. Whether that trend gets confirmed or not, I can attest that reviewing 600 PRs per month is hard, and that we need more help for interested contributors and users to both test and review the PRs that get opened on a daily basis.

---

That's all for now, I was already way too long and verbose while drafting this at the last minute to (try to) snatch the 100,000th issue number ;)

Aside from showing some cool numbers, I mostly want to convey that we are well aware that we have a significant backlog, though it's not as dire as it might look from the outside.

To deal with it, we need better triage and review processes (which we are designing now), more volunteers involved in these processes, but also importantly [**more funding**](https://fund.godotengine.org/). Volunteer contributors do a ton of work, but many critical parts of the workflow depend on a few paid contractors, and we need to grow that group to better manage the increasing scale of the project.

[^1]: I'll make a quick note that 100,000 is the combined number of issues and PRs, which share the same index system on GitHub.
At the time of writing, we've actually had 53,648 issues and 45,213 PRs created. Astute minds will notice that the sum is not 100,000, the difference comes from spam issues or PRs which have been deleted by GitHub.
comments:
I shouldn't have waited, why didn't I camp this issue?!
(I've been watching this for an entire day !!)

Cheers!

![Stack Overflow's 100,000th Question cake](https://cdn.stackoverflow.co/images/jo7n4k8s/production/1e2dcc51c5ea8637fa3875fecdef306d7bcf990a-170x145.gif?auto=format)

Now we wait for #1000000 😆

> The total count of people who helped build Godot is actually far greater, as it should include documentation writers, testers, bug reporters, translators, moderators, content creators, users doing community support or talking at events, folks making games that credit Godot visibly, everyone supporting the project financially, and many other types of contributions which I can't keep enumerating.

Godot is a monster, in the sense that it is an extremely huge project, and it's amazing to think that most of it its thanks to thousands of anarchic altruist contributions.

Thanks to every contributor, from Juan & Ariel to the one that changed a "your" to "you're" in the docs 😁
Thank you all for your hard work! I hope you all celebrate this impressive milestone.

I wish I could help to the core project, but I'm pretty busy accepting too many exciting projects (please don't propose more, I don't know how to say no 😅). I hope you consider my work currently maintaining the "free & unsupported Godot Engine Switch port" as my grain of salt in the Godot ~~ecosystem~~ multiverse 😎

A gigantic THANK YOU to every contributor!
Without you, this amazing engine would not be the same (literally!).

Thank you for all the hard work! 💖

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/0785494a-c816-47a5-99c6-764163c53dbf)
Thanks to every contributor! As a learner of Godot, I leave my first comment at this exciting moment. Hope Godot will develop better and better!😆

I'm a little worried now that this issue is still open. Therefore it adds fake data to the stats. Someone should close it soon. 😅 

Nonetheless a great achievement to have it brought thus far! ??? 
Keep up, community, keep up! 😘

I want to highlight one thing that I think is a huge part of what allows Godot to be so amazing: it is so accessible and welcoming

Not only are everyone welcome no matter who they are, which is incredibly important, but everyone is welcome no matter how much they can contribute. I don't know how other open source projects work but to me the lack of bureaucracy and unnecessary processes and hurdles to contributing makes it possible to contribute for anyone who are at all able to contribute. Many of our contributors have only a little time to spend working on their contributions, and the fact that you don't need to sit through long meetings or write some proof of concept that gets approval makes it so much more accessible

Discussing ideas and engaging with other contributors is of course always important and encouraged. But you don't have to be able to in order to be a part and add your contributions

This means people from all over the world can be part of this, people working long hours, people who are single parents, or who are disabled, are at school, or any of a thousand different things!

It's of course hard to tell what the schedules for individual contributors look like, but from engaging with various PRs it is clear to me that there are many people contributing really important changes to the engine who would never have been able to do so without that freedom

This of course depends a lot on the work of our amazing production team, having as de-centralized structure as we have wouldn't be possible without people who organize and manage things

And I want to thank everyone for being part of, and constantly improving, this amazing community we have together!

issueDTO.title: [v1.16.0] Add support for multi-modal search
issueDTO.description:
This issue follows the [mega issue](https://github.com/meilisearch/integration-guides/issues/317) of changes related to v1.16.

## Description

We want to update this SDK to allow using **indexing and search fragments** to enable **multi-modal search**. This feature is introduced in [Meilisearch 1.16](https://www.meilisearch.com/blog/meilisearch-1-16?utm_campaign=oss&utm_medium=integrations).

For more information, see the [embedder settings API](https://www.meilisearch.com/docs/reference/api/settings#update-embedder-settings).

NB: As of Meilisearch 1.16, this feature is experimental. This might require updating the API related to experimental features.

## Tasks

- [ ] Update settings methods to allow configuring `indexingFraments` and `searchFragments`
- [ ] Add new tests cases
- [ ] Add code sample in [.code-samples.meilisearch.yaml](../blob/main/.code-samples.meilisearch.yaml) under the `search_parameter_reference_media_1` key. The example should be similar to [this CURL example](https://github.com/meilisearch/documentation/blob/301cf97a0bd3059c9b99abda475c927e4caa32c7/.code-samples.meilisearch.yaml#L1548-L1563)
comments: I am working on this.
