summary.attemptedFixes: I am working on this.
summary.otherNotes: This issue follows the mega issue of changes related to v1.16, and is experimental as of Meilisearch 1.16. It requires updating the API related to experimental features.

issueDTO.title: (feature) Expose flag_name label on all_flag_evaluations_total
issueDTO.description:
### Requirements

👋 As discussed in Slack, it would be useful to me if there were a metric exposed that tracked the bulk evaluations for each flag. While this would essentially expose the current flag config as a metric, I believe it may be useful to myself and others to be able to see at any given point in time, via the metrics, which flags are being sent to clients during bulk evaluations.

This will be rather noisy though, massively increasing the cardinality of `all_flag_evaluations_total`, so my suggestion as part of this would be to expose a new flag/setting that enables the additional `flag_name` label on `all_flag_evaluations_total`, so folks can choose to opt-in to this additional cardinality if they so desire, or to keep the current single-counter functionality of this metric.
comments: For the context, the slack discussion is [here](https://gophers.slack.com/archives/C029TH8KDFG/p1759954799548829).
This issue has been automatically unassigned due to inactivity.

repository.description: GO Feature Flag is a simple, complete and lightweight self-hosted feature flag solution 100% Open Source. 🎛???
repository.name: go-feature-flag

summary.main: Exposing a metric that tracked the bulk evaluations for each flag, with the option to opt-in to additional cardinality or keep the current single-counter functionality.
summary.validationOrRequirement: Expose a new flag/setting to enable the additional flag_name label on all_flag_evaluations_total, so folks can choose to opt-in to this additional cardinality if they so desire, or to keep the current single-counter functionality of this metric.
summary.otherNotes: The issue was discussed in Slack, and the context can be found at https://gophers.slack.com/archives/C029TH8KDFG/p1759954799548829. The issue has been automatically unassigned due to inactivity.

issueDTO.title: ERROR - Error in novelty LLM check: asyncio.run() cannot be called from a running event loop
issueDTO.description:
Hi Everyone! 

I'm trying to get openevolve to run locally on an HPC cluster with GPU access. I noticed that embeddings are not supported by default so I've made the following relatively minor modifications to the basic example and how embeddings are called: 
```

iff --git a/examples/function_minimization/config.yaml b/examples/function_minimization/config.yaml
index 42fb739..a153ec7 100644
--- a/examples/function_minimization/config.yaml
+++ b/examples/function_minimization/config.yaml
@@ -5,16 +5,17 @@ checkpoint_interval: 5
 # LLM configuration
 llm:
   # primary_model: "gemini-2.5-flash-lite"
-  primary_model: "gpt-5-mini"
+  #primary_model: "gpt-5-mini"
   # primary_model: "llama3.1-8b"
+  primary_model: "gemma3:27b"
   primary_model_weight: 0.8
   # secondary_model: "gemini-2.5-flash"
   # secondary_model: "llama-4-scout-17b-16e-instruct"
-  secondary_model: "gpt-5-nano"
+  secondary_model: "gemma3:27b"
   secondary_model_weight: 0.2
   # api_base: "https://generativelanguage.googleapis.com/v1beta/openai/"
   # api_base: "https://api.cerebras.ai/v1"
-  api_base: "https://api.openai.com/v1"
+  api_base: "http://127.0.0.1:11434/v1"
   temperature: 0.7
   max_tokens: 16000
   timeout: 120
@@ -31,7 +32,7 @@ database:
   elite_selection_ratio: 0.2
   exploitation_ratio: 0.7

-  embedding_model: "text-embedding-3-small"
+  embedding_model: "embeddinggemma:latest"
   similarity_threshold: 0.99

 # Evaluator configuration
@@ -42,4 +43,4 @@ evaluator:

 # Evolution settings
 diff_based_evolution: true
-max_code_length: 20000
\ No newline at end of file
+max_code_length: 20000
diff --git a/openevolve/embedding.py b/openevolve/embedding.py
index 74d3c57..a75ee3f 100644
--- a/openevolve/embedding.py
+++ b/openevolve/embedding.py
@@ -17,6 +17,10 @@ OPENAI_EMBEDDING_MODELS = [
     "text-embedding-3-large",
 ]

+OLLAMA_EMBEDDING_MODELS = [
+    "embeddinggemma:latest",
+]
+
 AZURE_EMBEDDING_MODELS = [
     "azure-text-embedding-3-small",
     "azure-text-embedding-3-large",
@@ -50,6 +54,12 @@ class EmbeddingClient:
                 api_version=os.getenv("AZURE_API_VERSION"),
                 azure_endpoint=os.getenv("AZURE_API_ENDPOINT"),
             )
+        elif model_name in OLLAMA_EMBEDDING_MODELS:
+            client = openai.OpenAI(
+                base_url=os.getenv("OLLAMA_BASE_URL", "http://localhost:11434/v1/"),
+                api_key=os.getenv("OLLAMA_API_KEY", "ollama"),
+            )
+            model_to_use = model_name
         else:
             raise ValueError(f"Invalid embedding model: {model_name}")
```

However when running:

` python openevolve-run.py  examples/function_minimization/initial_program.py examples/function_minimization/evaluator.py --config examples/function_minimization/config.yaml --iterations 50`

I get the following error

`2025-11-06 17:23:16,806 - ERROR - Error in novelty LLM check: asyncio.run() cannot be called from a running event loop
/cluster/work/danimarc/openevolve_testing/openevolve/openevolve/database.py:1018: RuntimeWarning: coroutine 'LLMEnsemble.generate_with_context' was never awaited
  logger.error(f"Error in novelty LLM check: {e}")`

and later 

`2025-11-06 17:32:54,927 - ERROR - Error in novelty LLM check: asyncio.run() cannot be called from a running event loop`

I wonder if maybe this has something to do with running locally as opposed to making remote LLM calls. I'm very happy make my setup clearer if this can make debugging easier.

Best,

Daniel
comments: Forgot to mention: using the latest git commit `ba1ca44b468553da75404972089ca60101f718a8` and python3.10,

The error is coming from the novelty checking with embeddings. You can disable and try.

In your config.yaml, set the similarity threshold to 0 or remove the embedding model:

```
database:
  # ... other settings ...

  # Option A: Set threshold to 0 to disable novelty checking
  similarity_threshold: 0.0
  embedding_model: "embeddinggemma:latest"

  # Option B: Comment out the embedding model entirely
  # embedding_model: "embeddinggemma:latest"
  # similarity_threshold: 0.99
```

Yes this works! If I understand correctly this wasn't really an ollama bug (which I first thought it was) but rather an issue with the 'diversity' code, that would (probably) persist if I switched to using a pure openai embedding model? 

I quickly tried out the circle_packing example which seems to run fine. Is the diversity code relatively new?
Yes it was a new addition contributed recently - https://github.com/algorithmicsuperintelligence/openevolve/pull/287 you should able to use the system without it.
I get the same error message running LLMs remotely (gpt-5-mini).

repository.description: Open-source implementation of AlphaEvolve
repository.name: openevolve

summary.main: The main goal of the issue is to resolve an error in novelty LLM check: asyncio.run() cannot be called from a running event loop, which occurs when running openevolve locally on an HPC cluster with GPU access.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The issue seems to be related to the novelty checking with embeddings, and the fix requires modifying the config.yaml file to disable or comment out the embedding model.
summary.attemptedFixes: The author tried disabling the embedding model and setting the similarity threshold to 0, which resolved the issue. The author also tried running the LLMs remotely, but the error persisted.
summary.otherNotes: The issue seems to be related to the novelty checking with embeddings, and disabling or commenting out the embedding model in the config.yaml file resolves the issue. The error message suggests that asyncio.run() cannot be called from a running event loop, and the runtime warning indicates that a coroutine was never awaited.

issueDTO.title: [manifest-editor] Add a button to remove unused dependencies to the toolbar
issueDTO.description:
Currently removing unused dependencies is quite hidden in the "Dependencies" Tab under "Dependency Analysis" among other things.

I think it deserves to be placed in the toolbar so it is easier to find and use.
comments:
Hi @laeubi ! I would love to work on this issue 
Can you please assign it to me?

@saumyapandey1998 please make sure you have a working IDE setup see https://github.com/eclipse-platform/.github/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#creating-an-eclipse-development-environment and make you familiar with the codebase, then just create a PR with some initial proposal for this.
Ack! Thank you

> Currently removing unused dependencies is quite hidden in the "Dependencies" Tab under "Dependency Analysis" among other things.

Multiple of the things in the `Dependency Analysis` section are useful but adding all of them to the toolbar could make it very croweded.
So maybe we should just expand the section by default to make the tools more visible (and seeing them in the Dependencies section makes IMO sense) or we could also add them at the overview page?

I must confess I never use any of them except the removal of dependencies. If anything is useful we should add it there as well (as the space is mostly unused) and could think about using separators or better icons then to make it clear
I am from CodeDay and I am working on this.

> I must confess I never use any of them except the removal of dependencies. If anything is useful we should add it there as well (as the space is mostly unused) and could think about using separators or better icons then to make it clear At least opening the dependency hierarchy is often useful: FYI: For my presentation tomorrow at the `OC for Tooling` session of the OCX Webinar week I plan to create a PR that changes the section to be expanded by default as part of my live demo. This shouldn't hinder other work suggested for this issue.

Just FYI: From my experience with clients they typically would have a batch option for this clean-up, e.g. doing this manually for 800 plug-ins is to time consuming. AFAIK this is currently not possible (batch checking for unused dependencies). If it is already, please let me know.

You can select multiple projects in the Project Explorer the rightclick > Plugin Tools > Organize manifests

Or use [tycho-cleancode:manifest](https://tycho.eclipseprojects.io/doc/latest/tycho-cleancode-plugin/manifest-mojo.html)

> At least opening the dependency hierarchy is often useful: I found the correct location to place the `Remove Unused Dependencies` button ( in progress PR: #1975 ) and I added a button for `Show the plug-in dependency hierarchy` as well. Both currently have sample data and are not functional yet. (text shows when cursor hovers over button) **Original approach** (PR: #1975 ): For adding the initial button in the main toolbar, I followed the following [article](https://www.vogella.com/tutorials/EclipseCommands/article.html) from vogella. The change of the button from the main toolbar to the toolbar of the editor (correct location) should be straightforward with a change of the `locationURI`. **Challenge I encountered**: I used the Plug-in Selection Spy to locate the identifier of the Plug-in Manifest Editor (`org.eclipse.pde.ui.manifestEditor`) and changed the `locationURI` to `toolbar: org.eclipse.pde.ui.manifestEditor`. However, when I tested it by opening the runtime workspace, I did not see the button in the toolbar of the editor. I tested different possible identifiers and looked through Eclipse documentation, but I still was not able to get the button to show through this approach. **Findings from different approach**: I chose to follow `Organizing Manifest Headers...` through the codebase since it already exists as a button on the editor toolbar, and I discovered the following: - `ManifestEditor.java`: contains function `contributeToToolbar()`, which adds actions to the toolbar of the editor and contains `getOrganizeManifestsAction()`, which retrieves and runs the action, and sets the tool tip text and icon for the button **In progress**: - translating what I originally did for the `Remove Unused Dependencies` button into a `RemoveUnusedDependenciesAction` class and then doing the same for a `PluginDependencyHierarchyAction` class **Question**: Currently both buttons appear in the toolbar of the editor for the following tabs: Should I make it so that these two buttons only appear in the toolbar for `Overview` and `Dependencies` ?
See https://github.com/eclipse-pde/eclipse.pde/issues/2115 - This functionality does not work reliable, maybe not a good idea to promote it via additional functionality.

summary.main: The main goal of the issue is to add a button to remove unused dependencies in the toolbar, making it easier to find and use.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The issue requires the contributor to have a working IDE setup and be familiar with the codebase. The contributor should also be able to create a PR with some initial proposal for this issue.
summary.attemptedFixes: The author has created a PR (#1975) and is working on a `RemoveUnusedDependenciesAction` class and a `PluginDependencyHierarchyAction` class. They have also tried using the Plug-in Selection Spy to locate the identifier of the Plug-in Manifest Editor and change the `locationURI`.
summary.otherNotes: The issue involves adding a button to remove unused dependencies in the toolbar, and also includes suggestions to expand the 'Dependency Analysis' section by default or add tools to the overview page. It also mentions the possibility of batch checking for unused dependencies. The author is working on a PR for this issue and has found the correct location to place the button. The issue also discusses the challenge of getting the button to show in the correct location and the findings from a different approach.

issueDTO.title: Add flutter_v2ray_client sample: Flutter VPN & V2Ray Client
issueDTO.description:
I would like to contribute a new sample project, flutter_v2ray_client, which demonstrates how to implement a high-performance VPN client using V2Ray/Xray in Flutter.

GitHub Repository: https://github.com/amir-zr/flutter_v2ray_client

Key features of this sample:
- Real-time VPN tunneling in Flutter applications.
- Multi-protocol support (V2Ray/Xray protocols).
- Easy-to-understand, minimal code for educational purposes.
- Includes clear README with setup instructions and examples.

This sample is educational and focused on demonstrating V2Ray integration in Flutter. It does not include the full app functionality, only the core logic needed to understand and implement V2Ray in Flutter projects.

Before submitting the PR, I want to confirm if this type of sample is suitable for the flutter/samples repository.

issueDTO.title: [Examples] Bootstrap functions vs. explicit code
issueDTO.description:
I'm struggling a bit with some refactoring we've done in the examples - explicitly around dealing with the result of the Platform.

I'd argue the purpose of examples is to provide working code snippets for various platforms & features. ready for copy & paste - and understanding what's going on.

in the beginning I introduced bootstrap for getting rid of secondary things - basically boring stuff that wasn't around Symfony AI. retrieving env vars with error message, a logger and instantiating an http client with a logger.

with functions like `print_token_usage` we now hide how to actually access and use the token data, and devs would need to switch from the example to the `bootstrap.php`
other functions in question: `print_vectors`, `perplexity_print_*` and `print_stream`

i get that there's a lot of duplicated code, but i think that's the nature of it. and I'd argue it's kinda stupid code, that is easy to maintain.

WDYT?
comments: hey @chr-hertel , can i work on this?
Yes, @pratap834, feel free to do so and submit a PR referencing this issue - thanks :)

issueDTO.title: Show already used port better
issueDTO.description:
This is a feature request to improve the user experience in case of the dynamic port range (defined by `--dynamic-port-range`) is already used by some other process.

Currently, the `couldn't find two ports with the correct offset in range` log message is displayed with stacktrace:
```
    thread 'main' panicked at gossip/src/node.rs:149:14:
    tpu_socket primary bind: Custom { kind: Other, error: "couldn't find two ports with the correct
          offset in range" }
    stack backtrace:
       0: rust_begin_unwind
       1: core::panicking::panic_fmt
       2: core::result::unwrap_failed
       3: solana_gossip::node::Node::new_with_external_ip
       4: agave_validator::commands::run::execute::execute
       5: agave_validator::main
    note: Some details are omitted, run with `RUST_BACKTRACE=full` for a verbose backtrace.
```

The log/exception message is hard to understand for quite a common problem that can occur easily in badly configured environments.

The exception is emit from https://github.com/anza-xyz/agave/blob/v3.0.10/net-utils/src/lib.rs#L535.

I would expect better exception message to stress the problem lies in a) in "dynamic port range" and b) the ports are well defined but unavailable/already used.
comments: We have considered having a fixed block of ports allocated for the validator rather than a range where it searches for available ports, it would simplify a bunch of operational aspects too (as operators would be able to know exactly which service binds to which port). That would allow to improve the error message too. What do you think?

Thank you for your quick followup.

To put more context in this issue, let me tell you my story. I am new to Agave validator and this issue made running my first validator harder, as with many Agave validator's ports settings, it was not fully clear to me, what exactly is the issue.

I was following the https://docs.anza.xyz/operations/setup-a-validator guide. In my case, the `https://api.testnet.solana.com` endpoint was responding with rate limit, so I started local `solana-test-validator` first...

Then I proceeded with the regular/fully-fledged validator installation and got the exception above. It took me some time to realize I need to stop the `solana-test-validator` and what port conflict it caused.

I am not fully sure if it is possible to easily distinqush the cause why a port was not possible to be bound, but I think the most helpful to the user would be to display the port/range that was tried to be opened/bound.

Proposal of better exception message:

```diff
-couldn't find two ports with the correct offset in range
+couldn't find two unused ports with the correct offset in range: 8000-8025
```

That would make clear what is going on and the displayed port range would guide the user quickly to the problem, as with known port range, it would be clear the issue is about `--dynamic-port-range` and not for example with `--rpc-port`.
I see. Small fix like this can be easy to implement.
working on it !

issueDTO.title: Idea: Expose the Envoy admin UI
issueDTO.description:
Contributors who set up our environment with `make local-env-setup` should either get an exposed HTTPRoute for the Envoy admin web UI, or a make target to set it up.

`kubectl port-forward -n gateway-system deployment/mcp-gateway-istio 15000:15000` works, but it might be better to give it a host name so that we can navigate to it any time that we have port-forwarding or a nodePort/extraPortMapping on.

issueDTO.title: Document our dev environment Make targets, such as debug-envoy-admin
issueDTO.description:
Developers who contribute to our project will probably want to use the same debugging and troubleshooting strategies we use.

We have a number of undocumented make targets such as `debug-envoy` and `debug-envoy-admin`.  We should add a table of these, or a paragraph explaining them.
